headline: Mike Huckabee, Anti-Reform Conservative
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Choosing the dark side of conservative economic populism.
lead_paragraph: Four and a half years ago, during the Tea Party’s heyday and just after the G.O.P’s 2010 midterm success, Dave Weigel (then of Slate, now of Bloomberg) wrote a piece in which he asked various writers, myself included, who had argued that the G.O.P. needed a new domestic policy agenda to explain why Republicans had won back the House of Representatives while (seemingly) just doubling down on small-government rhetoric and offering little that could reasonably be described as new. I can’t get the link to the original Weigel piece working, but here is my follow-up, which includes a point with some relevance to Mike Huckabee’s just-launched presidential campaign: Namely, that there’s more than one way to operationalize the insights about American politics and working class voters that Reihan Salam and I tried to offer in “Grand New Party” many years ago, and that undergird what we’re calling “reform conservatism” today.

headline: Robert Fairchild and Tony Yazbeck Have It All on Broadway Stages
abstract: The two dancers — Mr. Fairchild in “An American in Paris” and Mr. Yazbeck in “On the Town” — are bringing terrific performances to their shows.
lead_paragraph: Two young men currently exemplify the best of what Broadway has to offer: Robert Fairchild in “An American in Paris” and Tony Yazbeck in “On the Town.” They sing, they talk, they dance, they switch gears between those activities seamlessly, and their energy and charm stay long in the memory. Both men are playing roles associated, in the film versions of these shows, with Gene Kelly; neither suffers from the comparison with that Hollywood legend. And each gives the most remarkable performance in his musical.

headline: Ian Schrager Unveils the New York Edition
abstract: The hotelier’s newest property opens in the landmark Metropolitan Life Tower on Madison Avenue on May 11.
lead_paragraph: Ian Schrager, the Bronx-born, Brooklyn-raised hotelier, will unveil his latest property, the New York Edition, in the landmark Metropolitan Life Tower on Madison Avenue on May 11.

headline: Chita Rivera, the Oldest Tony Nominee, and Sydney Lucas, the Youngest, Discuss Their Work
abstract: The two actresses spoke about their careers and their Broadway musicals.
lead_paragraph: They met in the hallway of the Paramount Hotel. It was the annual Tony-nominees-meet-the-media event, and Chita Rivera, 82, was about to leave for her matinee performance when she spotted a fellow nominee, 11-year-old Sydney Lucas. She stopped, said hello, posed for a few photos. And then, while mugging for the cameras, the oldest of this year’s acting nominees pointed at the youngest and cracked, “Before, and after.”

headline: How Michael Zelehoski Activates the Everyday
abstract: The artist’s sculptures incorporate found objects like wooden stockroom palettes and police barricades.
lead_paragraph: Michael Zelehoski isn’t exactly finished with “The Allegory of the Cave.” The Massachusetts-born artist, whose first solo show at Mike Weiss Gallery, “New Order,” opens this Thursday, first delved into Plato’s famous thought experiment when he used it as the subject for his early admissions essay for Bard College at Simon’s Rock at the unruly age of 16. “Art is a shadow of a shadow. This is why a lot of these philosophers didn’t really have a place for art — they saw it as a distraction,” says Zelehoski in his self-built studio in Beacon, New York, where he’s been working since a fateful trip to Dia, the minimalist Mecca, back in 2011. For his upcoming exhibit, Zelehoski has transformed found objects, mostly discarded wooden stockroom palettes and police barricades, into intricately cut 2D, wall-mounted assemblages. The works function as optical illusions that seek to alter our relationship not only to physical space but to the often overlooked, humble, utilitarian objects that move within it.

headline: Under the Sea, a Missing Link in the Evolution of Complex Cells
abstract: Scientists have discovered microbes that have many — but not all — of the features previously only found in eukaryotes.
lead_paragraph: Unlike bacteria, humans have big, complex cells, packed with nuclei containing DNA and mitochondria that produce energy. All so-called eukaryotes share our cellular complexity: animals, plants, fungi, even single-celled protozoans like amoebae.

lead_paragraph: Jim Wright, a driven Texas Democrat who rose to the pinnacle of congressional power before ethics charges forced his resignation as speaker of the House in 1989, died on Wednesday in Fort Worth. He was 92.

headline: Kenya Steps Back From Threat to Expel Somali Refugees
abstract: President Uhuru Kenyatta said there would be no forced repatriations from the Dadaab complex of camps that houses more than 350,000 Somalis.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya on Wednesday softened a threat to expel hundreds of thousands of Somali refugees within three months, saying there would be no forced repatriations.

headline: Free Speech vs. Hate Speech
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Terrorism', 'Hate Speech']
abstract: A Texas art exhibit was meant to express hatred, not to strike a blow for freedom, and can only worsen religious tensions.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that images ridiculing religion, however offensive they may be to believers, qualify as protected free speech in the United States and most Western democracies. There is also no question that however offensive the images, they do not justify murder, and that it is incumbent on leaders of all religious faiths to make this clear to their followers.

headline: Review: Judy Collins Performs at Cafe Carlyle
abstract: The singer’s opening night performance was full bodied as she presented works by Stephen Sondheim and others.
lead_paragraph: The moon was full on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle, and I don’t mean literally. I’m describing the voice of Judy Collins at the opening night performance of her engagement at the club. The cool, sweet caress of her vibrato-less soprano has always evoked various lunar phases. Always lovely, it can be a delicate wisp or a graceful crescent. But on Tuesday, it was full-bodied, confident and pitch-perfect.

The Burlington, Vt.-based household and baby care company Seventh Generation was aware of that challenge and decided to take action by sponsoring the installation of four pumping and nursing pods in New York area airports: one in the JetBlue terminal at Kennedy Airport, two at Newark Liberty International Airport and one at La Guardia Airport.

headline: Review: Alonzo King Lines Ballet at the Joyce Theater
abstract: The troupe opened its run with a 2013 work, “Concerto for Two Violins.”
lead_paragraph: Alonzo King Lines Ballet opened a run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with a 2013 work by Mr. King, “Concerto for Two Violins.” It is set to a Bach score that for many dance lovers, especially in New York, is indelibly associated with George Balanchine’s 1941 masterpiece “Concerto Barocco.” The inevitable contrast is unsurprisingly cruel. The more interesting and favorable comparison is between Mr. King’s “Concerto” and the rest of his program.

headline: Review: ‘Caring for Mom & Dad’ on PBS Looks at Elder Care Struggles
abstract: This special explores the financial and emotional costs of taking care of elderly parents.
lead_paragraph: The discussion of aging often doesn’t get much further than: “Your parent has Alzheimer’s, and you’re caring for her? That must be hard.” A PBS special on Thursday night (check local listings) at least tries to go deeper. Though it still spends considerable time on elder-care anecdotes — stories that are heart-rending but at this point familiar — it also acknowledges difficult questions of costs, rights and medical capabilities.

lead_paragraph: The developmental milestones for a human at age 5 include drawing basic shapes, turning a somersault, using a fork and distinguishing between genders. In today’s retail climate, the most common five-year milestone for an upstart fashion house is nonexistence. For a label called William Okpo, the half-decade mark has brought about its very first stand-alone location, an airy boutique in the South Street Seaport.

headline: Lynn Grefe, Advocate for Those With Eating Disorders, Dies at 65
abstract: After her daughter came forward with an eating disorder, Ms. Grefe organized a national campaign to convince women that being too thin can be fatal.
lead_paragraph: If Lynn Grefe ever agreed with the adage that “you can’t be too rich or too thin,” she publicly denounced it as “dead wrong” after her teenage daughter confided that she was suffering from bulimia and anorexia. That inspired Ms. Grefe to organize a national campaign to promote education and treatment for eating disorders and to convince women whom teenage girls idolize, like fashion models, that being too thin can be fatal.

headline: Zac Brown Band Hits No. 1

lead_paragraph: Zac Brown Band, country music’s favorite bar band, scored its third Billboard No. 1 album this week with “Jekyll + Hyde” (John Varvatos Records/Republic/Big Machine), selling 214,000 copies and racking up 3.9 million streams for a total of 228,000 album equivalent units, according to Nielsen Music.

headline: Review: In ‘Oh! You Pretty Things,’ Shanna Mahin Dishes on Hollywood Foibles
abstract: Ms. Mahin, who used to be a personal assistant, has a heroine who works as a personal assistant for a demanding composer and an even more demanding actress.
lead_paragraph: Shanna Mahin’s “Oh! You Pretty Things” falls into the gofers’-revenge genre, to which “The Devil Wears Prada” and “The Nanny Diaries” also belong. But the difference lies in location, and in this case location is everything. Ms. Mahin’s debut novel is set in Hollywood, which she uses less to denote a geographical location than a state of mind. It’s that clichéd but ever-trendy place with two castes: the rich, beautiful, famous types and the yes-people who do their bidding.

headline: Julie Kent Looks Effortless in Ballet and Beauty
abstract: The ballerina’s tips on maintaining a dancer’s diet, the power of a pumice stone and a cleansing routine that combats the toll of stage makeup.
lead_paragraph: The ballerina Julie Kent joined the American Ballet Theater in 1985, was anointed a principal dancer eight years later, and will be retiring her pointe shoes after this season. With A.B.T. celebrating its 75th anniversary, Ms. Kent, 45, is slated to dance in “Pillar of Fire,” “Othello,” “Giselle” and “Romeo and Juliet.” Her role as Juliet on June 20 will be her farewell performance. Born in Bethesda, Md., she lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Victor Barbee, associate artistic director of A.B.T.; her son, William, 11; and her daughter, Josephine, 5.

headline: Andrew M. Cuomo: Fast-Food Workers Deserve a Raise
abstract: The industry profits, while its employees turn to public assistance because they can’t get by. Government must act.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — INCOME inequality is a national problem that leaders at all levels of government are grappling with. While American capitalism never guaranteed success, it did once guarantee opportunity. But today, too many Americans don’t believe their children will have a better life than their own. The ideal of mobility has been replaced by the reality of stagnation.

headline: Ciara’s New Album ‘Jackie’ Shows a Singer Evolving
abstract: Ciara touches on personal matters and stretches her vocals on her new album.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Ciara has been a stalwart of the R&B margins. At the beginning of her career, she was more a rhythm instrument than a singer — a high-energy, sleek dancer with chilly songs to match. That approach has sustained, but not nourished, her. She’s long been an unremarkable vocalist, meaning she’s been more memorable for delivery than content, for pulse over feeling. Her best songs — including “1, 2, Step,” and “Ride” — were often about literal movement, but almost never about what was happening on the inside.

headline: ‘Hot Pursuit’ and Other Films Elevate the Art of the Blooper Reel
abstract: When directors first began attaching outtakes to the end of their films the late 1970s, there wasn’t much to them.
lead_paragraph: When directors first began attaching blooper reels to their films’ end credits in the late 1970s and early ’80s, there really wasn’t much to them. Actors flubbed a line or several, or laughed when they shouldn’t have. In the 1979 comedy-drama “Being There,” one of the pioneers of the tradition, Peter Sellers struggles for three minutes to get through three lines. In “Smokey and the Bandit II” the following year, Burt Reynolds forgets lines and trips over others; in one scene, he mistakenly says dialogue written for a co-star, Sally Field. Back then, watching actors botch their parts was still such a novelty that the reels didn’t have to do much, or be much, to make audiences laugh.

headline: Premature Babies May Survive at 22 Weeks if Treated, Study Finds
abstract: A small minority of babies born a week or two before what is considered the point of viability can survive, a finding that could affect the abortion debate.
lead_paragraph: A small number of very premature babies are surviving earlier outside the womb than doctors once thought possible, a new study has documented, raising questions about how aggressively they should be treated and posing implications for the debate about abortion.

headline: Mosque Installed at Venice Biennale Tests City’s Tolerance
abstract: An installation by the artist Christoph Büchel puts the city in the middle of the roiling debate about Islam’s place in Europe.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — The 18th-century novelist William Beckford wrote that he couldn’t help thinking of this city’s most beloved sight, St. Mark’s Basilica, as a mosque, with its “pinnacles and semicircular arches” all “so oriental in appearance.” But despite the profound stamp that Islamic culture has left on Venice’s art and architecture over centuries, it remains one of the few prominent European cities without a mosque near its historic center, leaving Islamic residents who work there to pray in storerooms and shops amid the tourist crush.

headline: Barcelona’s Lionel Messi Carves Up Bayern Munich in Champions League Semifinals
abstract: Lionel Messi scored two goals and set up a third as Barcelona beat Bayern Munich, 3-0, and took a giant step toward the Champions League final.

headline: Ukraine: Soldiers Die in Strife in the Separatist East

lead_paragraph: Ukrainian military officials said Wednesday that five soldiers had been killed and 12 wounded in fighting in the separatist east, casting further doubt on the prospects for a months-old cease-fire that has never fully taken hold. Four soldiers died when their vehicle carrier drove over a mine in Avdiivka, a town just north of Donetsk, the rebel capital, and the fifth in an ambush, a military spokesman, Andriy Lysenko, said. The fighting flared as envoys prepared to meet in Minsk, the Belarusian capital, for talks on better implementing the agreement. Those talks broke up inconclusively on Wednesday evening. Ukraine’s envoy, former President Leonid Kuchma, said the participants had not touched on Ukrainian requests that an outside peacekeeping force be deployed to the region, though that had been on the agenda.

headline: W.H.O. Officials Report a Drop in New Ebola Cases
abstract: The World Health Organization reported the lowest weekly total of new cases in the West Africa Ebola epidemic this year, calling it an encouraging development but expressing caution about complacency.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new cases in the West Africa Ebola epidemic this year, calling it an encouraging development but expressing caution about complacency until all infections from the highly contagious virus have been eradicated. In an update posted on the organization’s website, it reported 18 confirmed Ebola cases for the week ended last Sunday — nine each in Guinea and Sierra Leone. In Liberia, the third country that has been ravaged by Ebola, the patient with the last confirmed case died on March 27 and was buried on March 28. If no new cases are reported through Saturday, 42 days from that burial, the outbreak will be declared officially over in Liberia. The number of deaths from the Ebola outbreak, which began more than a year ago, totaled at least 11,005 as of Sunday, the update said.

headline: Yoko Ono Trusts You Not to Break This One Espresso Cup
abstract: Her set of seven, seemingly cracked illy designs represents shattering moments in her life — and a single plain vessel is sold separately, to “never be broken as it will be under your protection.”
lead_paragraph: Yoko Ono is the latest artist whose designs will grace a set of espresso cups for illy, the Italian coffee company. Timed to the debut of “Yoko Ono: One Woman Show, 1960-1971,” which opens at the Museum of Modern Art on May 17, they were inspired by Kintsugi, a Japanese method of fixing broken pottery using powdered metals (gold, silver, platinum, bronze or aluminum) mixed with water and lacquer. Ono’s designs have the look of Kintsugi, with fine gold lines used to mimic a shattering effect, and each saucer features a sentence marking a shattering event in her life, with the name of the event and the date. They include the My Lai Massacre (March 16, 1968), the bombing of Dresden during World War II (Feb. 13, 1945) and John Lennon’s death in New York (Dec. 8, 1980). The set of seven ($250) will be available at the MoMA design shop beginning tomorrow — and one plain white cup, with a saucer bearing the words “This cup will never be broken as it will be under your protection,” will be sold separately for $40.

headline: Maggie Nelson’s ‘The Argonauts’
abstract: A pregnancy prompts a critic to examine physical transformation and the ways our bodies define and limit us.
lead_paragraph: To become a mother is to learn, among many other things, that mothers are treated as both central and peripheral to American culture. “The most important job in the world” is such a sentimental truism that even women who don’t want to have children report having to explain themselves to incredulous busybodies. Yet actual mothering is accorded little ­social or economic value beyond hazy reverence and pious declarations. Mothers are allowed some authority when it comes to their homes, their children and their bodies; their domain is one of domestic necessity, which is supposed to stand in mute contrast to the wider world of work, of ideas, of rationality, of free will.

headline: A Small Child, a Big Board, on Oahu’s North Shore
abstract: Taking an intrepid 4-year-old to Waimea Bay, where big wave surfing was practically invented, to learn the secrets of surfing from a master.
lead_paragraph: Standing cross-armed on the beach, stiff with anticipation, I watched as my little towheaded son made his first solo ride on a surfboard. Jacopo scrambled to his feet shakily, the wave propelling him toward us, and then, as his toothpick legs set into a wider, firmer stance, he determinedly stood up to his full three-and-a-half-foot self, a huge smile taking over his whole face. Back on the shoreline, my own expression reflected his joy. He was just a week shy of his fifth birthday, and I’d brought him here, to the fabled North Shore of Oahu, specifically so that he could have his first lesson with none other than Garrett McNamara, one of the world’s most famous surfers. I am still not sure who was more excited.

headline: The Cost of Getting Kicked in the Face
abstract: The policeman took a pained look at my mouth, and then asked if I had dental insurance.
lead_paragraph: This happened in June 1997. It was around 2 in the morning. I was walking home, alone, from a party at a friend’s house. As I walked, I looked at the streetlights above, first with one eye closed, then the other, and it was as though the streetlights were winking at me. I’d been doing this for several blocks, long enough that the whole exercise had turned from time-passing to tiresome, but I kept doing because it seemed like bad luck to stop. I was drunk, obviously, although not very, just relatively — just a relatively drunk 28-year-old man who was in relatively good shape, feeling relatively happy. I had, at that time, a good head of hair, and a mouthful of good teeth. Out of all that information, only the last bit is especially relevant to this story.

lead_paragraph: John Huston and Satyajit Ray. One might not think these two major directors had similar taste in movies. In the 1950s, Huston made “The African Queen” and “Moby Dick”; Ray made the three films generally known as the Apu Trilogy: the epic story of Apu, a boy born in a village in India who struggles for education and recognition as a man in the cosmopolitan city of Calcutta (now Kolkata). Yet, when I was writing a biography of Ray in the 1980s, Huston sent me a letter about Ray and his work. “I recognized the footage as the work of a great filmmaker,” he wrote. “I liked Ray enormously on first encounter. Everything he did and said supported my feelings on viewing the film.”

The jury of white men was discharged when it reported its inability to reach a verdict at the end of a five-day trial. The hung jury left undecided the fate of 21-year old Collie Leroy Wilkins in the March 25 shooting of Mrs. Viola Liuzzo, 39, a Detroit mother of five. A state prosecutor said no decision will be made on whether to retry the defendant until the next court term, in September. — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 8, 1965

headline: Review: ‘The Story of O(OO)’ at David Lewis Gallery
abstract: Exactly what all this adds up to is hard to say.
lead_paragraph: The title of this provocatively puzzling exhibition refers to the erotic French novel “The Story of O,” by Pauline Réage, and to a recent movement in philosophy called Object Oriented Ontology, or OOO. (Backers of OOO put real things rather than perceptions or mental representations at the center of the study of existence.) Here, works by six artists are arranged on and around a diagram on the floor resembling a hopscotch court. It’s from a chart devised by Graham Harman, one of OOO’s leading proponents, that has to do with how we know reality.

headline: Jackson Pollock’s ‘Mural’ Makes a Rare Trip to the Venice Biennale
abstract: This 20-foot-wide work is one of the least familiar landmarks of 20th-century painting.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — “Jackson Pollock’s ‘Mural’: Energy Made Visible” at the Peggy Guggenheim Collection here is a small show built around a leviathan. “Mural” is the 20-foot-wide breakthrough painting that resulted in 1943 when Guggenheim commissioned Pollock to make a painting for a wall in her New York townhouse. And because she gave the work to the University of Iowa Museum of Art in 1948, it has been seen elsewhere infrequently, which makes it one of the least familiar landmarks of 20th-century painting.

lead_paragraph: 101 YEARS AGO

lead_paragraph: How can you rely on someone’s opinion of a book if you don’t know what that person reads, and what else she likes?

headline: The Mystery Behind an Eye That Changed Color
abstract: It is rare for an iris to change color, but it can happen during some viral infections. Most of the time, the changes in hue are permanent.
lead_paragraph: How can a viral infection change the color of a person’s eye? Months after Dr. Ian Crozier thought he had recovered from Ebola, he was stunned to find himself developing intense eye pain and fading vision. The inside of his left eye was still occupied territory, full of live, replicating virus. And one morning during this siege, he looked in the mirror and saw that his iris had changed from blue to green.

headline: After Nearly Claiming His Life, Ebola Lurked in a Doctor’s Eye
abstract: Dr. Ian Crozier, who survived an Ebola infection last fall, calls himself a poster child for “post-Ebola syndrome,” which is also being reported in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When Dr. Ian Crozier was released from Emory University Hospital in October after a long, brutal fight with Ebola that nearly ended his life, his medical team thought he was cured. But less than two months later, he was back at the hospital with fading sight, intense pain and soaring pressure in his left eye.

headline: Rhapsodies in Blues

lead_paragraph: Tony Award nominees for best lighting design used a lot of indigo and steel.

headline: Latest Updates: British Election 2015
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron, leader of the Conservative Party, aims to hold onto power and edge the Labour Party, led by Ed Miliband. It’s a tight race and several other parties will play pivotal rolls in determining the direction and shape of the government, including the Liberal Democrats, led by Nick Clegg; the Scottish Nationalist Party, led by Nicola Sturgeon; and the U.K. Independence Party, led by Nigel Farage.

headline: Review: Instant Composers Pool Orchestra Plays at Roulette
abstract: This group of improvisers may be one of the longest-running entities active in jazz — if you choose to call what it does jazz.
lead_paragraph: The story of the Instant Composers Pool, a squirrelly, interrogative, original group of improvisers based in Amsterdam, began in the late 1960s. By a generous definition, the 10-piece ICP Orchestra, which assumed its present shape and sound in the 1980s, may be one of the longest-running entities active in jazz, if you choose to call what it does jazz.

headline: How to Buy Art: A Beginner’s Cheat Sheet
abstract: The hunt and its thrills do not have to lead to a giant price tag if you keep a few tips in mind.
lead_paragraph: You probably aren’t the one who shelled out $66.3 million for that late van Gogh on Tuesday night at Sotheby’s. And the stratosphere of next week’s art auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s, with works by Picasso and Giacometti poised to set records, is most likely out of your league too. Still, there are more earthbound ways to get into the art-buying game — at auctions, art fairs, end-of-year student shows and some big open-studio events. The next four weeks present art-buying opportunities galore in New York, with bargains for anyone willing to stray from the beaten path and stay alert. The hunt and its thrills do not have to lead to a giant price tag if you keep a few tips in mind.

headline: Omar Khadr, Former Guantánamo Detainee, Is Released on Bail in Canada
abstract: A judge said the government did not show that releasing Mr. Khadr, a former child soldier in Afghanistan, would cause “irreparable harm” to Canada’s international obligations.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Despite a vigorous protest from the Canadian government, a court in Alberta released Omar Khadr, a former child soldier in Afghanistan, on bail Thursday while he appeals his conviction by an American military tribunal.

headline: T. Boone Pickens, With Cash, Backs Jeb Bush

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The oil tycoon T. Boone Pickens is backing former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida for president, saying Thursday that he had donated $100,000 to help give Mr. Bush a leg up in the 2016 election.

headline: Review: Santu Mofokeng, ‘A Metaphorical Biography’
abstract: Our art galleries often give us what our museums should but don’t.
lead_paragraph: Our art galleries often give us what our museums should but don’t, as is the case with this small yet chronologically comprehensive survey of work by the South African photographer Santu Mofokeng. Born in Johannesburg in 1956, Mr. Mofokeng produced some of the great pictures of the apartheid years, but his images were different from many others of the time. His interest was less in a photojournalistic documenting of battles between South African blacks and the repressive government, than in recording the dynamics of another front line: daily life in black communities.

headline: Obama Chooses Nike Headquarters to Make His Pitch on Trade

abstract: While labor activists have criticized the apparel maker, Nike says that it has learned from its mistakes and that freer trade would benefit Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During years of debate about the costs and benefits of trade, few businesses came to symbolize the dark side of international commerce more than Nike, the multibillion-dollar apparel giant with armies of low-paid factory workers in Asia stitching together Air Jordans.

headline: The Visual Influence of China — on Pinterest
abstract: On the occasion of the Costume Institute’s new exhibition, the British jewelry designer and T contributor Charlotte di Carcaci curates a board of compelling Chinoiserie.
lead_paragraph: The Costume Institute’s new “China: Through the Looking Glass” exhibition, which opened to the public today (and made for an interesting red carpet at Monday night’s Met Gala), examines China’s influence on fashion over the years. Tracing such a visual thread from ancient artisans to the runway is something Charlotte di Carcaci does for each isssue of T with her “In the Air” column, which has explored the influence of everything from gardens and fairy tales to Latin glamour and marble.

lead_paragraph: Burundi, Nepal and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Drugmaker Sues F.D.A. Over Right to Discuss Off-Label Uses
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Amarin Pharma says it has a constitutional right to share information on unapproved uses of its products, a practice the government frowns on.
lead_paragraph: Drugmakers have long argued they should have the right to talk to doctors about unapproved uses for their products, as long as they are being truthful. And in some cases, courts have agreed. But the federal government still frowns on the practice and, in recent years, has fined drug companies billions of dollars for talking to doctors about so-called off-label uses for their medications.

headline: Review: ‘A Curious Blindness’ at Wallach Art Gallery
abstract: This show brings together 18 young artists focusing on race and claims of colorblindness.
lead_paragraph: If, as it is sometimes said, we live in a postracial era, why are reports about race and racial conflict in the news every day? This is more or less the question asked by three students in the critical and curatorial studies program at Columbia University — Vivian Chui, Tara Kuruvilla and Doris Zhao — in a cogent group exhibition called “A Curious Blindness.” The show brings together 18 young artists focusing on the functional fantasies that revolve around race and the purported colorblindness it engenders.

headline: In the Studio With a Cat-Loving, Genitalia-Painting, 72-Year-Old Artist
abstract: In the final stages of preparation for a new solo show, Judith Bernstein invited T into her Chinatown home, where she also works (and reads The New York Times).
lead_paragraph: The artist Judith Bernstein has been a trailblazer for more than half a century. In 1964, she was one of just a handful of women in Yale’s M.F.A. program; but rather than let the boys intimidate her, she befriended them. When pals like the playwrights John Guare and Kenneth Brown secreted her into the men’s room so she could see the graffiti there, she treated the experiences as material, and based her first major series of works — Vietnam War protest paintings emblazoned with lewd language — on them. In the decades since, her work has been unapologetically feminist, sexual, sometimes profane, often vividly colorful — and incontestably influential for generations of younger female artists. In the final stages of preparation for “Voyeur,” a new solo show, the exuberant artist invited T into her Chinatown studio.

abstract: Mr. Freeman and Ms. Keaton play a Brooklyn couple who need to sell their fifth-floor walk-up. They find that in New York, real estate isn’t easy.
lead_paragraph: If every longtime couple were as contentedly happy and healthy as the pair played by Morgan Freeman and Diane Keaton in “5 Flights Up,” aging side-by-side with a devoted partner would be something to look forward to.

abstract: This film by Bertrand Bonello offers an all-access look into the designer Yves Saint Laurent at work and after-hours with a perspective that is at once intimate and detached.
lead_paragraph: Like an E! channel reality show or an Instagram feed from the Met Gala, Bertrand Bonello’s “Saint Laurent” beckons with the promise of an inside look at the hectic and mysterious world of fashion. Shepherding you past security with a flash of a V.I.P. all-access pass, it confers instant insider status made even more alluring by the element of time travel.

headline: Venice, Your Roots Are Showing
abstract: Uprooted trees are in evidence at the Central, France and United States pavilions at this year’s Biennale.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that curators have a penchant for trees. Whether standing tall or forced into unnatural postures, a tree is on its own a kind of figure and en masse a component of a landscape. And in our ecologically strained times, trees are also urgent reminders of what a mess we’ve gotten ourselves into — plus a symbol of hope for greener days ahead. Arboreal uprooting is by no means a rarity in the contemporary art world, and it seems to have reached a critical mass at this year’s Venice Biennale, opening to the public May 9, where three of the most prominent pavilions in the Giardini are tree-centric.

headline: At Danziger Gallery, a Pair of Artists United by Playing With Abstraction
abstract: An exhibition brings together Enoc Perez’s “Cut Shapes” and Inge Morath’s “Masquerades,” made half a century apart.
lead_paragraph: “If Hugh Hefner and Alexander Calder had a child, this is what it would look like,” says the artist Enoc Perez of his “Cut Shapes” series. Currently on display at Danziger Gallery, the photo collages emerged from his paintings of nudes that he deemed not up to par. “I had a lot in storage and I thought, ‘What do I do with these?'” he says. “So, I started to add abstractions, like ‘little Calders,’ and each turned out to be a better painting” — and to play with censorship, plenty of which Perez has encountered on Instagram. (“You have no idea how many posts of mine have been taken down because they don’t meet the community standards,” he says.) He then decided to pull pictures of women from their social media accounts and apply the same principle, both an organic extension of his practice and a response to the age of digital sharing. “And,” Perez continues, “I like covering certain parts because people’s imaginations complete the job.”

headline: Review: ‘The Seven Five,’ a Documentary About a Corrupt New York Cop
abstract: Tiller Russell’s documentary focuses on Michael Dowd, a Brooklyn police officer who in the late 1980s was earning $4,000 a week from illegal dealings with drug organizations.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “The Seven Five” giddily revisits the true-crime deeds of Michael Dowd, a former New York police officer who was arrested in 1992 with a stash of cocaine on him. As the ringleader of a crew of dirty cops stationed at the 75th Precinct in East New York, he padded his income by stealing money, guns and drugs from dealers. He eventually graduated to working for drug rings, one of which put him on retainer so he could provide information about narcotic operations. “The Seven Five” has been called “the cop version of ‘GoodFellas,’ ” which may explain why Sony has plans to produce a fictional remake. Here’s hoping that version uses a better moral compass.

headline: Review: Marjani Forté’s Latest Work, on Urban Plagues
abstract: The choreographer’s themes in this trilogy are the interlocking, inescapable forces of poverty, addiction and mental illness.
lead_paragraph: Marjani Forté’s “being Here.../this time” begins on the sidewalk outside of Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center, on a block of Chambers Street bordering City Hall Park. As spectators gathered there on Wednesday, a woman in a wool coat and sneakers came gesticulating toward us, the courthouse as her backdrop. A vagrant evangelical, she preached about “His glory” and shouted at confused pedestrians — a convincing display of what New Yorkers habitually dismiss as “crazy.” Only her gauzy white veil, metallic body paint and a hovering cameraman gave her away as a performer.

headline: Review: ‘1001 Grams,’ by the Norwegian Filmmaker Bent Hamer, Mixes Levity and Gravity
abstract: Mr. Hamer is notable for his deadpan visual wit and his interest in odd jobs.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian filmmaker Bent Hamer is notable for his deadpan visual wit and his interest in odd jobs. “Factotum,” his 2005 English-language feature starring Matt Dillon, followed its down-and-out protagonist (drawn from the writing of Charles Bukowski) through a series of unlikely employments. None were quite as peculiar as the work undertaken by the researchers in “Kitchen Stories,” who perched in lifeguard chairs in middle-class kitchens in the 1950s to observe the habits of housewives. The title character in “O’Horten” had the relatively conventional profession of railway conductor but compensated with personal eccentricity.

headline: Review: In ‘The D Train,’ Jack Black and James Marsden in a Steamy Bromance
abstract: In this bromantic comedy, Mr. Black’s character wants Mr. Marsden’s to attend their high school reunion, but he gets a great deal more.
lead_paragraph: In most movie bromances, sexual desire skitters at the edge of the story, quivering like a man-child in a cathouse. The dudes in these movies tend to observe a ritualistic narrative proximity (they get close, but not too close) that’s echoed in the physical protocols of the typical bro-hug. In these familiar ceremonial interactions, the bros lean in toward each other for some upper-body contact even as they simultaneously maintain scrupulous, observable genital distance. Once contact is made, the bro-huggers exchange two or three hearty back slaps and then uncouple. In the comedy “The D Train,” there’s no such retreat — only sweet, sweaty surrender.

headline: World’s Largest Steel Maker Loses $700 Million in Quarter
abstract: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, on Thursday lowered profit expectations for the year and said it had lost $700 million in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, on Thursday lowered profit expectations for the year and said it had lost $700 million in the first quarter as a recovery in Europe failed to offset a sharp drop in prices for iron ore and steel. The company also said its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which is a more closely watched metric than net income in the industry, had fallen to $1.4 billion for the quarter. Earnings were $1.8 billion in the same period a year earlier. “We faced a number of headwinds,” Lakshmi Mittal, the company’s chief executive, said. The company, based in Luxembourg, cut the lower end of its guidance range for that pretax measure of earnings to $6 billion from $6.5 billion. Revenue for the first quarter was $17.1 billion, compared with $19.8 billion in the same period a year earlier.

headline: Movie Review: ‘5 Flights Up’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “5 Flights Up.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “5 Flights Up.”

headline: Dean Skelos, Albany Senate Leader, Takes Leave of Absence From Law Firm
abstract: The Long Island law firm that employed the state senator accused of corruption said in a statement that he is “currently on a leave of absence.”
lead_paragraph: With his grip on power in Albany slipping, Dean G. Skelos, the State Senate majority leader, who was recently arrested in a federal corruption case, is taking a leave of absence from the Long Island law firm where he has worked for two decades, the firm said on Thursday.

headline: Siemens to Cut 4,500 Jobs, Half of Them in Germany
abstract: Siemens, the German industrial giant, said on Thursday that it would cut 4,500 jobs as a slump in oil prices has eroded its sales of equipment to the energy industry.
lead_paragraph: Siemens, the German industrial giant, said on Thursday that it would cut 4,500 jobs as a slump in oil prices has eroded its sales of equipment to the energy industry. The cuts bring the number of layoffs this year to almost 12,000 out of a global work force of 340,000, or a reduction of 3.5 percent. Half of the cuts will be in Germany. From January to March, sales rose 8 percent to €18 billion, but the gain was because of the weaker euro.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Hot Pursuit’

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Hot Pursuit.”

headline: A New Labor Contract at the Expanding Cincinnati Orchestra
abstract: As recently as 2009, the organization was struggling financially, but musicians and management worked together creatively to turn the problem around
lead_paragraph: The orchestra world is all too familiar with vicious cycles of mounting deficits, dwindling audiences, difficulty raising money and cuts. But at the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, things are moving happily in the opposite direction: think crescendo, not diminuendo.

headline: Regarding Report, Tom Brady Says, ‘I Will Address It’
abstract: A day after a report indicated that it was “more probable than not” that Brady was at least generally aware of Patriots personnel deflating footballs, he appeared at an event in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: A day after a report commissioned by the N.F.L. indicated that it was “more probable than not” that quarterback Tom Brady was at least generally aware of Patriots personnel deflating footballs to gain an advantage, Brady appeared at a previously scheduled event at Salem State University in Salem, Mass.

headline: With U.S. Eyes on Iran, North Korea’s Nuclear Arsenal Expanded
abstract: While the Obama administration pursued a deal on Iran’s nuclear program, North Korea went on an atomic spending spree that some officials fear there is little hope of stopping.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — While the Obama administration spent the past two years getting within striking distance of a deal to delay Iran’s race for a nuclear bomb, North Korea went on an atomic spending spree: an expansion officials here fear Washington has little hope of stopping.

headline: Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase Agree to Erase Debts From Credit Reports After Bankruptcies
keywords: ['Credit Scores', 'Bankruptcies', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Personal Finances', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The two banks have agreed to update borrowers’ reports within the next three months to reflect that the debts were canceled.
lead_paragraph: Two of the nation’s biggest banks will finally put to rest the zombies of consumer debt — bills that are still alive on credit reports although legally eliminated in bankruptcy — potentially providing relief to more than a million Americans.

headline: Bank of America’s Relief for Mortgage Borrowers Is Questioned
abstract: Under its settlement with the Justice Department, Bank of America has in some cases offered forgiveness for loans already discharged in bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: There was plenty of fanfare last August when Bank of America agreed to a record $16.7 billion settlement with the Justice Department over dubious mortgage practices. Prosecutors crowed about the deal, which required the bank to provide $7 billion of consumer relief — including such things as loan modifications — over the ensuing four years.

headline: Riot Erupts in Iran’s Kurdish Capital Over Woman’s Death
abstract: Angry over the death of a chambermaid threatened with rape, ethnic Kurds in Mahabad burned the hotel where she had worked, witnesses and reports said.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Furious over the unexplained death of a chambermaid, ethnic Kurds in an Iranian provincial capital rioted on Thursday, apparently setting the fire that roared through the hotel where she had worked. Police officers used tear gas to disperse the crowds, according to news accounts, witnesses, and images posted on social media.

headline: Review: ‘Preggoland.’ It’s a Nice Place to Visit. Sort Of.
abstract: Jacob Tierney’s comedy focuses on a single, childless and irresponsible woman who pretends to be pregnant after a mistaken assumption.
lead_paragraph: “Preggoland,” a mild comedy about a fake pregnancy, has some rewards, though you have to be prepared to give it a chance. The central character, Ruth, initially comes across as irritating. By the end, though, the actress who plays her, Sonja Bennett, has made her likably irritating.

headline: Slushy Ice Is Springtime Hazard, Even as Arena Crews Sweat to Keep Cool Air In
abstract: As outdoor temperatures rise over the course of the N.H.L. playoffs, it becomes a greater challenge for crews at rinks to keep the ice cool and solid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before Jay Beagle took the ice for the Capitals in Game 3 against the Rangers on Monday, he stepped on a scale and noted his weight, to use later as a reference point.

headline: Review: In ‘Piku,’ Amitabh Bachchan Plays a Dad to Deepika Padukone
abstract: A young career woman and her demanding, aging father bicker at home and on the road in this Hindi film directed by Shoojit Sircar.
lead_paragraph: “Piku,” an offbeat Hindi comedy, would have you contemplate the intestines and mortality of one Bhashkor Banerji and the actor who plays him, Amitabh Bachchan. Bhashkor’s life and conversation may revolve around his constipation and fussy hypochondria, but there’s no mistaking the scene-stealing energy that Mr. Bachchan, India’s erstwhile Angry Young Man, musters for his new role of Cranky Old Man.

headline: Top Qaeda Figure Dies in Yemen Drone Strike
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Terrorism', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A senior leader of Al Qaeda in Yemen, his son and six Qaeda fighters were killed last month in a drone attack, American officials said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American drone strike in a southern port city of Yemen last month killed a senior operative of the Qaeda branch in that country who had recently emerged as a public face of the group, it announced on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Playing It Cool,’ with Chris Evans
abstract: Cut loose from the flash-bang-wallop of the “Captain America” and “Avengers” franchises, Chris Evans seems lost.
lead_paragraph: You know how awkward it is when you date a man and he won’t stop talking in voice-over? Allow me to introduce the hero of “Playing It Cool,” a struggling writer named Me (Chris Evans, insufferable) whose incessant narration — for audiences, if not for his luckless love interest — is inescapable.

headline: Armenia Official Criticizes Turkey for Genocide Denial
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Armenians', 'Ottoman Empire', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: Armenia’s foreign minister, Edward Nalbandian, condemned Turkey over its angry responses to global acknowledgments that the killings of ethnic Armenians by Ottoman Turks 100 years ago were genocide.
lead_paragraph: Armenia’s foreign minister criticized Turkey on Thursday over its angry responses to what he called the growing and “irreversible” trend of global acknowledgments that the killings of ethnic Armenians by Ottoman Turks 100 years ago was a genocide.

headline: Review: In ‘Maggie,’ Arnold Schwarzenegger Faces Zombies
abstract: The movie, about a virus that turns its victims into zombies, was directed by Henry Hobson.
lead_paragraph: Zombies, Arnold Schwarzenegger and a certain Terrence Malick je ne sais quoi — what could go wrong? More or less everything in this low-budget head-scratcher and periodic knee-slapper. A bearded Mr. Schwarzenegger plays Wade Vogel, a strenuously humble American farmer who, not long after the movie opens, retrieves his 16-year-old daughter, Maggie (Abigail Breslin), from a world crammed with artfully uglified, zomboid victims of a ghastly virus. Cars burn, fields burn and every so often — as when Wade gasses up his truck — one of these hungry zombies goes on the attack.

headline: For Patriots, the Bizarre Has Long Been the Norm
abstract: The transgression of deflated footballs is just the latest example of flimflam or folly from a franchise that has long lived on the outskirts of the pro football establishment.
lead_paragraph: The Gillette Stadium crowd was in full throat at the A.F.C. championship game in January, stoked to mock and tease the opposition by the team’s rascally leader, Bill Belichick, who stood on the sideline peering from beneath both a hoodie and a windbreaker against a driving rain.

headline: Review: ‘Intrepido’ Follows an Italian From Job to Job
abstract: In a land with high unemployment, a man is willing to do anything, for a time.
lead_paragraph: “Intrepido: A Lonely Hero,” set in “Milan, in these times,” opens on a day when rain falls on old snow. The protagonist, Antonio Pane (Antonio Albanese), takes short-term jobs, filling in for different people. He works at a construction site, in costume at a mall, in a kitchen and as a tram driver. No occupation holds his interest for long: When he delivers pizzas to a sewing factory, he shows off his facility with one of the machines.

headline: F.B.I. Says It Sent Warning on One Gunman in Attack at Texas Gathering
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent a bulletin to the Garland police three hours before the cartoon contest warning them that Elton Simpson, one of the men who carried out the attack, might show up at the event.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three hours before two gunmen opened fire outside a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Garland, Tex., the F.B.I. sent a bulletin to the Garland police warning them that one of the men might show up at the event, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared’
abstract: This often droll Swedish movie is a new entry in the genre that might be called Old People Behaving Hilariously.
lead_paragraph: The film genre that might be called Old People Behaving Hilariously gets an appealing new entry with “The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared,” a sometimes daffy, often droll Swedish movie. Among other things, this film dares to ask the controversial question: Can a cadaver dog distinguish between a body that’s dead and one that is merely triple-digit old?

headline: U.S. Trains Syrian Rebels in Jordan to Fight ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)']
abstract: American Special Operations troops have started training a small group of Syrian rebels in Jordan, with the goal of creating a politically moderate force with the fighting prowess to take on Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of planning and delays, American Special Operations troops have started training a small group of Syrian rebels in Jordan, with the goal of creating a politically moderate force with the fighting prowess to take on the seasoned and well-armed extremists of the Islamic State, senior Pentagon officials said Thursday.

headline: At Murder Trial for James Holmes, Conflicting Views of the Colorado Student
abstract: Prosecutors say Mr. Holmes carried out the massacre at the Aurora theater after his academic dreams crumbled. Defense lawyers argue he had a psychotic break.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — He is like a cipher in the courtroom, swiveling lightly in his chair, his expression placid. He almost never turns to glance at his parents just behind him, or at the families of the 12 people he killed and 70 he wounded in a shooting rampage inside a Colorado movie theater.

headline: India: Border Dispute With Bangladesh Nears an End
abstract: A constitutional amendment paves the way for a resolution by exchanging pockets of land near the border and allowing thousands of people to choose their citizenship.
lead_paragraph: Parliament unanimously passed a bill on Thursday for a constitutional amendment that paves the way for a resolution of a decades-old boundary dispute with Bangladesh by exchanging pockets of land near the border and ultimately allowing thousands of people to choose their citizenship. More than 160 enclaves exist in either India or Bangladesh near the border that are encircled by the other nation’s territory. The situation is rooted in centuries-old peace treaties and the partition of India and Pakistan in 1947. East Pakistan became Bangladesh in 1971. Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India called the passage of the bill “a historic milestone,” and Bangladesh’s envoy to India, Syed Muazzem Ali, called it a “historic and landmark day.” The bill must be passed by at least half the state legislatures before the boundary agreement can be put into effect.

headline: Guy Carawan Dies at 87; Taught a Generation to Overcome, in Song
abstract: With his performance of “We Shall Overcome” at the inaugural meeting of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in 1960, Mr. Carawan turned a little-known folk song into an anthem.
lead_paragraph: On an April night in 1960, Guy Carawan stood before a group of black students in Raleigh, N.C., and sang a little-known folk song. With that single stroke, he created an anthem that would echo into history, sung at the Selma-to-Montgomery marches of 1965, in apartheid-era South Africa, in international demonstrations in support of the Tiananmen Square protesters, at the dismantled Berlin Wall and beyond.

headline: France: Claims of Abuse by Troops Prompt an Inquiry
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: French judges will formally investigate allegations that French troops sexually abused children during peacekeeping operations in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: French judges will formally investigate allegations that French troops sexually abused children during peacekeeping operations in the Central African Republic, the Paris prosecutor’s office said Thursday. Prosecutors opened a preliminary investigation in July after a confidential United Nations report on the allegations was brought to the attention of the French authorities, but the case publicly surfaced last week after a report in The Guardian. According to the prosecutor’s statement, the United Nations report contains testimony by six children aged 9 to 13. Four of them said they had been abused by French soldiers and two others said they had witnessed the abuse, which is said to have occurred at a camp at the M’poko airport, in the capital, Bangui, between December 2013 and last June. The airport was guarded by French troops who were sent to the Central African Republic in 2013 to quell a sectarian conflict.

headline: Review: ‘Noble,’ the Crusade of a Children’s Rights Activist
abstract: The film follows Christina Noble, who emerged from a traumatic childhood in Dublin to build a foundation that helps thousands of children in Vietnam and Mongolia.
lead_paragraph: A feisty, passionate performance by the Irish actress Deirdre O’Kane gives the inspirational biopic “Noble” a serrated edge of defiance and gumption. Its subject, Christina Noble, is an Irish children’s rights activist and writer, who traveled to Ho Chi Minh City in 1989 and established a foundation that has set up more than 100 projects in Vietnam and Mongolia that provide protection, education and health care for more than 700,000 children and their families.

headline: Justice Department Will Investigate Baltimore Police Practices
abstract: The Justice Department will investigate whether the Baltimore Police Department engaged in a pattern of unconstitutional policing, a day after the mayor asked for an inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department will investigate whether the Baltimore Police Department engaged in a pattern of unconstitutional policing, law enforcement officials said on Thursday, a day after the mayor asked for an inquiry.

headline: Review: In ‘Bravetown,’ a Bad Boy Redeems Himself Through D.J. Magic
abstract: The film is part high school dance competition movie and part shameless flag-waver.
lead_paragraph: “This town is good for nothing but turning out future soldiers,” says Mary (Kherington Payne), the glum captain of a North Dakota high school dance team in the excruciating “Bravetown,” an unwieldy hybrid of high school dance competition movie and shameless flag-waver.

headline: Capitals’ Stars Are Sharing Spotlight With Rookies During Postseason Run
abstract: Washington’s roster has stars such as Alex Ovechkin, but in the postseason, two European rookies are leading the Capitals as they have taken the Rangers to the brink of elimination.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — When the Washington Capitals selected the Russian winger Alex Ovechkin as the No. 1 overall pick in the 2004 draft, it was a consolation prize for having played miserable hockey.

headline: Obama Administration Urges Fast Action on New Hudson River Rail Tunnels
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Commuting', 'Railroads', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: A Transportation Department official lightly chastised New York-area transit leaders for inaction on new rail links between the city and New Jersey, a project the White House has ranked as a high priority.
lead_paragraph: Elected officials usually have to go to Washington and beg for federal support to build huge transportation projects. On Thursday, on a high floor of the tallest building in New York City, that dynamic was on display in reverse.

headline: Spieth Gets Lesson on Intricacies of Course at Sawgrass
abstract: Rory McIlroy and Jason Day positioned themselves nicely with matching 69s, two strokes behind the leaders, while Jason Spieth struggled to a 75.
lead_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Jordan Spieth did not look at T.P.C. Sawgrass and see the danger lurking around every moss-laden oak. As one might expect of someone with four victories in his last 12 stroke-play starts dating to last year’s Australian Open, Spieth saw fairways as wide as meadows and holes the size of Frisbees.

headline: ‘Forbidden Films’ Exhumes Nazi Poison From the Movie Vaults
abstract: Felix Moeller’s documentary “Forbidden Films: The Hidden Legacy of Nazi Film” examines movies banned in Germany from the Nazi period and contemporary reactions to them.
lead_paragraph: The Third Reich was not only a totalitarian state but also a total multimedia regime. Seven decades after its fiery collapse, the embers remain — including some 1,200 feature films produced under Joseph Goebbels’s ministry of propaganda. Are they historical evidence, incitements to murder, fascist pornography, evergreen entertainments, toxic waste or passé kitsch? All of the above?

headline: Fox Hunt Leader of Old
abstract: Friday fun with Ian Livengood.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Man, this was a tough one for me. There’s nothing like a puzzle like this one by Ian Livengood to highlight what you don’t know.

headline: Review: In ‘Cool Hand Luke,’ the Ultimate Escape
abstract: The Godlight Theater Company brings a hero back to life at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every man who can flee a chain gang while shackled in two sets of leg irons, but Luke Jackson isn’t just anyone. A hero, an outlaw and an iconoclast, immortalized by Paul Newman in the 1967 film based on the Donn Pearce novel, Luke has returned to us courtesy of the Godlight Theater Company at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Louis Nuñez, Champion of Puerto Ricans, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Nuñez worked to advance educational and economic opportunity for Puerto Ricans in the United States for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: Louis Nuñez, a champion of educational and economic opportunity for Puerto Ricans for more than three decades, died on April 30 at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 83.

headline: Dianne White Clatto, Weathercaster Who Broke a Color Barrier, Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Clatto, who transitioned from radio host to a television “weathergirl” in St. Louis, became the first full-time black television weathercaster in the country in 1962.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years before Al Roker started as a weather anchor for a CBS affiliate in Syracuse, Dianne White Clatto made broadcasting history in St. Louis. In 1962, according to industry colleagues, she became the first full-time black television weathercaster in the country.

headline: Disney Names Marketer to Run Consumer Products Division
abstract: Leslie Ferraro, who will become president of Disney Consumer Products, joined the company’s theme park business 16 years ago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company’s top theme park marketer will take over its fast-growing consumer products division, an appointment that fills an important vacancy and brings a woman into the entertainment conglomerate’s most senior ranks.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Latest Budget Won’t Pay for More Police Officers
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio suggested that changes under his administration had already eased the burden on officers’ time, even as crime remained relatively low.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday outlined a $78.3 billion budget — an increase of more than 4 percent from the spending plan adopted last June — putting forth a series of proposals intended to reduce income inequality but rebuffing requests from the City Council and his own police commissioner to add officers to the force.

headline: Homeland Security Chief Hears Skepticism on Effort to Identify Extremists
abstract: In Brooklyn meetings with civil rights and Muslim representatives, Jeh Johnson, the Homeland Security secretary, asked for community help in countering the lure if ISIS propaganda.
lead_paragraph: The timing could not have been more appropriate, the Homeland Security secretary, Jeh Johnson, remarked, for him to hold a day of preplanned meetings with Muslim, interfaith and civil rights community leaders in New York on Thursday.

headline: Paternity Case for a New Jersey Mother of Twins Bears Unexpected Results: Two Fathers
abstract: In an unusual ruling, a judge found that egg and sperm had colluded to create a medical oddity: The man whom the woman claimed to be the father of her twins was deemed responsible for only one.
lead_paragraph: A mother of twins was applying for public assistance in Passaic County, N.J., when she made the seemingly uncontroversial claim that one man was responsible for her progeny.

headline: American Will Pursue Tennis’s Top Global Post
abstract: David Haggerty will run for president of the sport’s global governing body, the International Tennis Federation.
lead_paragraph: David Haggerty, the former United States Tennis Association president who helped lead the effort to build a roof at Arthur Ashe Stadium and a new national training center in Orlando, Fla., will run for president of the sport’s global governing body, the International Tennis Federation.

headline: Rodriguez Passes Mays but Still Doesn’t Collect
abstract: Alex Rodriguez hit his 661st home run to pass Willie Mays for fourth on the career list, but the Yankees, who edged the Orioles, were not planning to pay him a bonus for the achievement.
lead_paragraph: The person who first seemed to recognize that Alex Rodriguez had hit his 661st career home run Thursday night was Adam Jones, the Baltimore Orioles’ center fielder, who took a few steps toward the wall in left-center and then stopped, as if he knew his chase was futile, knew the ball was gone.

headline: Not Nothing
abstract: Achieving dewiness — skin that glistens with moisture or glows with its own good health — is more complicated than it looks.
lead_paragraph: Achieving dewiness — skin that glistens with moisture or glows with its own good health — is more complicated than it looks.

abstract: In the ancient hills of Jawai in northwest India, locals and big cats have peacefully coexisted for centuries like nowhere else in the world. As safarigoers arrive to experience the unique environment, can the harmony last?
lead_paragraph: In the ancient hills of Jawai in northwest India, locals and big cats have peacefully coexisted for centuries like nowhere else in the world. As safarigoers arrive to experience the unique environment, can the harmony last?

headline: Seattle Storm Express Concern After Liberty’s Hiring of Isiah Thomas
abstract: Seattle’s owners emphasized a duty to address “sexual harassment, domestic violence and sexual assault, all of which have been inadequately addressed for far too long.”
lead_paragraph: Two days after Isiah Thomas was named the president of the Liberty and given part ownership of the W.N.B.A. team, the Seattle Storm issued a statement expressing concern over the development and implying that they might vote not to approve Thomas’s ownership stake.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:10 P.M. (HBO Signature) BELLE (2014) The biracial daughter (Gugu Mbatha-Raw) of a British Navy captain (Matthew Goode) struggles to transcend the problems of living as a black woman in slave-trading England after being raised in privilege by her aristocratic uncle and aunt (Tom Wilkinson and Emily Watson), and alongside her white cousin (Sarah Gadon). This biopic about Dido Elizabeth Belle (1761-1804), directed by Amma Asante and written by Misan Sagay, chronicles the difficult love life of Belle, an educated beauty — including a dashing suitor, John Davinier (Sam Reid), as well as several not-so-charming ones. The movie also covers Belle’s uncle, the Lord Chief Justice, who must decide on a case involving a slave ship on which more than 130 Africans were massacred for an insurance payment. “The movie plays with the historical record for dramatic effect, as is often the case when the past is disinterred for entertainment, and its realism at times groans under the weight of too many passionate speeches,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Yet the weave of the personal and the political finally proves as irresistible as it is moving, partly because it has been drawn from extraordinary life.”

headline: David Cameron and Conservatives Get Majority in British Election
abstract: The result defies pre-election opinion polls that suggested a tight race between the Tories and Labour, and it gives Mr. Cameron a second term as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron and his Conservatives won a resounding victory in the British general election, with complete results on Friday showing that the party had secured an overall majority in Parliament.

headline: Photographs of Everyday African-American Pride in Queens
abstract: A photographer goes back to St. Albans, a Queens neighborhood that has been a proud middle-class African-American enclave.
lead_paragraph: The pizza shop on Farmers Boulevard where Elias Williams and his friends hung out as teenagers seemingly has a new owner every year. His longtime barbershop spun off a convenience store to help pay the rising rent. And some of his childhood friends and their families are gone, their houses dark, empty and financially under water.

headline: Conservative Party Wins Surprising Victory in Britain’s General Election
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron and his party emerged victorious, with partial results showing that the party will at a minimum come close to winning an overall majority in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron and his party emerged victorious, with partial results showing that the party will at a minimum come close to winning an overall majority in Parliament.

headline: The Growing Generational Divide
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Elderly', 'Age, Chronological', 'Children and Childhood', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: What do we lose as we drift further away from our elders?
lead_paragraph: BEREA, Ky. — I WAS always with older folks when I was very young. They called me “Little Man” and told me I was “an old soul.” I worked in the garden with my grandparents, learned how to count money with Old Man Hoskins at the local store, and eavesdropped on the tales of my ancient neighbors. But it was the stories of my fierce aunt, Sis, that were my favorite.

headline: Mothers and Presidents
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Families and Family Life', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Dynasties in politics and business tip the playing field, but we wouldn’t want to live in a society without them.
lead_paragraph: Americans are embarrassed. Over the last 35 years there have only been two elections without a Bush or Clinton on the national ticket. Next year both names could rest atop the ballot. In one poll voters saw this as a bad thing by a ratio of 8 to 1.

headline: Triumph of the Unthinking
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: It is easier to appeal to voters with nonsense economics than to think things through.
lead_paragraph: “Words,” wrote John Maynard Keynes, “ought to be a little wild, for they are the assault of thoughts on the unthinking.” I’ve always loved that quote, and have tried to apply it to my own writing. But I have to admit that in the long slump that followed the 2008 financial crisis — a slump that we had both the tools and the knowledge to end quickly, but didn’t — the unthinking were quite successful in fending off unwelcome thoughts.

headline: The New SAT: Will It Be Better?

abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed essay that criticized how SAT exams are graded based on a bell curve.

headline: Don’t Rehab La Guardia Airport. Close It.
abstract: It’s beyond saving. And J.F.K. and Newark can absorb its passengers.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey put off, yet again, deciding between two proposals for a nearly $4 billion project to rehabilitate the dilapidated Central Terminal Building at La Guardia Airport. Disdain about the disrepair, crowds and grubbiness at La Guardia is so pervasive that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has likened La Guardia to an experience “in a third world country.”

headline: Measure California’s Water
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Water', 'Drought', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The state can only get a handle on its drought problem if it knows exactly where, and how much, water is being used.
lead_paragraph: California’s water board voted Tuesday to impose new rules that would reduce the state’s urban water use by 25 percent, as mandated by Gov. Jerry Brown at the beginning of April. By requiring towns and cities to cut back, the state expects to save about 1.3 million acre-feet of water over the next nine months. Rationing in urban areas will be tiered. headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘X Minus One’
abstract: A dystopian radio drama from the 1950s becomes a modern sleep potion.
lead_paragraph: I can’t fall asleep in silence. Eyes closed, earplugs in, I consume free audio as if it were Ambien. For years I burned through podcasts, before moving on to off-hours international talk shows. I drowsed through introductory university lectures. I discovered that there are at least 8,000 public-domain audiobooks available online, narrated by volunteers. I can’t say for sure how many I started, but I know exactly how many I finished (none). It was a couple thousand nights into this habit that I ended up on “X Minus One,” a 1955 NBC radio anthology about time, space, war, apocalypse and the future: a 60-year-old exercise in figuring out how things might be today. It was, for my ritual, perfect.

When Sherry Turkle, a psychologist who directs the M.I.T. Initiative on Technology and Self, examined the effects of digital technology on our lives, she gave her book the title “Alone Together.”

headline: Confederates in the Jungle
abstract: Why did tens of thousands of rebels move to Latin America after the Civil War?
lead_paragraph: The Fourth of July celebration has all the hallmarks of a scene from “Gone with the Wind,” or a county fair in the most unreconstructed corners of Mississippi or Alabama. The men, dressed in Confederate gray shell jackets, yellow-trimmed frock coats, kepis and plumed black slouch hats, cross the dance floor to select their partners, elegant young women in colorful hoop-skirted ball gowns. Arm in arm, they step to the rhythms of ancient dances, as the fiddle and banjo strike up the old-time strains of “Dixie’s Land,” “The Yellow Rose of Texas,” “The Virginia Reel” and “Cumberland Gap.”

headline: Where Would the Kardashians Be Without Kris Jenner?
abstract: The mother, and manager, of reality TV’s most famous clan has created a strange new form of family business — and changed the nature of celebrity.
lead_paragraph: Kris Jenner slowly descended one side of the curving double staircase in her home in Hidden Hills, Calif., like some sort of grande dame, like Elizabeth Taylor in a White Diamonds commercial, only dressed head to toe in black: Balmain blazer, Rag & Bone jeans and Chanel ankle boots. When she reached the foyer, she greeted the former ’N Sync member Lance Bass, kissing him on both cheeks, and then said hello to Tom, who was . . . Bass’s assistant? His producer? Everyone there was an assistant and everyone was a producer. Whatever Tom’s official job title was, his actual name was Bob, and he corrected Kris, who smiled and explained that they really were the same name. A production assistant in surgical shoe coverings handed out microphones, and people wired themselves up through the bottoms of their shirts while Kris invited them into the kitchen for coffeecake.
