abstract: A whimsical mascot in the Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, neighborhood, known as Broken Angel, with eclectic, stacked rooftop additions is being converted to luxury condominiums.
lead_paragraph: Standing at Downing and Quincy Streets in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, one would never know that the handsome yet unremarkable brick building on the quiet corner was once a whimsical neighborhood mascot known as Broken Angel, with eclectic, stacked rooftop additions that reached ever higher.

headline: Bedazzled Sandals
abstract: The humble shower slide has ascended to high fashion, with crystal beading, golden grommets and a metallic sheen.
lead_paragraph: The humble shower slide has ascended to high fashion, with crystal beading, golden grommets and a metallic sheen.

headline: For Carly Fiorina, Resentment Over Firing Softens With Time
abstract: If Carly Fiorina emerges as a serious contender for the Republican presidential nomination, her ouster at Hewlett-Packard 10 years ago, along with her two books since, will likely face more scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: It has been 10 years and two autobiographies since Carly Fiorina was ousted as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, the technology giant where she began her career as a secretary

headline: Review: Young Concert Artists Gala Features Three Rising Soloists
abstract: The pianists Ji and George Li, and the violinist Benjamin Beilman performed concertos with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz.
lead_paragraph: Young Concert Artists makes no claim to quality in its name. But over 54 years, through its choices of artists it has helped to develop careers, in many cases, major ones.

headline: April Jobs: Not Good News. Not Bad News. Relieving News.
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The 223,000 jobs added are the latest evidence that the steady-as-she-goes recovery remains exactly that, for both optimists and pessimists.
lead_paragraph: The latest jobs numbers are a classic glass half-empty/glass half-full report on the state of the economy.

headline: How to Talk to Your Child’s Wary Professors
abstract: Let’s do this together, and let’s be nice, so that when we meet at graduation, it won’t be weird.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, at universities around the United States, a miracle will occur. Parents and professors will watch their college students walk with awkward confidence across stages, and for the first time in years, many of those students will be wearing clean laundry. Afterward, those students will want to introduce their biological parents to their intellectual parents.

headline: Chinese Province Issues Draft Regulation on Church Crosses
abstract: The rules put new legal force behind a continuing campaign in Zhejiang to remove crosses from the tops of churches.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Cities in Zhejiang, one of China’s most prosperous provinces, are studded with Christian churches, Protestant and Catholic alike. Until recently, many of them had been topped by large crosses soaring into the sky, often illuminated with neon lights at night.

headline: A New Look at Works Banned by the Catholic Church
abstract: Inspired by the collection at Rome’s Angelica Library, the artist Ileana Florescu submerged books underwater to explore the concept of destruction as it relates to the censorship and preservation of ideas.
lead_paragraph: Rome’s prodigious Angelica Library, founded in 1604 by the Augustinian bishop Angelo Rocca, is endowed with some 200,000 volumes and manuscripts on the history of Catholicism, with particular emphasis on the Reformation and Counter-Reformation of the Church. Enshrined amongst the library’s texts is a precious collection of first editions of books that, over the course of the centuries, were officially banned by the Catholic Church and placed in its Index Librorum Prohibitorum. These volumes include works by Machiavelli, Copernicus and Erasmus, as well as Voltaire’s “Candide” and Jonathan Swift’s “A Tale of a Tub.” The collection, which includes the very first Index of banned books compiled by the Church in 1559, is what inspired the artist Ileana Florescu’s new show, “Libri Prohibiti,” which opens at Angelica Library next week.

headline: Politics Are Set Aside as Thousands Mourn Officer Brian Moore
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Nearly a week after he was shot and killed while on patrol in Queens, Officer Moore was laid to rest on Friday surrounded by a sea of blue.
lead_paragraph: SEAFORD, N.Y. — This time, politics was not on display at a funeral for a fallen New York City police officer. No officers turned their backs to Mayor Bill de Blasio and no one voiced support for protests that have riven communities from Ferguson, Mo., to Baltimore.

headline: Prime Minister Cameron’s Victory Speech
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said he would bring the country together and “govern as a party of one nation, one United Kingdom,” in his victory speech on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said he would bring the country together and “govern as a party of one nation, one United Kingdom,” in his victory speech on Friday.

headline: Britain’s Labour Leader Miliband Resigns
abstract: Ed Miliband, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, offered his resignation on Friday a day after Thursday’s general election.
lead_paragraph: Ed Miliband, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, offered his resignation on Friday a day after Thursday’s general election.

headline: The Benefits and Caveats in Physical Challenges for Charity
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: The benefits these events produce in awareness and demonstrated interest in a cause may be more important than the money they raise.
lead_paragraph: SEAN MALONEY had an ambitious plan: to be the first stroke survivor to bicycle from San Francisco to New York via a circuitous route that would take him down the West Coast and across Texas. It would be over 5,000 miles.

headline: Top Economist Sees Clinton Money Machine as Problematic
abstract: Prof. Jeffrey D. Sachs, a leading economist, said that members of the international philanthropy community have been concerned about the Clinton Foundation’s practices for years.
lead_paragraph: Questions surrounding foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation are beginning to fester beyond the usual conservative critics who hope to derail the presidential hopes of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: How to Use Siri, Google Now and Cortana Voice Commands
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Voice Recognition Systems', 'Android (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Windows (Operating System)']
abstract: Get the most out of speech-recognition mobile assistants. Also, how to use speed-test websites to measure broadband speeds.
lead_paragraph: Q. I ask the Google app on my phone only about the daily weather forecast, but how does it compare to the Siri program for the verbal instructions it understands?

headline: Shirley Jackson’s ‘Life Among the Savages’ and ‘Raising Demons’ Reissued
abstract: Two reissued memoirs showcase Shirley Jackson’s lighter side.
lead_paragraph: When “Life Among the Savages,” a collection of warm and funny magazine pieces chronicling the ups and downs of Shirley Jackson’s household, was first published in 1953, Jackson was already a well-known writer — of a rather different kind. She had made headlines five years earlier with “The Lottery,” which attracted attention not only for its shocking content, but also for the vehemence of the response it provoked. Many were unsure whether this tale of ritual stoning in an American village was fact or fiction; some railed at The New Yorker for printing such barbarism; others just wanted to know what on earth it meant. Jackson, who had already published the novel “The Road Through the Wall” (1948), about murder and suicide in a small California town, sealed her macabre reputation with her next two books: “The Lottery” (1949), a collection of often suspenseful short stories, and “Hangsaman” (1951), a coming-of-age novel about a college student who suffers a mental breakdown.

headline: Concern for Business Leaders as Cameron’s Win Edges Britain Closer to E.U. Exit
abstract: With Mr. Cameron having promised a referendum on Britain’s membership, the prospect of degrading access to European markets is a worry.
lead_paragraph: David Cameron’s re-election as Britain’s prime minister increases the risk that the country will quit the European Union in the next few years. Although this is still not a probability, the possibility will concern business, as an exit would degrade Britain’s access to by far its largest market.

headline: When Mother Leaves the Room
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: What took us so long to make the mother’s point of view a natural one in fiction?
lead_paragraph: Every year on Mother’s Day the lists appear: Bad Mothers in Fiction, Monstrous Mothers in Literature, 10 Worst Mothers in Books We Love. There are a few Most Wonderful lists, but these mothers are not from books generally recognized as great or enduring works. The two most famous are Caroline Ingalls in “Little House on the Prairie” and Marmee in “Little Women” — it’s a bonnet thing perhaps, though a good straw poke does not save Mrs. Bennet in “Pride and Prejudice” from the charge of foolishness. This makes you a bad mother too, apparently. Perhaps there should be an exam. Who could pass it? To be ordinary in any way — weak, fallible, occasionally drunk or desiring, all of these make you a liability to your fictional children’s fictional well- being. Thank goodness reality is not like that.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Use Polarizing? Site Begs to Differ
abstract: Almost 29 percent of the news stories displayed by Facebook’s News Feed present views that conflict with the user’s own ideology, the study found.
lead_paragraph: For years, political scientists and social theorists have fretted about the Internet’s potential to flatten and polarize democratic discourse, Farhad Manjoo writes.

headline: Embracing Squid in Its Many Forms
abstract: Fried calamari is an obvious choice, but there are numerous other options, including eating them whole and stuffed.
lead_paragraph: It’s funny that people who are normally squeamish about eating oddball food have no problem with squid.

headline: Tax Documents: What to Shred, and What to Keep
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Archives and Records', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Storage', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Tax returns and divorce decrees may be useful to keep for a lifetime, but many financial documents can be stored on a flash drive, or even destroyed.
lead_paragraph: THE income tax filing deadline is, thankfully, receding on the calendar. And while most people would prefer to move on to other, more pleasant activities, now is a good time to consider how you save your tax returns and other financial documents.

headline: To Cameron, the Tory Victor, Now Go the Headaches
abstract: The Conservatives have such a narrow majority that Prime Minister David Cameron will have to tread carefully over thorny issues that could redefine 21st-century Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron, having achieved a smashing and unexpected outright victory in Britain’s general election, heads into his second term facing severe challenges to his nation’s identity and place in the world: how to keep the United Kingdom in the European Union and Scotland in the United Kingdom.

headline: 1915: Roosevelt Remarks on Lusitania
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Roosevelt’s comments on the Lusitania in 1915.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The Herald obtained an interview with Colonel Roosevelt in the Court Room in Syracuse, where he was attending the trial of the libel suit brought against him by Mr. William Barnes, whom he lately called a ‘‘boss.’’

headline: ESPN Is Splitting With Bill Simmons, Who Offers an Uncharacteristic Word Count: Zero
abstract: John Skipper, ESPN’s president, said the company would not renew its contract with Simmons, an outspoken personality who said nothing publicly on Friday about the move.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Simmons learned on Friday morning that his nearly 15-year-old relationship with ESPN was over, he responded with something uncharacteristic: silence.

headline: The Mysterious Persistence of the Cronut
abstract: Two years after the pastry’s moment seemed to have come and gone, people are still lining up for it.
lead_paragraph: The line begins about a third of a block into Spring Street and still regularly wraps around the corner up Thompson Street. One morning last week, on the second-to-last day of the month of Strawberry Rhubarb and Thyme — otherwise known as April; the flavor changes every month — a man named Thao stood at the front of the neatly assembled crowd. He was visiting from Vietnam, and had arrived at 5:30 that morning. At 7:36 a.m. there were 35 people lined up, including a baby in a stroller. The line was nearly half a block long. In the middle of the procession stood an older, serious-looking man named Greg Ingram, who was in town on business from Atlanta. “If people are still lining up, there must be something about it,” Ingram said. But also: “What else are you going to do at 7 in the morning?”

headline: 1940: Confidence Vote in Britain
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Chamberlain wins a confidence vote in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Chamberlain government obtained such a narrow vote of confidence late tonight [May 8] at the end of a two-day debate on the Norwegian debacle that it was believed in some political quarters that the Prime Minister might go soon to King George VI and offer to step down. The vote on the division was 281 for the government, 200 against it. One hundred and thirty-two members abstained.

headline: Baltimore Case Is Full of Conflicts, Lawyers for Officers Contend
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The lawyers sought the dismissal of charges in the death of Freddie Gray and accused the prosecutor who brought them of betraying professional standards..
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Lawyers for the six Baltimore police officers charged in connection with the death of Freddie Gray unleashed a personal and professional broadside on Friday against the prosecutor who brought the charges, accusing her and her office of being riven by conflicts of interest and alleging that she had betrayed professional standards.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Golf, Memory and Food Cravings
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Stuff We Liked
abstract: Coyotes, problems with the Port Authority and a continuing debate over whether Facebook polarizes political debate.
lead_paragraph: We like it, of course, when an Upshot feature gets lots of attention — and our analysis and visualization of a new study on the importance of where a child grows up certainly did. We also liked how Emily Badger over at Wonkblog took the same study and applied her own analysis to the case of Baltimore for a very readable article.

headline: With Berlin Philharmonic Vote Looming, Mariss Jansons Stays On in Munich
abstract: Mariss Jansons, who had been thought to be a possible candidate for the post of chief conductor and artistic director at the Berlin Philharmonic, announced Friday that he had agreed to remain as chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra until 2021.
lead_paragraph: The invisible primary being waged before the players of the Berlin Philharmonic meet Monday to elect their new chief conductor and artistic director continues apace: Mariss Jansons, who had been thought to be a possible candidate, announced Friday that he had agreed to remain as chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra until 2021.

headline: Patrick Lynch, Police Union Leader, Faces Election Fight
abstract: The combative qualities that have long defined Patrick Lynch’s leadership of the New York Policemen’s Benevolent Association may now be liabilities.
lead_paragraph: In early January, mutiny broke out within the upper ranks of the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association, the city’s largest police union. At a monthly meeting, at a catering hall in Queens, a cabal of senior delegates confronted the union’s president, Patrick J. Lynch, with a defiant declaration: It was time to end his distracting battle with Mayor Bill de Blasio and refocus his attention on his members.

headline: Aftermath of Pakistan Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Helicopters', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']

lead_paragraph: Video shows the aftermath of a helicopter crash in Pakistan on Friday that killed foreign dignitaries, with initial reports suggesting it crashed into a school while attempting to land.

headline: Watching Maya Plisetskaya
abstract: Ms. Plisetskaya, who died on Saturday, was the epitome of the Bolshoi’s larger-than-life tradition. These clips give a sense of her dancing.
lead_paragraph: The great Bolshoi ballerina Maya Plisetskaya died on Saturday at 89. I saw her only once, in 1988, at a gala in her honor in Boston; an announcer proclaimed the priceless words: “And now Maya Plisetskaya will dance her immortal Dying Swan” — which she validated by dancing it twice. And that’s what many people remember her for, the number of times her Swan would dance and die. (One colleague remembers her dancing it six times in a row.)

headline: Idina Menzel to Tour in ‘If/Then’
abstract: Idina Menzel will begin a tour of “If/Then” in Denver in October.
lead_paragraph: Idina Menzel is hitting the road.

headline: ‘Adult Onset,’ by Ann-Marie MacDonald
abstract: Parenting pressures and traumatic memories push Ann-Marie MacDonald’s heroine to the brink.
lead_paragraph: Do our more modest northern neighbors talk about the Great Canadian Novel? After all, they have big geography there too — the mountains, the prairies. “Always in view was the vastness of what in most countries would be called a sea but in Canada was known simply as ‘one of the Great Lakes,’ ” the Canadian writer Ann-Marie MacDonald writes in her big, troubling and brave new novel. Books like hers have a continental sweep: The writer amply stocks them with people and ideas, with all she knows. Spare, quiet perfection isn’t the aim.

headline: On the Job
abstract: New books by Chen Guangcheng, Nina MacLaughlin, Heather Lende and Steve Osborne.
lead_paragraph: THE BAREFOOT LAWYER

headline: ‘The Lost Child,’ by Caryl Phillips
abstract: Caryl Phillips’s characters are separated from their families.
lead_paragraph: At age 57, Caryl Phillips is seen by many as the father of Afro-British fiction. Phillips was born on the island of St. Kitts in 1958, but as an infant he left with his parents during the mass migration of people from the Caribbean islands — still colonial subjects ­­— to Britain in the 1950s. Immigration has been a key topic in Phillips’s work from his very first novel, “The Final Passage” (1985). His first two novels were fairly straightforward in style and structure, but with his third, “Higher Ground” (1989), Phillips introduced the more ambitious and unconventional approach he has used ever since. Rather than tell one linear story, these later novels bring together several independent narratives set at different places on the globe and at different moments in time. The stories are linked by theme and situation as opposed to setting and plot.

headline: ‘Where Women Are Kings,’ by Christie Watson
abstract: A boy is removed from his unstable mother’s care.
lead_paragraph: Not all children love magic. Seven-year-old Elijah, the central character in Christie Watson’s second novel, has a scar on his forehead and more on his body. And he is convinced he has a wizard inside him. This isn’t fun, and the magical power it involves is a pernicious, festering force, endangering everyone around him. Or so Elijah believes.

headline: ‘Smart Money,’ by Andrew Palmer
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Innovation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Social Impact Bonds']
abstract: A journalist examines financial instruments that seek to do good.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, The Economist published a 14-page special report on financial innovation entitled “Playing With Fire.” It opened with the line “Financial innovation has a dreadful image these days.” The goal: rehabilitate that image.

headline: ‘Romantic Outlaws,’ About the Lives of Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley
abstract: A dual biography of the 18th-century English feminist Mary Wollstonecraft and the daughter she never knew.
lead_paragraph: They had it all. When they eloped, 16-year-old Mary Godwin and 21-year-old Percy Shelley had everything artists could desire: genius, beauty, literary pedigree, aristocratic inheritance, Mediterranean villas, famous friends, fearless admirers, freedom and — above all — faith in free love.

headline: ‘Firstborn,’ by Tor Seidler
abstract: In Tor Seidler’s tale of self-acceptance and survival, a young wolf born into a rigid hierarchy seeks the courage to be himself.
lead_paragraph: “The glint of wolves’ eyes in the night is a chilling sight. If I’d been wingless, I would have been terrified.” That’s Maggie, the lively magpie who narrates Tor Seidler’s artful and affecting new novel, “Firstborn.” As it turns out, those eyes belong to wolves who, improbably, become her family. Together, led by the fearless Blue Boy, wolves and bird journey to the remote Lamar Valley in Yellowstone National Park where, they hear, an abundance of food awaits them. In the valley — where gray wolves were reintroduced 20 years ago, nearly a century after hunters drastically reduced their numbers — they will birth pups, raise and lose progeny, challenge other wolf packs and re-­examine their loyalties to themselves and one another.

headline: ‘Hermit of the Jungle’ Guards a Brazilian Ghost City Rich in History
abstract: Shigeru Nakayama looks after Airão Velho, once the site of an Amazon rain forest rubber boom, which now lies in ruins.
lead_paragraph: AIRÃO VELHO, Brazil — SHIGERU NAKAYAMA, the guardian of this ghost city in the Amazon rain forest, gazes at the Rio Negro, a vast blackwater tributary. From some angles, it looks less like a river than a sea, spurring him to remember Japan.

headline: Sara Pennypacker’s ‘Meet the Dullards,’ and More
abstract: In four new picture books, a dog, a skunk, an elephant and an extremely dull family subvert readerly suppositions.
lead_paragraph: Despite the efforts of story-time subversives as varied as Jo March, Tom Sawyer, the Mad Hatter, Madeline, Eloise, Ramona Quimby, the Cat in the Hat, Willy Wonka and the Stinky Cheese Man, ­namby-pambyism has for generations been a scourge of children’s literature. The impulse to force-feed kids the bookish equivalent of steamed spinach is unlikely ever to fade, though our notions about what that should be continue to evolve. But in recent years an opposing virus has also infected the nursery library. You might call it peepee-poo-ism: the anxious, overeager impulse to engage children on what we adults think of as their own terms, lest they believe us uncool — or worse, and more to the point, old.

headline: ‘I Will Always Write Back: How One Letter Changed Two Lives’
abstract: A correspondence between an American girl and a boy from Zimbabwe transforms them both in this young adult memoir.
lead_paragraph: In a suburban Pennsylvania classroom in 1997, a life-altering moment: Caitlin Alifirenka, “a typical 12-year-old American girl,” more interested in what she “should wear to school” than what she “might learn there,” chooses a pen pal from Zimbabwe. Caitlin has never heard of Zimbabwe, but the name, “exotic, and difficult to pronounce,” intrigues her.

headline: ‘Ben Draws Trouble,’ ‘How to Draw a Dragon’ and ‘My Pen’
abstract: Three books celebrate the pleasures of drawing — bicycles, boats, classmates, dragons: pretty much anything.
lead_paragraph: The trouble with drawing is that it’s fun. Almost too much fun. Drawing can become uncontrollable, a force you can barely handle. Children know this and give in; adults knew it once, but forget. For children a notebook for math class can easily transform into a sketchbook for art. Lines, shapes and colors become little masterpieces at the margins of the page. How can one stop? Why should one stop? There’s seemingly no choice in the matter. The drawing has to come out.

headline: ‘Black Dove White Raven,’ by Elizabeth Wein
abstract: Faced with discrimination, a pilot and her children move to Ethiopia on the eve of Mussolini’s invasion.
lead_paragraph: Historical fiction, especially historical fiction for young adults, presents many challenges for a writer, not least of them this one: While history is decidedly political, novels are decidedly not political treatises. To ignore the politics of history is naïve — and what novelist wants to be that? On the other hand, objectivity is an undesirable trait in a literary work. Point of view is very serious business.

headline: ‘Lost in the Sun,’ by Lisa Graff
abstract: In this middle-grade novel, a boy must break free from a cycle of guilt and recrimination after an accidental death.
lead_paragraph: The title of this simple yet soulful novel refers to a fly ball that drifts over the head of a Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder, leaving the book’s sixth-grade narrator (and obsessive Dodger fan), Trent Zimmerman, in a confused rage. “He had it,” Trent whines. “If he’d just shifted even a little, he would’ve caught it easy.”

headline: Gordon Korman’s ‘Masterminds,’ and More
abstract: Four new series of speculative fiction, filled with perilous journeys, long-held secrets and bands of tenacious children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: What happens during summer vacation has a lot to teach us about children and reading. Librarians and teachers are very aware of the “summer slide.” This friendly-sounding phrase describes the loss of reading skills during the long break. After two months of not reading, a student experiences a gap in learning that, by the time she reaches middle school, might add up to a two-year lag in skills. We also know that children who choose reading as a leisure activity will do well on those dreaded tests of comprehension, vocabulary and reading speed.

headline: ‘Bone Gap,’ by Laura Ruby
abstract: The myth of Demeter and Persephone colors a young adult novel of abduction and captivity in small-town America.
lead_paragraph: The goddess Demeter had a daughter, Persephone, who was abducted by Hades, the lord of the underworld. In her daughter’s absence, Demeter let the world go barren out of sorrow and anger. Anyone who had a dog-eared copy of the D’Aulaires’ illustrated “Book of Greek Myths” has a handle on Persephone.

headline: ‘Listen, Slowly,’ by Thanhha Lai
abstract: A trip to Vietnam brings a girl in touch with her family history in this middle-grade novel.
lead_paragraph: Literature in English for children and young adults offers few books about Vietnam and even fewer about the Vietnam War. Walter Dean Myers’s 1988 novel “Fallen Angels” explored the costs borne by American soldiers sent to Vietnam with little knowledge about where they were and less about why they were there. The book deglorified war, exposing the sharp irony of sending young men, not yet old enough to vote and often marginalized by race or socioeconomic status, to defend ideals of democracy. They fought a war filled with “hours of boredom, seconds of terror”; if they came home again, it was not as angel warriors, but as fallen angels.

headline: ‘Ms. Rapscott’s Girls’ and ‘The Girl With the Glass Bird’
abstract: Children learn much more than the three R’s at the unconventional institutions in these novels.
lead_paragraph: Who can resist a good boarding school novel? The literary tradition dates back as far as the mid-19th-century “Tom Brown’s School Days,” by Thomas Hughes, and Frances Hodgson Burnett’s 1905 classic, “A Little Princess.” These beloved stories shunt the parents aside without (necessarily) killing them off, leaving children to discover their own mettle. Two new boarding school tales for middle-grade readers offer fresh approaches — one whimsical and magical with a dose of gentle social satire, the other a whodunit of sorts, with a taste of international intrigue.

headline: ‘An Ember in the Ashes,’ by Sabaa Tahir
abstract: When a cruel regime imprisons her brother, a young woman goes undercover in a bid to free him.
lead_paragraph: “An Ember in the Ashes” presents a ­vicious empire that has subjugated several cultures, including the once learned Scholars. “Usually, the Empire raids in the heat of the day,” we are told. “The soldiers want Scholar mothers and children to watch. They want fathers and brothers to see another man’s family enslaved.” One Scholar, Laia, is so desperate to free her imprisoned brother that she becomes a slave and a spy at Blackcliff, an imperial academy where young men (and one other young woman, Helene) train to ­become the ­Empire’s soldiers. We also meet Elias, the son of the school’s commander. Appalled by the Empire’s rule, he wants to run away, but the announcement of a competition changes his plans. If Elias wins, he will become emperor. And only if he competes, the imperial ­magicians tell him, will he attain a true moral freedom.

headline: 15 European Opera Houses to Offer Free Online Streaming
abstract: The operas — including works from the Vienna State Opera and the Royal Opera House — will be available live and on-demand for six months.
lead_paragraph: A free showing of Verdi’s “La Traviata” will be streamed live from Madrid’s Teatro Real on Friday, inaugurating a new program backed by the European Union in which some of Europe’s top houses will stream performances free to make opera more accessible.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jane Smiley, whose novel “Early Warning” is No. 10 on the hardcover fiction list, said of the creative life: “What we do as writers is voluntary, so don’t complain.”
lead_paragraph: Smiley’s People: Jane Smiley’s new novel, “Early Warning” — it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 10 — is the middle volume of a trilogy that started last year with “Some Luck,” covering a century in the life of an Iowa family at the rate of a chapter per year. This installment takes the characters from 1953 through 1986, introducing a new generation and letting them contend with milestones like the Vietnam War, Jim Jones’s seductive Peoples Temple and the early days of the AIDS crisis. In some hands the conceit could have felt gimmicky or forced, a kissing cousin to “Forrest Gump” or Billy Joel’s “We Didn’t Start the Fire.” But reviewers so far have been largely impressed, comparing Smiley to the giants of 19th-century literature. (“America’s Tolstoy,” ruled Christobel Kent in The Guardian.) Smiley also keeps an eye on her forebears, if more humbly. “Trollope would sneer,” she told one interviewer last year, after announcing she was about done with the trilogy’s 1,300 pages. In the same profile, she remembered with approval the motivational note — “Nobody asked you to write this novel” — that a former classmate kept taped to her typewriter. “What we do as writers is voluntary, so don’t complain,” Smiley said, recalling how inspired she was by an exhibit of hand-­corrected page proofs at the Balzac museum in Paris. “It’s good to see what it meant to be a popular author in the middle of the 19th century,” she said. “When you see how hard Balzac worked, you’ll never complain again.”

headline: Missouri Lawmakers Limit Revenue From Traffic Fines in St. Louis Area
keywords: ['Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Local Government', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The bill seeks to address complaints of excessive ticketing raised by black residents after the death of Michael Brown in Ferguson last year.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Missouri legislators have agreed to a proposal that would sharply limit revenue from traffic fines in municipalities across St. Louis County, where heavy fines and ticketing helped inflame unrest after the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer here last year.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Middle-East Role Model: His Brother?
keywords: ['Elections', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Who I listen to when I need advice on the Middle East is George W. Bush,” said the former Florida governor on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: There’s a bit of controversy today about a remark that Jeb Bush, Republican presidential contender, made about his brother, former President George W. Bush, at a meeting on Tuesday in Manhattan.

headline: Bookshelf: This Is How We Roll
abstract: New picture books include “The Bus Is for Us!” and “The Red Bicycle.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “The Bus Is for Us!” and “The Red Bicycle.”

lead_paragraph: THERE IS SIMPLY TOO MUCH TO THINK ABOUT: Collected Nonfiction, by Saul Bellow. Edited by Benjamin Taylor. (Viking, $35.) The nonfiction shows the same strengths as the novels: a dynamic responsiveness to character, place and time.

headline: Scottish Nationalists Rejoice in Big British Election Win
abstract: The bid for Scottish independence from Britain may have failed last year, but it set in motion forces that ended Labour Party dominance in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: PAISLEY, Scotland — When the results were in last September and the Scottish National Party  lost its bid for Scotland’s independence, a spirited young separatist, Mhairi Black, walked past local officials of the Labour Party who were clapping sarcastically and goading her. “Better luck next time,” they said.

headline: Highlights at This Weekend’s Echo Park Craft Fair
abstract: The biannual event showcases L.A.’s thriving scene of independent designers and artisans.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, stylish and creatively inclined Angelenos will flock by the thousands to the Echo Park Craft Fair. The biannual event is a showcase for L.A.’s thriving scene of independent designers and artisans, and for a certain type of Los Angeles aesthetic that fuses the handmade and earthy with sophisticated modern design. (We imagine there will be some overlap with last weekend’s Mercado Sagrado fair.) Visitors can shop for Modernist-inspired ceramics (Mt. Washington Pottery; BZippy & Co.), unusual cacti (The Cactus Store), jewelry and objets such as rocks from the L.A. River wrapped in strands of leather (Matthew Ready), ideal for decorating their (real or imagined) Craftsman bungalows.

headline: In Alex Rodriguez’s Big Moments, Yankees Start to Look Small
abstract: Something was missing when Rodriguez passed Willie Mays on the career home run list: the heartfelt joy when player and organization are of one accord.
lead_paragraph: I live in what I call the New York Yankees historical baseball district.

headline: On England’s Coast, Thomas Hardy Made His World
abstract: Dorset, the countryside the author called Wessex, was “another character” in his novels, and pilgrimages to the area began even during his lifetime.
lead_paragraph: It was in Lulwind Cove, an inlet on England’s south coast, that the dastardly Sergeant Troy took an impromptu swim in “Far From the Madding Crowd,” Thomas Hardy’s 1874 novel about an uncommonly independent Victorian woman and her suitors. The water in the cove was “smooth as a pond,” Hardy wrote, until Troy “swam between the two projecting spurs of rock which formed the pillars of Hercules to this miniature Mediterranean,” whereupon he was swept out to sea and presumed drowned, only to make a dramatic reappearance — this being a Hardy novel — at a most inconvenient moment.

headline: National Sawdust, a New Concert Hall, to Open in Williamsburg in October
abstract: The new venue is envisioned as a concert hall, nightclub and recording studio and musical hangout.
lead_paragraph: The transformation of a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into a new music center is nearly complete: organizers said Friday that the hall, National Sawdust, would open this fall and host three concerts in the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! series.

headline: China and Russia Honor WWII Relations
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday, a day before the 70th anniversary celebration of Victory Day in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping of China met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday, a day before the 70th anniversary celebration of Victory Day in Moscow.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ON THE RUN: Fugitive Life in an American City, by Alice Goffman. (Picador, $16.) This is a closely observed study of the criminal justice system’s impact on life in a poor black Philadelphia neighborhood. Goffman, a sociologist, spent six years in a community she calls 6th Street, documenting the routine police stops, raids and beatings that young men navigate. “The level of detail in this book and Goffman’s ability to understand her subjects’ motivations are astonishing,” Alex Kotlowitz wrote here.

abstract: This week, Tom Perrotta discusses Kate Atkinson’s “A God in Ruins”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ruth Franklin talks about Shirley Jackson; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: ‘Sounds Like Music: The Films of Martín Rejtman’ at Lincoln Center
abstract: The retrospective looks at the works of the Argentine filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: “Sounds Like Music: The Films of Martín Rejtman,” a retrospective of work by the Argentine filmmaker at Lincoln Center, Wednesday through May 19, will culminate with a weeklong run of his newest film, “Two Shots Fired,” a comedy about a 16-year-old boy, Mariano, who survives self-inflicted gunshot wounds to his stomach and head. Although he suffers from auditory disturbances, he is otherwise barely injured. From the seemingly unmotivated suicide attempt, the absurdist movie radiates outward to observe the foibles of family members and friends, who like Mariano, act on impulse.

headline: Yve Laris Cohen at the Kitchen
abstract: The choreographer will again look to architecture to inspire a new dance work.
lead_paragraph: In the work of Yve Laris Cohen, choreography often takes the form of construction: walls and floors being built, transported, taken apart. Traversing the worlds of dance and visual art, Mr. Laris Cohen is interested in their architectural spaces, the nature of black boxes and white cubes. Recently at St. Mark’s Church, he assembled and disassembled, over several nights, a portable stage belonging to New York City Ballet.

headline: Carnegie Hall Has Big Week Planned
abstract: The Philadelphia Orchestra, the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe and Evgeny Kissin will perform at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Lovers of great orchestras, opera singers and pianists may want to claim a seat at Carnegie Hall for three consecutive nights this week. On Thursday, Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the superb young music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, brings that storied ensemble to the hall for Nico Muhly’s “Mixed Messages,” Beethoven’s Third Piano Concerto (with the eminent Emanuel Ax as soloist) and Rachmaninoff’s rhapsodic Third Symphony. (8 p.m., Thursday, 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Isabella Boylston on Treasuring ‘Giselle’ and Trusting Herself
abstract: Ms. Boylston has an intensely busy spring season with American Ballet Theater, which begins on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, though one role stands out above them all.
lead_paragraph: Some years are so full of happy transformation that they seem conjured from a fortuneteller’s hopeful reading. In 2014, the ballerina Isabella Boylston had one of those years. She danced her first Giselle, magnificently, with American Ballet Theater and was promoted to principal soon after. She got married. “He’s not a dancer,” Ms. Boylston said, flashing a smile. “He works in finance.” And she performed as a guest artist at the Mariinsky Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet. “You show up, and they’re expecting you to be this prima ballerina,” she said. “So you just have to fill the shoes.”

headline: Pop Music Catches Up to Shamir
abstract: The singer Shamir brings his distinctive androgynous voice to his debut solo album, “Ratchet” (XL), which combines early 1980s electro-pop, classic house, post-punk and R&B.
lead_paragraph: NORTH LAS VEGAS, NEV. — On the small patio at the far-from-it-all apartment here that the singer Shamir shares with two friends, an ashtray sat on a small table, though you could barely see it underneath the lava flow of cigarette butts erupting out of it. He was perched on a high chair, puffing his way through a Maverick, lamenting the disarray, and also passing the buck.

headline: Monitoring the Metropolitan Opera’s Vital Signs
abstract: Taking the Met’s artistic temperature by attending all 26 operas it presented, at least once each and often more.
lead_paragraph: In news reports over the past year, the Metropolitan Opera has come across as an ailing patient, its costs and revenues spiraling in opposite directions. While many observers agree that the company’s financial model is unsustainable, at least in the long term, there’s far more disagreement about the quality of its performances. At the beginning of the 2014-15 season, which ends on Saturday, I resolved to take the Met’s artistic temperature by attending, as I never had before, all of the operas it presented — 26 this year — at least once each and often more. I tried to catch notable newcomers and cast changes, to move beyond the premieres and big stars to see how things are faring on those ordinary nights that are an opera house’s lifeblood.

headline: Freddie Highmore on ‘Bates Motel’
abstract: As the third season of the show ends, a young Norman Bates transforms into his mother.
lead_paragraph: Season 3 of A&E’s “Bates Motel,” which has its finale Monday night at 9, has been transformative for young Norman Bates. And not just figuratively.

headline: Race and Gender in Black and White
abstract: Her work displays candid studies in style and attitude, and it documents a double apartheid involving race and gender
lead_paragraph: The South African photographer Zanele Muholi, born in Durban in 1972, specializes in portraiture of a particular kind: Almost all of her subjects are members of South Africa’s lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex communities. Early on, combining political activism and art, she began in 2002 documenting hate crimes against gays. In 2007, she initiated the portrait series, which is ongoing and forms the centerpiece of “Zanele Muholi: Isibonelo/Evidence” at the Brooklyn Museum, her largest solo show in the United States.

abstract: Other new releases include those by Ryan Truesdell’s Gil Evans Project and the Cuban percussionist Dafnis Prieto.
lead_paragraph: Della Mae

headline: The Economy and the British Election
abstract: Recent growth does it again.
lead_paragraph: Just a reminder: The overwhelming evidence for US elections is that they are not judgements of an administration’s overall performance — they are driven by the rate of growth just ahead of the election, as in the chart above (taken from Larry Bartels.) (Any pointers to UK-specific work along the same lines would be welcome.) I’ve also put in the closest growth number I could get to the one Bartels uses for the US, taken from the ONS.

headline: The Curious Case of Negative Interest Rates
abstract: Powerful forces are affecting the overall global economy, as the world is awash in a glut of labor, goods and energy with little economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Scaramucci is founder and co-managing partner of global investment firm SkyBridge Capital and host of the television program “Wall Street Week.”

headline: B.B. King, in Hospice Care at Home, Is Focus of Court Battle
abstract: B.B. King, 89 and ailing, will remain under the guardianship of his longtime manager.
lead_paragraph: B.B. King, the esteemed bluesman, who at 89 is currently in hospice care at his home in Las Vegas, will for now remain under the guardianship of his longtime manager, Laverne Toney, despite claims of abuse by three of Mr. King’s children, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Stop-Go Austerity and Self-Defeating Recoveries
abstract: Seizing the chance to make the same mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes good things happen to bad ideas. Actually, it happens all the time. Britain’s election results came as a surprise, but they were consistent with the general proposition that elections hinge not on an incumbent’s overall record but on whether things are improving in the six months or so before the vote. Cameron and company imposed austerity for a couple of years, then paused, and the economy picked up enough during the lull to give them a chance to make the same mistakes all over again.

headline: In Paris, Craft Cocktails Sidle Up to the Bar
abstract: The French capital was slow to join the modern cocktail revival, but now many bars are blooming, with French products finding their way onto cocktail menus.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On the menu at Mabel, a rum-focused bar in the Second Arrondissement, is a section titled “Mabel’s Recommendations.” It lists the names and addresses of nearly 30 other cocktail bars in Paris.

headline: How Labour Gained Votes but Still Lost Seats
abstract: This week’s British election was a disaster for the Labour Party, even though it got a bigger share of the vote than last time around.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s election in Britain was great for the Conservatives and terrible for Labour — so terrible that Labour’s leader, Ed Miliband, is stepping down. Yet Mr. Miliband has something to brag about: Not only did Labour take a larger share of the vote this week than it did in 2010, but it also improved its vote share by substantially more than the victorious Conservatives did.

headline: Queen Latifah Stars in ‘Bessie’ on HBO
abstract: The biopic of the blues singer Bessie Smith was written and directed by Dee Rees.
lead_paragraph: Within the first 10 minutes of “Bessie,” HBO’s new biopic of Bessie Smith, we see the blues legend sing, cry, dance, cut a man and kiss, lustily, both men and women. The drinking comes later, but not much. At a party at the home of Carl Van Vechten, the Harlem Renaissance patron and gadfly, a soused Bessie, played by Queen Latifah, belts the anthem “Work House Blues,” to an audience including Langston Hughes, then throws a drink in the host’s face when he uses a racial epithet.

headline: Chinese Debate the Meaning of Alan Mak’s Election to the British Parliament
abstract: For the first time ever, an ethnic Chinese has been elected to the British House of Commons.
lead_paragraph: For the first time ever, an ethnic Chinese has been elected to the British Parliament. But the new Conservative Party member for Havant, in southern England, has downplayed that aspect of his victory in Thursday’s general election.

headline: A Rebound in Hiring
abstract: Employers in the United States added 223,000 jobs in April. Sectors like construction and health care did well, while the oil and gas category fared poorly.
lead_paragraph: Employers in the United States added 223,000 jobs in April. Sectors like construction and health care did well, while the oil and gas category fared poorly.

headline: On the French Riviera, Fitzgerald Found His Place in the Sun
abstract: In Antibes, vestiges of the moneyed elite who once captivated the American writer live on.
lead_paragraph: Unless you happen to be on a billionaire’s yacht requiring a deepwater port or are a paparazzo stalking Leonardo DiCaprio along the Riviera, you might have no reason to find yourself near Antibes or its charming little sister village, Juan-les-Pins, on a summer evening. And that would be unfortunate, because among the legendary diversions of Cap d’Antibes is exploring the rocky playground peninsula on the French Riviera that inspired one of America’s greatest writers.

headline: New York Archdiocese Will Close 7 More Churches
abstract: The closings — three in the Bronx, one in Manhattan and three north of the city — are part of the biggest reorganization in archdiocese history.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced on Friday the shuttering of seven more churches as part of the biggest reorganization in its history, a process of parish consolidations that will leave the archdiocese 20 percent smaller than it was last year.

keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Budgets and Budgeting']

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Illinois Supreme Court on Friday rejected changes that legislators made to fix a deeply troubled public pension system, leaving the state where it had started — with a significant budget crisis, a vastly underfunded pension program and no plan in sight.

headline: Nine Rooms in the San Remo for $20.75 Million
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: An apartment that was owned by the hedge fund pioneer and philanthropist Robert W. Wilson was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A nine-room apartment on the 16th floor of the venerable San Remo that was owned for more than three decades by Robert W. Wilson, a hedge fund pioneer and philanthropist, sold for $20,750,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: The Classic, Trendy and Elevated Sides of a White Port and Tonic
abstract: From Portugal to L.A., the cocktail is having a moment.
lead_paragraph: Rising in popularity along with aperitifs like vermouth and sherry is white port — the drier, bittersweet cousin of red. Mixed with tonic, it makes for an unexpectedly bracing yet refreshing spring cocktail that’s lower in proof than a classic gin and tonic, but with more kick than a wine spritzer.

headline: Ben Carson Bucks G.O.P. and Backs Raising Minimum Wage
abstract: Ben Carson takes a stand against Republican orthodoxy by saying in an interview that the minimum wage should “probably” be raised.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson has adopted many positions that align closely with conservative orthodoxy, supporting a flat tax not to exceed 15 percent and going so far as to urge the elimination of not only the Internal Revenue Service, but also Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: Investors Choose Bojangles’ Over Shake Shack
abstract: Bojangles’ enjoyed a strong market debut on Friday while shares of Shake Shack continued their retreat.
lead_paragraph: Fried chicken is in and “modern-day roadside” burgers are out — at least on Wall Street.

headline: Anticipating a Crowd, Milan’s Cathedral Undergoes a Restoration
abstract: The Duomo di Milano is among the restoration projects undertaken in the city in anticipation of Milano Expo 2015.
lead_paragraph: For Milan’s Duomo, beauty has its price. The city’s massive Gothic cathedral, on which construction began in 1386, is undergoing a restoration, and the marble that provides its celebrated luster is a particular challenge.

headline: Unless You Are Spock, Irrelevant Things Matter in Economic Behavior

lead_paragraph: Early in my teaching career I managed to get most of the students in my class mad at me. A midterm exam caused the problem.

headline: Post-Election Britain: A Disunited Kingdom
abstract: An unexpectedly decisive election masks Britain’s profound political fragmentation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the most anodyne election campaigns in living memory has left Britain with a result that few expected — and one that could transform Britain both internally and externally. This was an election that recast the political geography of Britain. It may redraw the boundaries of the nation. And it raises questions about the future shape of the European Union.

headline: The Red Bull Music Academy Festival Arrives
abstract: The first event of the program, “Yardcore: Brooklyn Bashment,” is free and features King Jammy.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bull Music Academy Festival offers three full-scale genre immersions this week: in dancehall, noise and what might be called avant-garde ambience. The first is free: on Sunday at 1 p.m. at Fort Greene Park, where “Yardcore: Brooklyn Bashment,” savors the connections between Jamaica and New York. It features King Jammy, the Jamaican producer whose collaboration with Wayne Smith on “Under Mi Sleng Teng” gave dancehall a new electronic sound. A six-hour marathon of noise — as assault, experiment, improvisation, torment and catharsis — features Merzbow, Pharmakon, Prurient and Genesis P-Orridge (performing the Psychic TV album “Electric Newspapers”) at 10 p.m. Wednesday at Output, 74 Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg. On Friday, Tri Angle Records celebrates its fifth anniversary with nine acts including Haxan Cloak, Forest Swords and Evian Christ. They’re primarily electronic musicians creating soundscapes that can be darkly immersive and push you around; 10 p.m., 23 Wall Street, redbullmusicacademy.com.

headline: Review: Joan Jonas’s Venice Biennale Pavilion Is a Triumph
abstract: Her multimedia installation is one of the best solo shows to represent the United States at Venice in over a decade.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Performance art is a young person’s sport, most often pursued in heat, often accompanied by sensationalism and abandoned as stamina fades. But, at 78, Joan Jonas has avoided all of the above, quietly but determinedly elaborating performance into an immersive multimedia art form that has sustained her for more than five decades.

headline: Hepatitis C Drugs Added to W.H.O. List of Essential Medicines
keywords: ['Hepatitis', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Sovaldi (Drug)', 'Harvoni (Drug)', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Inclusion on the list indicates to governments and drug companies that those medicines should be made available to poor countries at low prices.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization put five new hepatitis C drugs on its essential medicines list for the first time on Friday, including drugs that cost $1,000 a pill or more in wealthy countries. The new drugs are ground-breaking because they usually cure quickly with minimal side effects.

abstract: Syngenta rejected the offer as too cheap and too risky. The company has a point, but it will need to explain just how it will create more value on its own.
lead_paragraph: Monsanto is heaping pressure on Syngenta.

headline: Art Imitates Life as ‘The Audience’ Gets a New Post-Election Scene
abstract: After the election in Britain, Peter Morgan writes a new scene for “The Audience.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Conservatives have won; David Cameron has been called to see the Queen before forming a new government. That happened on Friday morning here, and was to happen again onstage Friday evening in a hot-off-the-press new scene in “The Audience,” which offers a fictional account of the meetings between Queen Elizabeth II and her prime ministers over the 63 years of her reign.

headline: In Time for Memorial Day, Atlantic City Attempts a Turnaround
abstract: Forget gaming. Atlantic City is looking to concerts to draw the crowds now that its casinos are dwindling.
lead_paragraph: Since it arrived in 1978, casino gambling has been the engine driving Atlantic City’s economy.

abstract: The fishing guides Barry and Cathy Beck will be hosts of a trip to Iceland for Frontier International Travel.
lead_paragraph: The sporting outfitter Frontiers International Travel recently introduced a website dedicated to fishing in Iceland, one of the most highly regarded wild trout and char destinations in the world.

headline: Russia and China Sign Cooperation Pacts
abstract: One agreement calls for China to invest $6 billion in a Russian intercity rail line. Another is a “nonaggression pact” in cyberspace.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On the eve of a celebration commemorating to the defeat of Nazi Germany, the presidents of Russia and China on Friday signed 32 bilateral agreements designed to highlight the warming of relations between the countries even as Russia’s have soured with the West.

headline: Strained Ties With Israel
abstract: How will Israel's new government, probably the most right-wing in its history, affect relations with the United States and American peace efforts?

lead_paragraph: Mack Butler, a state legislator from Alabama, has introduced a bill that would “allow public school teachers to help students understand, analyze, critique, and review the scientific strengths and scientific weaknesses of all existing scientific theories covered in a science course.” If you’re confused about what that might mean, Raw Story has found this helpful explanation on Mr. Butler’s Facebook page:

headline: Salman Khan, Bollywood Star, Is Allowed to Remain Free on Bail in India
abstract: A Mumbai court ruled that Mr. Khan, who was found guilty in the death of a homeless man in a hit-and-run case, is allowed to remain free until his appeal.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A Mumbai court on Friday ruled that the Bollywood actor Salman Khan would be allowed to remain free on bail until it hears his appeal of his conviction in a drunken-driving hit-and-run case.

headline: Australian Football Visits U.S. in Search of Basketball Big Men
keywords: ['Australian Football', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Football', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)', 'Basketball (College)', 'College Athletics']
abstract: The sport’s most important player is the ruckman, who is typically tall and athletic, a combination that is rare in Australia but common in American college basketball.
lead_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — Jalen Carethers, four weeks removed from his final game as a basketball player at Radford, was at a loss. Sports had always come easily to him, but now he was standing in the middle of a multipurpose field at IMG Academy, cradling an oblong ball in his hands and doing his best to figure out how to make this foreign object fly.

headline: All Aboard: The Luxe Boat
abstract: Cruising in luxury aboard the Regent Seven Seas Explorer, scheduled to launch in July 2016.
lead_paragraph: Luxurious cruise lines have been around since 1900, when the German designer Albert Ballin created Prinzessin Victoria Luise, but the newly unveiled Regent Seven Seas Explorer is gaining attention, touting itself as the most luxurious cruise ship ever. It is set to make its 14-night maiden voyage in July 2016, from Monte Carlo to Venice, the latest entrant in the busy category of high-end cruises.

headline: Saudi Arabia Announces Cease-Fire in Yemen
abstract: The Saudi foreign minister said the five-day cease-fire could be renewed, and called upon Houthi rebels to “come to their senses.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Saudi Arabia announced on Friday that it would halt its bombing campaign in Yemen for five days beginning on Tuesday, in a sign that it was bowing to international pressure to ease a worsening humanitarian crisis in a country battered by weeks of war.

headline: Democrats Relish Hillary Clinton’s Embrace of Cultural Issues
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s recent comments on immigration and same-sex marriage reflect a growing feeling among Democrats that the balance on cultural issues has shifted in their favor since her last campaign.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s call this week for more expansive action on immigration was the latest in a series of policy statements likely to appeal to her party’s liberal base. But her comments also reflect a growing feeling among Democrats that the political balance on cultural issues has shifted in their favor since her last campaign.

headline: In Venice, Plenty to See Beyond the Pavilions
abstract: The Biennale isn’t the only game in town; here, a few of T’s picks for art exhibitions to visit outside the Giardini.
lead_paragraph: The 56th Venice Biennale officially opens on Saturday, but La Serenissima has already been saturated by the international art world for almost a week — previews, parties and canal-navigating ad infinitum. One absolutely ephemeral and unintentional piece of performance art made headlines when, on Wednesday, acqua alta knocked a pontoon-load of well-heeled guests entering the Fondazione Prada into the water (or was it Miuccia’s ingenious interpretation of a trap door for gatecrashers?). Don’t fret if you missed it; there are plenty of other extra-Biennale highlights scattered throughout the city.

headline: Tempur Sealy Shareholders Vote to Remove C.E.O. and Chairman From Board
abstract: Spurred by an activist investor, shareholders of the mattress maker vote against the re-election of three directors.
lead_paragraph: Spurred by an activist investor, shareholders of Tempur Sealy International voted on Friday to overhaul the mattress maker’s board, including by stripping the company’s chief executive of a director seat.

headline: When a City Stops for Soccer
abstract: On Sunday, New York will get its own derby when the city’s two Major League Soccer teams, New York City F.C. and the Red Bulls, meet for the first time. So to preview this one, we asked veterans of other derbies to share their memories.

lead_paragraph: A strong showing by an incumbent party usually brings stability and continuity. That, at least, is how the markets read the unexpected and decisive victory by Prime Minister David Cameron’s Conservative Party in Britain’s general election on Thursday. The pound and stock prices had quick bounces. Further down the line, however, this election may prove to be a fateful turning point for British and European unity.

headline: Dancing With the Fishes at a Restaurant in Queens
abstract: The music at Greek-owned Astoria Seafood, a fish shop with tables and often long waits, is an invitation to cut the rug (on the white tiles).
lead_paragraph: “Let’s dance!” a waitress said one Friday at Astoria Seafood. It was a relatively quiet night, which means the wait for a table was only 25 minutes. The waitress, Elena Faroupos, 56, her eyes glamorously lined with a cheerful shade of green, threw her hands in the air and spun elegantly as Spyro Christakos, the owner, turned up the bouncy, brassy sounds of Greek music from behind the cash register.

headline: Review: Arlo Hill, Always in Love With Loesser
abstract: Mr. Hill’s cabaret show “I’ve Been in Love Before” at the Metropolitan Room is an expansive tribute to Frank Loesser, featuring 29 of the Broadway songwriter’s works.
lead_paragraph: The charismatic theater singer Arlo Hill aimed for the bull’s-eye in his Frank Loesser tribute, “I’ve Been in Love Before,” on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. The 28-year-old performer, accompanied on piano by Rick Hip-Flores, didn’t merely sing the work of the songwriter who turned Broadway on its ear 65 years ago with “Guys and Dolls.” He became Loesser’s champion and surrogate, punching out his songs in the brash, unpretty voice of a scrappy, streetwise rebel against the polite, polished musical theater of Rodgers and Hammerstein.

headline: First Manhattan Condo by a Chinese Developer

keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: StreetEasy, the New York real estate website, has a revamped iPhone app and a new Android app, where more than 19,000 rentals are listed.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a year ago, I reviewed an app called Movement, writing that it was the best service I had found for searching for apartment rentals on the smartphone. That a bootstrapped and relatively flawed app could be the best option spoke to the fact that big players had yet to fully enter the space, and as many could have predicted, Movement’s lead did not last long.

headline: Review: ‘NewYorknewyork @Astor Place,’ a Multilayered Production
abstract: This dance-theater work from Mark Dendy at Joe’s Pub includes a cast of historical and contemporary characters from Astor Place and the surrounding area.
lead_paragraph: Stacked books arranged like city blocks fill the diminutive stage of Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater. The book covers are white; there are no titles. Instead, the names of writers are projected against the back wall as a voice reads aloud: Samuel Beckett, Mark Twain, Upton Sinclair, Grace Paley. A feather-slim woman, Mei Yamanaka, winds around the stacks with nimble pliés and razor-sharp turns until her legs and arms turn deadly, and she demolishes the literary landscape. (Make way for e-readers.)

headline: A Loan Modification Program’s Limited Reach
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Foreclosures', 'Mortgages', 'Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan']
abstract: A federal inspector is taking the Treasury Department to task for not doing enough to promote HAMP, a program designed to help borrowers avoid foreclosure.
lead_paragraph: A federal inspector is taking the Treasury Department to task for not doing enough to increase participation in the government’s Home Affordable Modification Program, known as HAMP, which helps keep homeowners out of foreclosure. Borrowers having trouble paying their mortgage can apply to HAMP for a loan modification that lowers their monthly payment. So far, about 1.5 million homeowners have received HAMP modifications, about half as many as originally predicted by the Treasury. The department has repeatedly extended the program’s initial December 2013 deadline; HAMP now is scheduled to expire in December 2016.

So I’m culling my three-and-a-half decade collection drastically. The picture above shows the books I put out to be taken away today, which was day three; the books from the previous two days have already been taken away, and I expect to need all weekend to finish.

headline: At Castellano’s House of Music, Instruments to Sell and Stories to Hear

At last year’s Players Championship, Kaymer embraced it, posed for photographs with it. He may have even kissed it. And then he traveled home to Germany without it.

headline: Grand Army, a New Seafood Bar in Brooklyn
abstract: Grand Army, which opened on Tuesday evening in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, represents the coming-of-age of the neighborhood’s restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Grand Army, which opened on Tuesday evening in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, represents the coming-of-age of the neighborhood’s restaurants — a cocktail bar with only small plates, and nothing repurposed in sight. It’s also the coming-of-age of some restaurateurs: Noah Bernamoff of Mile End and Julian Brizzi of Rucola, who teamed up with a longtime Prime Meats bar director, Damon Boelte, to open in what was once the chrome-plated Victory Cafe. headline: Traces of Ziegfeld’s New York
abstract: Curse or no curse, the Ziegfeld Club, the subject of an article in this Sunday’s Metropolitan section, still remains in the city, as do other relics connected to the famous “Follies” impresario.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, Broadway actors spoke of a “Ziegfeld Curse,” because so many of Florenz Ziegfeld Jr.’s famous showgirls came to tragic ends. In the generations since the impresario’s death in 1932, New Yorkers might be forgiven for thinking that there is also a curse on anything to do with Ziegfeld’s memory. His lavish theater on Sixth Avenue was demolished in 1966, and now the owners of the Ziegfeld Theater, the world’s largest single screen cinema, built near the site of the original, have considered closing it, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Spotify’s Revenue Is Growing, but So Are Its Losses
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Royalties', 'Music', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The music streaming service said $197 million in losses in 2014 were the result of product development, international expansion and new personnel.
lead_paragraph: As streaming music has spread around the world, Spotify’s financial picture has remained much the same year after year: rapid revenue growth, with steady losses.

headline: Myrna Blyth, AARP Executive, and Her Sunday Routine
abstract: Ms. Blyth lives in Washington, D.C., Mondays through Thursdays, but comes home to New York City, and all it offers, on the weekends.
lead_paragraph: No offense to our nation’s capital, but for Myrna Blyth, who lives there Mondays through Thursdays, it is just not home. Home is where she spends her Sundays, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where she has lived in the same huge apartment for four decades. Ms. Blyth, 76, is a senior vice president at AARP and the editorial director of AARP Media. After three years of commuting, she is struck by the differences between the two cities. “There are more people on the street in New York at 10 o’clock on an O.K. evening than there are in Washington on any day but the inaugural,” she said. One draw Washington has for Ms. Blyth is her “adorable 5-year-old grandson,” who lives there, as does her son Jonathan. Her “beautiful redheaded granddaughter” and her other son, Graham, live in Portland, Me. For Mother’s Day, she and Jonathan plan to be in Manhattan together.

lead_paragraph: The 74-year-old jazz saxophonist Pharoah Sanders played in an unusual context on Wednesday night. headline: What Tom Brady Told Me During Deflategate, and What He Didn’t
abstract: The New England Patriots and the murky morality of professional football.
lead_paragraph: “I’m always a thinker — I’ve got to outthink them,” Tom Brady told me. It was early January, and I was working on an article for this magazine about “the N.F.L.’s ageless, ruthless, peerless superstar,” as the cover text would read. headline: Review: New York City Ballet Performs Bournonville Classics at Spring Gala
abstract: The double bill included “La Sylphide” and excerpts from other classic ballets by the Danish choreographer.
lead_paragraph: The new double bill at New York City Ballet, choreography by the great Danish ballet master August Bournonville (1805-79), presents the oldest pieces in the company’s repertory. Yet Bournonville’s ideas remain fresh and modern in these dances; and the program shows how today’s performers are challenged, focused and refreshed by them. Apart from one or two over-bright smiles as dancers sail through brilliant series of rapidly beaten jumps, they’re as engaged as if Bournonville himself was watching in the wings. And their steps are stitched, gleamingly and tightly, into their music

headline: Georgia: Transgender Inmate to Be Transferred
abstract: The Department of Corrections gave Ashley Diamond, a transgender inmate and prison rape victim, what a federal judge refused to grant her in April: a transfer to a medium-security prison.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Corrections on Friday gave Ashley Diamond, a transgender inmate and prison rape victim, what a federal judge refused to grant her in April: a transfer to a medium-security prison. The department, which previously maintained that Ms. Diamond was properly placed at Georgia State Prison, transferred her to Jack T Rutledge State Prison after she was touched on the face by another inmate during a group activity and then received a sexually explicit and threatening note from another inmate at a religious service. Ms. Diamond, who has sued corrections officials, charging that they have failed to protect her, had asked the federal judge to order the state to transfer her; he had declined to “second-guess” state authorities. Ms. Diamond, a transgender woman and nonviolent offender, has been housed primarily in men’s maximum-security prisons; her prior stay at Rutledge was the only time during her incarceration that she was not sexually victimized, her lawsuit said.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2 P.M. (FX) WANDERLUST (2012) Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd star as Linda and George, out-of-work Manhattanites unable to sell their “microloft” in the West Village. Then they stumble onto Elysium, an “intentional community” in rural Georgia, where good vibrations — and not a little smoke — fill the air. Established decades earlier by Carvin (Alan Alda), now in a wheelchair and battling memory loss, and his hippie friends, the commune is home to a touchy-feely guitar-strumming collage led by Seth (Justin Theroux), a creepy Lothario; and a novelist and nudist (Joe Lo Truglio) who wears the occasional sanitary pouch (like a hairnet, but lower) when he’s crushing grapes for homemade wine. “Part of what gives this movie unexpected resonance is that Linda and George have joined only somewhat voluntarily,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this “mostly funny comedy” from David Wain. “Like other Americans seeking simplicity and maybe a chicken coop out back, they want off the road, at least for a while. There’s something touching about this desire, though Mr. Wain doesn’t let Linda and George fly their freak flags for long.”

abstract: Each character in the author’s latest collection has an arsenal just special enough to make the damage he or she wreaks distinctive.

The malice comes in endless varieties — conscious, buried, self-destructive, jealous, spiteful, sexual, snobbish, druggie, fiendish and breathtakingly awful, to name only a few. The goodness is more limited. It might as well be. This writer, critic and teacher, whose books until now have included only two scalding novels, “Jernigan” (1991) and “Preston Falls” (1998), and one short story collection, “The Wonders of the Invisible World” (1999), rarely gives it a fighting chance.

Choreographed in 1975 to Ravel’s three-movement solo piano piece of that name, it’s an intricate, spellbinding vehicle for sensitive dancers. Although Balanchine originally made it for Violette Verdy and Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux as the opening of his Ravel festival, he soon revived it for Patricia McBride and Mikhail Baryshnikov (1979, for City Ballet’s European tour) and later for the radically dissimilar Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins.

headline: Action and Dysfunction in the U.S. Food-Safety Effort
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'E Coli (Bacteria)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Outbreaks of tainted food often lead to calamities that sicken millions and cause deaths, indicating that protections do not always work, some experts say.
lead_paragraph: The notion that “a crisis is a terrible thing to waste” is credited to the American economist Paul Romer, who offered the thought a decade ago in a discussion about education. Mr. Romer’s observation has since been echoed in a variety of contexts. It could be applied as well to stewardship of this country’s food supply. Significant measures to keep Americans from being sickened, and sometimes killed, by what they eat have tended to come only after calamity strikes. Even then, in the view of many experts on food safety, the United States has wasted too many crises for comfort.

headline: To Market, to Market with Rob Pruitt
abstract: The artist talks about his inspirations, in time for a career-spanning retrospective at the Brant Foundation.
lead_paragraph: From Obama to Marilyn Monroe to — naturally — himself, the artist Rob Pruitt has covered a wide range of subjects and mediums in his lifetime; one of his most prominent works to date is “The Andy Monument,” a 2011 statue of Andy Warhol that spent nearly a year and a half standing proudly in Union Square, near Warhol’s Factory stomping grounds. T caught up with the artist as he prepared a new retrospective at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., “Rob Pruitt 50th Birthday Bash” (this Sunday, May 17, is actually Pruitt’s 51st birthday; shh). The foundation commemorated the exhibition with a private event yesterday, which included an auction of items contributed by members of the Brant family themselves — yes, including the billionaire paper magnate after whom the foundation is named, Peter M. Brant, and his wife, the supermodel Stephanie Seymour; and yes, the offerings include a to-die-for assortment of Seymour’s shoes. Proceeds from the tag sale, which is ongoing throughout the exhibition, will benefit the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College. In the slide show above, Pruitt shared a few of his favorite items up for sale with T; he’ll also select some items later this month to add to his famous eBay page.

headline: How Blue Hill at Stone Barns Transplanted Its Farmhouse Feel Into a Sotheby’s Gallery

lead_paragraph: Michael Moore, Sotheby’s director of events, continually outdoes himself — it’s in his job description. With a three-person team, Moore produces more than 350 American events (and some abroad) for Sotheby’s each year, the crowning jewel of which is the ultraexclusive dinner that precedes the high-profile New York contemporary auction each spring and fall. This year, Moore faced the task of topping last spring’s contemporary dinner, for which Sotheby’s flew in 16 chefs from Noma, the Copenhagen restaurant often cited as the best in the world, and asked them to recreate its dining experience right in Sotheby’s New York flagship on the Upper East Side. (Moore and his team attempted to meet all of the chefs’ requests, no detail too small — one consequence of which was a long, thorough search for just the right river rocks for Noma to serve its langoustines upon.)

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:30 A.M. (Showtime) FRUITVALE STATION (2013) On Jan. 1, 2009, Oscar Grant III, a 22-year-old black father, was shot in the back by a white Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer on a subway platform in Oakland, Calif., his killing captured on cellphone. Ryan Coogler’s feature directorial debut reconstructs the final 24 hours in the life of Mr. Grant (played by Michael B. Jordan, above with Ariana Neal) who, after two stints in prison, had returned to selling drugs after losing his job at a supermarket because of chronic lateness. Octavia Spencer plays his mother and Melonie Diaz the mother of his daughter, with whom he’s trying to stay. Mr. Coogler’s “main intention — and his great achievement, as well as Mr. Jordan’s — is to make Oscar a fully human presence, to pay him the respect of acknowledging his complexities and contradictions,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The radicalism of ‘Fruitvale Station’ lies precisely here, in its refusal to turn a man into a symbol. Nearly every black man, whether or not he is president, tends to be flattened out by popular culture and the psychopathology of everyday American life, rendered as an innocent victim, a noble warrior or a menace to society. There is a dehumanizing violence in this habit, a willed, toxic blindness that ‘Fruitvale Station’ at once exposes and resists.”
