lead_paragraph: Yesterday Politico posted a hit piece on Elizabeth Warren, alleging that she’s being hypocritical in her opposition to a key aspect of TPP, that’s interesting in several ways. First, it was clearly based on information supplied by someone close to or inside the Obama administration – another illustration of the poisonous effect the determination to sell TPP is having on the Obama team’s intellectual ethics. Second, the charge of hypocrisy was ludicrous nonsense – “You say you’re against allowing corporations to sue governments, yet you were a paid witness against a corporations suing the government!” Um, what?

headline: Chicano Batman Serves Latin Rock With ’60s Spice
abstract: Chicano Batman — blending cumbia, bolero, vallenato and Brazilian pop experimentalism with soul vocals and twin guitars — plays three gigs in New York City this week.
lead_paragraph: Chicano Batman, from Los Angeles, plays an expanded version of 1960s Latin rock, with wah-wah pedals and organ — the kind of music a lot of non-Latin North Americans seldom heard before the age of scholarly CD reissues uncovering long-ago scenes in Peru, Chile, Brazil and Southern California. What it does is jammy, fuzzed-out and discursive, full of soul vocals and twin-guitar arrangements; it brings together elements of cumbia, bolero, vallenato and the Brazilian pop experimentalists of the late ’60s and early ’70s. The band members play in ruffled, powder-blue tuxedo shirts and deliver party music from top to bottom, with stylish attention to tube amps and analog warmth. But their sets are serious business: You can climb into one of them and follow it a long way. They’re rarely in New York but will perform three times this week: Sunday at the Loisaida Festival, in the East Village (loisaidafest.org); that evening at Brooklyn Bowl, in Williamsburg (brooklynbowl.com); and on Wednesday at Subrosa, in the West Village (subrosanyc.com).

abstract: The violinist Augustin Hadelich will perform Mozart’s Violin Concerto No. 5 “Turkish” in the concert.

But the stellar work he has done with the Pittsburgh Symphony and a few highly successful guest stints with the New York Philharmonic have made him one of the contenders to succeed Alan Gilbert in New York when he vacates the job of music director. Players and audiences can test the chemistry this week at a series of concerts beginning on Thursday, featuring the magnificent violinist Augustin Hadelich in Mozart’s Violin Concerto No. 5 “Turkish,” Brahms’s Fourth Symphony and the overture to Strauss’s “Die Fledermaus.” (Avery Fisher Hall Thursday at 7.30 p.m., Friday at 2 p.m. and Saturday at 8 p.m.; nyphil.org)

Since the late 1990s, he has been creating works of terrific technical ambition and sometimes controversial subject matter. For “Charles Ray: Sculpture 1997-2014,” the Art Institute of Chicago has devoted the 18,000 square feet of its second floor Modern Wing to just 17 pieces, affording lots of breathing room for each. “Horse and Rider” (2014), a full-scale equestrian self-portrait, will be displayed elsewhere in the museum. There, she made “Two Women” for the great Vittorio De Sica, a wrenching story of a mother trying to protect her 12-year-old daughter from the horrors of World War II, and was awarded a best actress Oscar in 1962, the first for a performer in a foreign language film.

headline: Art for Food’s Sake at the Whitney Museum’s Untitled
abstract: The restaurant in the recently opened museum in the meatpacking district offers an elegantly simple menu and stylish, sleek décor.
lead_paragraph: Despite some evidence to the contrary — the Modern, say, at the Museum of Modern Art — the words “museum restaurant” have not inspired culinary ecstasy so much as images of footsore diners and tuna salad sandwiches in plastic wrap. While art and eating are both intensely sensual experiences, even in New York they only occasionally coincide. Untitled, the glassy restaurant from Danny Meyer (who not coincidentally also runs the Modern) in the recently opened Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, is trying to establish a counter trend with an elegantly simple menu and stylish, sleek décor. Last Wednesday, three weeks after the restaurant opened, the line to get in was not quite as long as the line for the museum, but the dining room was nonetheless packed with a lunchtime crowd that included three members of a family whose interest in a good meal actually preceded their interest in the art.

headline: Review: ‘The Future Was Looking Better in the Past,’ a Long-Ago Crime Reappears
abstract: The performance artist Rebecca Patek’s work at the Chocolate Factory is partly based on Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb’s murder of Bobby Franks in 1924.
lead_paragraph: In Chicago in 1924, two affluent and intellectually precocious teenagers named Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb coldly murdered a 14-year-old boy named Bobby Franks. The crime and the trial spawned a media circus, novels, plays and films. On Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, the performance artist Rebecca Patek added another work to the pile. The Leopold and Loeb case, though, is not the only subject of Ms. Patek’s jumbled, hourlong “The Future Was Looking Better in the Past.” (The subtitle runs on for 28 more words.) The murderers and their victim are played by dancer-actors, who recite segments of actual and imagined courtroom testimony and who appear in video re-enactments and fantasies. But the same performers also portray Ms. Patek and an interviewer discussing the process and motivations behind this show. (Here, and in the program bio, Ms. Patek claims to be related to Loeb.) Threaded in alternation with these two strands is a third, given in audio with subtitles, as if from a wiretap recording. This is a scene presented as another crime, one from last year, in which Ms. Patek engages in sex acts with anonymous men.

headline: Good News for the Nation’s Waterways
keywords: ['Clean Water Act', 'Environment', 'Lakes', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Water', 'Water Pollution', 'Wetlands']
abstract: A new rule expected next week would restore federal protections to some of the waters the Clean Water Act aimed to protect.
lead_paragraph: Joan Mulhern would have loved this day, had she lived to see it. Joan, who died at the age of 51 in December 2012, was a feisty Massachusetts native, passionate Red Sox fan and environmental lawyer who gravitated to the Washington office of Earthjustice, an advocacy group she served as a senior attorney while becoming an absolute terror to anyone who threatened the waters of the United States — legislators and lobbyists, passive regulators, coal companies that insisted on blasting the tops off mountains and dumping coal slag in the valleys and streams below. Her biggest cause, in which she enlisted every environmentalist, journalist and ordinary citizen she could buttonhole, was to restore the full meaning and scope of the 1972 Clean Water Act, whose protections, she believed, had been fatally weakened by the courts and by politicians in thrall to special interests — mainly developers, industrial and municipal polluters, and big farmers. Next week, barring an 11th-hour cave-in by the White House, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers are expected to issue a firm, clear rule restoring federal protections to most (though probably not all) of the waters the Act’s framers, and Joan, had hoped to protect.

We humans, by contrast, can get goose bumps when we experience awe, that often-positive feeling of being in the presence of something vast that transcends our understanding of the world.

abstract: Fashion and nature reflect each other’s beauty.
lead_paragraph: Fashion and nature reflect each other’s beauty. Early in May back in New York, buttercups dominated a farmers’ market. The color showed up in fashion as well, and even on a sports car. abstract: Governor Cuomo’s bill would reward those who are already contributing to private schools, when it is public schools that need a financial boost.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo can talk passionately about improving New York’s “failing public schools,” but when he made that point at churches and a yeshiva last Sunday it was, at best, disingenuous. He was there to sell his bill that would help private and parochial schools, by offering big tax credits to their donors. This energetic effort for an expensive and possibly unconstitutional bill that Mr. Cuomo has named the Parental Choice in Education Act could cost the state more than $150 million a year. headline: Honduras: Ex-President’s Son Arrested

The charge carries a maximum sentence of life in prison, said the office of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Lobo had been arrested in Haiti. The defendant’s father, Porfirio Lobo, served as president of Honduras from 2010 to 2014. The Associated Press reported that the father, in an interview with government television, said he hoped that his son could prove his innocence. “Fabio is not a child,” The A.P. quoted him as saying. “He is a man with a family and must answer for his actions.” Manuel J. Retureta, a lawyer for Mr. Lobo, said his client would enter a plea of not guilty.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES (2014) A decade has passed on screen since “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” and millions of people have fallen prey to a lethal virus, leaving survivors to cobble together a society in the ruins of San Francisco, where Dreyfus (Gary Oldman), the former police chief, is in charge. But across the Golden Gate Bridge in Marin County, the upright-walking chimpanzee Caesar (Andy Serkis) and his team have built their own civilization, complete with distinctive wooden architecture, domesticated horses, a sophisticated sign language and an education system overseen by the orangutan Maurice (Karin Konoval). But when the humans ask to encroach on their territory to build a hydroelectric station, the alarms are sounded — and schisms formed. “It’s a satisfying movie and an example — a dispiritingly rare one these days — of what mainstream Hollywood filmmaking can still achieve,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Matt Reeves’s Oscar nominee for best achievement in visual effects. “That we have progressed from ‘Rise’ only as far as ‘Dawn’ suggests many future sequels, which may, in this case, be a source of hope as well as dread, provided that civilization doesn’t collapse in the meantime.”

keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Assyrian Civilization']
abstract: Not everything about Palmyra is irreplaceable.
lead_paragraph: THE guard from the antiquities authority was asleep when I arrived at the Temple of Bel, deep in the Syrian desert. Not unreasonable, given that it was before visiting hours, maybe 5:30 a.m., and almost totally dark. A ribbon of purple on the horizon hinted at sunrise, and the war raging over there, in Iraq. But this was Syria, in 2005, and another day of the Assad family dictatorship was dawning in perfect order. European tourists were about to crawl over the ruins of Palmyra, and the biggest structure of all, a 2,000-year-old monument to an official god, was barely visible in front of me. “O.K.,” the guard said, waving me inside. “Go ahead. You can look.”

headline: What College Applications Shouldn’t Ask
abstract: High school disciplinary records have no place in the admissions process.
lead_paragraph: Over the last several years, the federal government has been pushing school districts across the country to dial back disciplinary policies under which children are suspended for minor misbehavior that once would have been dealt with in a meeting with parents or though minor sanctions like detention. These “zero tolerance” policies make it more likely that children will drop out, and they are especially damaging to minority students, who are disproportionately subjected to suspension, expulsion or even arrest for nonviolent offenses. Now, colleges that penalize applicants for high school disciplinary records should change their policies as well.

headline: 30 Seconds With Edwin Moses: Understanding Racing Mechanics
abstract: Edwin Moses, who won gold medals in the 400-meter hurdles at the 1976 and 1984 Olympics, has long been a fan of Formula One racing.
lead_paragraph: Edwin Moses, 59, won gold medals in the 400-meter hurdles at the 1976 and 1984 Olympics. From 1977 to 1987, he won 122 consecutive races and set the world record four times. In 2000, he was elected the first chairman of the Laureus World Sports Academy, an international service organization designed to increase participation in sports and to promote sports as a tool for social change. Moses graduated from Morehouse College in Atlanta with a degree in physics and industrial engineering. He worked as an engineer at General Dynamics in the cruise missile program before devoting himself to sports full time. He has long been a fan of Formula One racing. Since 2000, Mercedes has been a sponsor of Laureus, giving Moses a door to the Formula One paddock. The questions and answers below have been edited and condensed.

headline: 1915: Germany at War With Italy
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Berlin reacts to what it calls “the defection of the third ally and her desertion to the enemies’ camp.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Following on Italy’s declaration of war on Austria-Hungary, says an Amsterdam despatch, Germany declared war this morning [May 24] on Italy. A Berlin official telegram says: ‘‘The Italian Government yesterday caused to be declared through Duca d’Avarna, Italian Ambassador to the Austro-Hungarian Government, that Italy considered herself from midnight in a state of war with Austria-Hungary. The Italian Government by this provocative attack on the Dual Monarchy has also broken without right or reason the alliance with Germany. The loyal relation existing according to treaty between Austria-Hungary and the German Empire which has been still more firmly welded by comradeship in arms has remained uninjured by the defection of the third ally and her desertion to the enemies’ camp. The German Ambassador, Prince Bülow, has therefore received instructions to leave Rome conjointly with the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador, Baron Macchio.’’ Prince Bülow left Rome this evening at 9.45. The Prussian Minister to the Vatican and the Bavarian Ministers to the Quirinal and the Vatican left by the same train. — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 25, 1915

lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO – An inter-American peace-keeping force, comprised primarily of U.S. troops, today [May 24] took over the job of ending the Dominican crisis. A Brazilian general, Hugo Panasco Alvim, was named to command the Organization of American States forces, the first such in hemispheric history. The U.S. ground commander, Lt. Gen. Bruce Palmer jr., was named deputy commander. Jose A. Mora, secretary-general of the OAS, last night signed documents officially putting the unit into operation as junta and rebel troops continued to observe an informal cease-fire.

lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — In 1952, the year the American Psychiatric Association declared homosexuality a “sociopathic personality disturbance,” readers began discovering Patricia Highsmith’s lesbian romance “The Price of Salt.” Initially published under the name Claire Morgan — the cover promised “a modern novel of two women” — it involves a naïve 19-year-old, Therese Belivet, whose world spins deliriously off its axis when she meets the older Carol Aird, a lovely blonde whose voice, Highsmith wrote, “was rich and supple, and somehow full of secrets.”

headline: Behind the Downfall at BlackBerry
abstract: A new book by two reporters from The Globe and Mail offers details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding BlackBerry’s near collapse.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis stepped down as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of BlackBerry, neither has spoken much in public about the once-dominant smartphone maker’s fall into near market obscurity. The two and many others have opened up, however, to two reporters from The Globe and Mail in Toronto: Jacquie McNish, a senior business writer and author of several books and Sean Silcoff, who reports about the company. The resulting book, “Losing the Signal: The Untold Story Behind the Extraordinary Rise and Spectacular Fall of BlackBerry,” which will be published in the United States on Tuesday, fills in some details of the early history of BlackBerry. And its later chapters offer gripping details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding its near collapse.

headline: Olsen Twins Won’t Appear in ‘Full House’ Reboot
abstract: The coming Netflix reboot of “Full House” will move forward without the twins who took turns playing the cheeky Michelle Tanner on the ’90s sitcom.
lead_paragraph: You’re in big trouble, mister! The coming Netflix reboot of “Full House” will move forward without Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, the twins who took turns playing the cheeky Michelle Tanner on the ’90s sitcom. “Although Ashley and Mary-Kate will not be a part of ‘Fuller House,’ I know how much ‘Full House’ meant to them and they are still very much considered family,” said Robert L. Boyett, the show’s executive producer, in a statement given to The Hollywood Reporter. The Olsen twins started filming in the role of Michelle at 9 months old, and remained on the show for its full eight seasons. They now run Dualstar, a lifestyle and fashion company. The new season will center on other members of the original Tanner clan, including D. J. (Candace Cameron Bure) and Stephanie (Jodie Sweetin). The Olsens’ former co-star John Stamos, who announced the show’s return on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” last month, tweeted that he was “heartbroken” the twins would not be returning. Still, there’s always a chance they’ll change their minds: David Lynch recently returned to the revival of “Twin Peaks” after renouncing his ties to the project.

headline: Lincoln Center President Saw Increase in Bonus
abstract: Lincoln Center showed its appreciation to Reynold Levy, its president who stepped down last January, by raising his bonus to $600,000 in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center showed its appreciation to Reynold Levy, its president who stepped down last January, by raising his bonus to $600,000 in 2013, his last year with the organization, according to recent tax filings. The bonus was on top of his $1.29 million salary and pushed Mr. Levy’s total compensation package to $2.4 million, including retirement payments and other benefits, up from $2.2 million the previous year. “The bonus was based on annual reviews of his performance and his project performance,” said Eileen McMahon, a representative for Lincoln Center. She also noted that the bonus, first reported by The New York Post, was based on 18 months of work, not 12. Mr. Levy spent 11 years as president of the performing arts center, where he was renowned for his fund-raising abilities and applauded for completing an ambitious $1.2 billion renovation project. His recently released memoir, “They Told Me Not to Take That Job: Tumult, Betrayal, Heroics, and the Transformation of Lincoln Center,” depicts the interior struggles over the renovation and included criticism of other New York cultural executives.

The polluter, General Electric, has been digging up toxic PCB’s, polychlorinated biphenyls, that it dumped into the river, by the millions of pounds, decades ago. It plans to keep dredging through the fall, then pack up its machinery and walk away from the job.

Ten House members and 32 of their staff members should be pondering that question now that their all-expenses-paid trip to Baku two years ago has been found by ethics investigators to have been secretly financed by Azerbaijan’s state-owned oil company. That would be a violation of House ethics rules and federal law against foreign governments’ intruding into United States policy.

headline: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
abstract: Judy Blume’s first novel for adults in 17 years is about a ninth-grade Jewish girl and her New Jersey community in the aftermath of three plane crashes in the town.
lead_paragraph: Judy Blume isn’t just revered, she’s revolutionary. She has dared to write about so-called taboo topics for children and young adults — racism (“Iggie’s House”), bullying (“Blubber”), sex (“Forever . . . ”) — and has done it so honestly that her work is both beloved and banned. Now, in her first novel for adults in 17 years, she uses her own young life as source material, revisiting a time when three planes crashed over eight weeks in her hometown, during an indelible period of history — the ­beginning of the 1950s, just as the glossy suburban dream of picket fences and safe conformity jutted up against unrelenting Cold War paranoia.

headline: Getting It Right
abstract: Why merely believing something that is true doesn’t qualify as real knowledge.
lead_paragraph: What is it to truly know something? In our daily lives, we might not give this much thought — most of us rely on what we consider to be fair judgment and common sense in establishing knowledge. But the task of clearly defining true knowledge is trickier than it may first seem, and it is a problem philosophers have been wrestling with since Socrates.

headline: How the Civil War Became the Indian Wars
abstract: We think of the two conflicts as separate, but they were tightly intertwined.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 21, 1866, a year and a half after Gen. Robert E. Lee and Gen. Ulysses S. Grant ostensibly closed the book on the Civil War’s final chapter at Appomattox Court House, another soldier, Capt. William Fetterman, led cavalrymen from Fort Phil Kearny, a federal outpost in Wyoming, toward the base of the Big Horn range. The men planned to attack Indians who had reportedly been menacing local settlers. Instead, a group of Arapahos, Cheyennes and Lakotas, including a warrior named Crazy Horse, killed Fetterman and 80 of his men. It was the Army’s worst defeat on the Plains to date. The Civil War was over, but the Indian wars were just beginning.

If I had it my way, we’d all be together, too — with our toes in the sand, sitting on piles of snuggly soft, body-engulfing velour and terry beach towels like the ones from Ruby Mint. headline: 1915: Italian Troops Advance
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Italian troops confront Austrians.

During May 24 our artillery shelled the positions occupied by the enemy’s artillery. On the frontier of Friuli our troops have everywhere advanced into enemy territory and have encountered only a feeble resistance. We have occupied Caporetto, the heights between the Judrio and Isonzo, Cormons, Cervignano and Terzo. — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 26, 1915

headline: Massimo Bottura’s Pope Francis-Approved Refectory, and Recipe to Turn Stale Bread Into Gold
abstract: The Michelin-starred chef discusses the Ambrosian Refectory — an old theater converted into a dining hall during Expo Milano 2015.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s most progressive exhibition of sustainable cooking commences this Thursday, when the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura throws open the doors of Refettorio Ambrosiano, the once-derelict theater repurposed to educate and feed the refugees and working poor who reside far across town from the multinational pavilions welcoming culinary tourists to this summer’s Expo Milano 2015. The contemporary refectory in the heart of the city’s under-resourced Greco neighborhood will host a coterie of Bottura’s most charitable colleagues, beginning with Eleven Madison Park’s Daniel Humm and former Chez Panise chef Seen Lippert, eager to make a feast of the exposition’s transported food waste for those most in need by performing culinary alchemy twice daily in a glass-enclosed stage. “At lunchtime, there are going to be students there; and the very best chefs in the world, the rock ‘n’ roll stars, will be cooking scraps for them,” says Bottura of the facility’s secondary mission. “It’s like the Pope washing the feet of the people in the street.” While Bottura’s inspiration for the project draws on local influences including the Italian cinematic fantasia “Miracle in Milan” and Leonardo da Vinci’s “Last Supper,” his greatest motivator has been Pope Francis, whose spontaneous utterance of “Buon pranzo!” (“Good lunch!”) five days into his papacy inspired a renewed sense of faith within the chef. “Introducing himself with those words reminds everyone to start each day with humility, and humility is the most important thing,” Bottura says, “because from there others are going to follow you.”

headline: Hollywood

lead_paragraph: Who qualifies as an icon? What deserves to be called iconic? In matters of Hollywood, a designation that originally pertained to religious imagery is now regularly applied to subjects as secular as “Animal House,” Sandra Bullock, “Vertigo,” W. C. Fields and that scene in the original “Friday the 13th” where Kevin Bacon is stabbed through the neck with an arrow. One army of admirers may think the title ought to go to “This Is Spinal Tap”; for a different platoon, Judy Garland deserves the title for life.

headline: Humor
abstract: Michael Ian Black reviews new books by Dave Barry, Brad Garrett, Mamrie Hart and more.
lead_paragraph: A complaint: The “humor section” is a meaningless bookseller’s term. Think about it for a second. If you go to the bookstore and find yourself browsing the biography section, you know what you’re going to get: biographies. Mystery section: mysteries. Sports: books about sports. But humor is something else entirely, conveying an intention rather than a subject. Rare is the humorous book about humor, although Joe Randazzo has just written quite a good one about breaking into the humor industry. Books filed under “humor” aren’t about anything specific. Their subjects run the gamut from “Calvin and Hobbes” anthologies to comedic memoirs to pop culture parodies to the sorts of gift books that are best read from the cozy confines of the commode. Their only commonality is their desire to amuse.

headline: Reducing My Dose, Unblocking My Muse
abstract: Why would I quit my anxiety and depression medication just because I had writer’s block?
lead_paragraph: I’m spending a month at an artist residency in central Mexico, where I’ve befriended a local healer named Katuza who believes in the spirit world. He believes in the power of plants, especially peyote. He believes in the temescal (sweat lodge) as a cure for most ailments, including depression, anxiety, and insomnia. He has long gray hair, a long gray beard, the wide eyes of the ecstatic. He says that I need to release the things I hold in my chest. “We will teach you how to scream,” he says. He often uses the first-person plural — maybe because English is his second language, maybe in homage to interconnectedness.

headline: A Place to Sip Piña Coladas in Your Own Private Pool
abstract: Mahekal Beach Resort in Mexico is a quaint departure from the big-box, all-inclusive hotels in the area.
lead_paragraph: To escape the tyranny of the all-inclusive big-box resorts that dominate much of the Riviera Maya, the pristine stretch of coastline that stretches from Cancun to Tulum (and beyond), there’s Mahekal — a 122-room boutique hotel nestled on the glistening Caribbean Sea and right off bustling Fifth Avenue in Playa del Carmen. Opened in December, the luxury village is comprised of many thatched-roof, airy casitas that are both plush and vibrant. Splurge for one a stone’s throw from the beach with your own private plunge pool. When you get tired of sipping banana piña coladas at the infinity pool or in the hammock on your porch, hire a private boat that leaves right from the property’s water edge to take you 30 minutes down the coast to Ihna Bay, where you’ll find shallow reefs and dazzlingly clear water ideal for snorkeling. Unplugging from the world is practically mandated — there are no televisions, and Wi-Fi, while it is available in the rooms, is spotty. Access to shopping and ruins is easy — but not worth sacrificing a day in paradise.

headline: Jeb Bush as John Kerry
abstract: Rising to the challenge of imagining Jeb’s path to victory.
lead_paragraph: Almost two months ago, I wrote a column sketching out how Jeb Bush might lose the Republican nomination. Since then, it’s become more interesting, because it’s more challenging, to try to figure out exactly how he might win. Yes, he has the money; yes, he has the connections; yes, he still leads, technically, in the current poll of polls. But he isn’t going to take the Republican nomination with 15 percent of the primary vote; he needs a whole lot of voters who currently lean toward Marco Rubio or Scott Walker or Paul or Huckabee or Carson or Cruz or PerryFiorinaJindalSantorumKasich to decide, actually, I guess Jeb Bush is the candidate for me. If neither Rubio nor Walker were in the race, it would be relative easy to see how that consolidation would eventually happen (as it did for Mitt Romney in the end). But with them — and their own money, their own respectable center-right supporters, and so on? Let’s just say that when you’re polling at just 25 percent in a head-to-head against Rubio (and the Rubio-Walker head-to-head is a lot closer), you have a problem that a better answer to questions about the Iraq invasion isn’t going to be enough to solve.

headline: 1965: Voting Rights Bill Adopted
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Senate approves bill giving voting rights to blacks in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After five weeks of debate, the Senate today [May 26] approved President Johnson’s Negro voting rights bill by a 77-to-19 roll call. Senate passage of the historic measure came after the isolated Southern camp concluded a bitter verbal assault on the bill, which would suspend literacy tests and install federal registrars throughout much of the old Confederacy. The bill now goes to the House. Should the House, however, insist on making some relatively minor changes in the voting bill, a conference could still be avoided by sending the revised draft back to the Senate for approval. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 27, 1965

headline: Lassa Fever Carries Little Risk to Public, Experts Say
abstract: The viral illness killed a man who had traveled to New Jersey from Liberia, where it is common, but it does not carry the threat of Ebola or spread easily from person to person.
lead_paragraph: The report that a man who traveled from Liberia to New Jersey had died on Monday from the viral illness Lassa fever is another reminder that infectious diseases can hop continents and elude detection by health care workers who do not know a patient’s travel history.

headline: Iraqi Army and Shiite Militias Begin Push to Take Ramadi From ISIS
abstract: The offensive began Tuesday in the desert areas north and east of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi officials said Tuesday that a combined force of Iraqi soldiers and allied Shiite militias had started moving to retake the city of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, from Islamic State fighters.

headline: Time Warner Cable Finds That Money Covers Charter’s Flaws
abstract: Last year, Time Warner Cable balked at the leverage, cash and stock on offer from Charter. Those terms haven’t changed much, but the price has shot up.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner Cable has concluded that one out of four ain’t bad.

headline: Toogood’s Indigo Installation in Amagansett
abstract: The sister designers Faye and Erica filled the stylist Tiina Laakkonen’s East Hampton boutique with a shoppable salute to the blue-collar worker.
lead_paragraph: “We hereby reject and reprehend the cruel diktats of the discredited fashionista treadmill,” reads the brand manifesto for Toogood, the clothing line created by the British designer Faye Toogood and her younger sister, the Savile Row-trained pattern cutter and fashion designer Erica Toogood. Like the elder Toogood’s celebrated furniture and interiors, the project — which introduces its second collection this spring, though the sisters disavow the concept of fashion seasons — is a humanistic exploration of the possibilities of handicraft. Each unisex, oversize piece is named for a profession (the plumber jumpsuit, the beekeeper jacket) and finished with droll details (handpainted mask appliqués, “Abolish the High Street” spelled out in frayed rope) that must be seen in person to be fully appreciated. Now, Statesiders will have the chance to do just that thanks to a new installation created by the sisters at Tiina, the Amagansett boutique owned by the influential Finnish-born stylist Tiina Laakkonen.

headline: Kayak Suspect Moved Paddle Away as Fiancé Died, Prosecutors Say
abstract: In a news conference on Tuesday, prosecutors disclosed new details in the death of Vincent Viafore, the kayaker who had been missing for weeks.
lead_paragraph: GOSHEN, N.Y. — Her fiancé, separated from his kayak, struggled in the frigid and choppy waters of the Hudson River, reaching for his paddle to save his life. But prosecutors here in Orange County said on Tuesday that Angelika Graswald moved it away, and was slow to call for help.

headline: Suspect Killed by Police After Woman Is Fatally Shot Outside Queens Casino
abstract: The suspect, Dalton Branch, an ex-boyfriend of the woman, was pursued and killed by officers in Brooklyn when he opened fire on them Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Gunshots were fired early on Tuesday in the parking lot of the Resorts World Casino in Queens. The police were called, and officers discovered a 55-year-old woman slumped in her car, fatally wounded.

headline: Jeb Bush Signals More Funding and Faster Drug Approval for Alzheimer’s
abstract: Jeb Bush gives strong hints that if he runs for president and wins, he would be willing to reverse some spending cuts to medical research that Republicans have pushed for during budget battles.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush opened up last week about his mother-in-law’s affliction with Alzheimer’s disease and, on Tuesday, shed some light on what he thinks should be done to fight the illness.

headline: More Strikes at National Gallery in London
abstract: Some 200 employees are participating in the strike, expected to last until June 4, which could block visitors’ access to some works and events.
lead_paragraph: National Gallery employees in London began a new wave of strikes on Tuesday at one of London’s most-visited museums to protest ongoing measures to privatize some staff positions.

abstract: Basics to set up a garden using window boxes, containers and hanging baskets.
lead_paragraph: Herbs, tomatoes, blueberries, nasturtiums and many other edibles can flourish in window boxes, pots, hanging baskets and recycled containers.

headline: Ann Kirkpatrick to Challenge John McCain for Arizona Senate
abstract: Representative Ann Kirkpatrick enters the race as a likely underdog to Senator John McCain, the five-term Republican who is running for re-election.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ann Kirkpatrick announced on Tuesday that she will run for United States Senate in Arizona, setting up a likely challenge to Senator John McCain.

headline: With Short-Term Goals, Go for a Bird in the Hand
abstract: The return on an investment is not nearly as important as having the money there when it’s needed, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine recently sold his house. It will be a few years before he’ll buy another one. Because the house was worth a lot more than what he and his wife owed the bank on their mortgage, they are now sitting on a pile of money and wondering what to do with it.

headline: Tech Rivalries Impede Digital Medical Record Sharing
keywords: ['Electronic Health Records', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Obama administration has spent billions on getting doctors and hospitals to computerize patient records, but not everyone is playing along.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Obama took office, the federal government has poured more than $29 billion into health information technology and told doctors and hospitals to use electronic medical records or face financial penalties.

headline: Police in Cleveland Accept Tough Standards on Force
abstract: The Cleveland police department has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, part of a settlement with the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland police department, which has become synonymous with the racially charged debate over police tactics, has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, and it will accept close oversight to make sure those rules are not ignored, city and federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: The ‘King of Cable’ Behind a Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
abstract: John Malone made his fortune as a pioneering baron of American cable, and has had his hands in everything from the Discovery Channel to DirecTV.
lead_paragraph: When the billionaire media executive John C. Malone bought a million acres of Maine forestland in 2011, assuming the mantle of America’s top landowner from his friend and fellow mogul Ted Turner, he made no triumphant announcement. Instead, he shielded his identity through a shell company.

headline: A Drive for Swing State Votes Has Colorado’s Latinos Listening
abstract: Both parties are planning an aggressive courtship of Latino voters for 2016, with Republicans trying to chip away at the Democrats’ hold on the bloc.
lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Under the red roof of Lupita’s Mexican Restaurant, Elizabeth Oxley and her 23-year-old daughter, Leticia, work seven days a week, from breakfast to last call, to keep pace with the price of their family’s American dream. There is a $250,000 renovation on their restaurant to pay off. Mortgage bills. College loans.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Tuesday to hear a case that will answer a long-contested question about a bedrock principle of the American political system: the meaning of “one person one vote.”

headline: Key to a Quick Goal? It May Be Resting in the Penalty Box
abstract: Twice in these playoffs, Rangers players have scored immediately upon exiting the box. Luck is a factor, but there are steps the Rangers take to be prepared for such moments.
lead_paragraph: The moment when a hockey penalty is successfully killed has its own rhythm. The goalie whose team no longer has the man advantage pounds his stick against the ice, alerting his teammates the way a guard might signal a prison break. And the punished player bursts from the penalty box, often to join the action, skating harder than ever.

headline: Scott Walker May Let Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio Fight Over Florida
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has not formally announced that he is seeking the Republican nomination, but he has clearly given some thought to what his campaign strategy might be.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has not formally announced that he is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, but he has clearly given some thought to what his campaign strategy might be if he does run.

headline: Will the Charter-Time Warner Deal Benefit Customers?
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The F.C.C. should make sure it does before approving it.
lead_paragraph: Charter’s proposed $56.7 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable poses fewer antitrust problems than Comcast’s ill-fated plan to buy Time Warner Cable. But the Federal Communications Commission should still study the proposal carefully to make sure it will benefit the companies’ customers.

headline: Portraits of the Youth of a Nation on the Verge of Revolution
abstract: For a new book, Daniel King photographed teens in Ukraine in the final months of 2013, leading up to the country’s descent into civil war.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that adolescence can be a particularly turbulent time. But in the case of the teenagers photographed by Daniel King for “Ukraine Youth: Between Days” (Damiani, $40), the nation’s then-impending revolution lends an added dimension of angst to that equation — “The Breakfast Club,” this is not. Shot in the final months of 2013 leading up to Ukraine’s descent into civil war, King’s photographs document the innocent revelry and flirtations of kids whose country’s fate is increasingly uncertain. King’s candid work falls somewhere between Larry Clark and Nan Goldin, and his interest in Ukrainian teens is part of a larger project he is working on, photographing “youth culture around the world.”

headline: Federal Panel Lets Injunction Against Obama’s Immigration Actions Stand
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The three-judge panel in New Orleans left in place an order temporarily halting President Obama’s executive actions on immigration.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday denied the Obama administration’s request to lift a hold on the president’s executive actions on immigration, which would have granted protection from deportation as well as work permits to millions of immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: Security Researchers Start Effort to Protect ‘Smart’ Cities
abstract: Cities around the world are spending billions to automate and computerize everything from traffic control to the power grid. But fears are growing that these networks are easy targets for attacks.
lead_paragraph: It’s a brave new world when hackers step in to protect citizens because regulators are not getting the job done.

headline: Garlic Shrimp Lightened by Its Own Broth
abstract: Shell broth reduces the olive oil component, with green garlic adding a sweet edge.

headline: ‘Hand to God’ Melds Gore and Giggles, Each Often Elicited by a Puppet
abstract: This Tony nominee for best play stitches together comedy and horror with the help of Tyrone, the hand puppet that acts as the main character’s angry id.
lead_paragraph: In “Hand to God,” a hand puppet named Tyrone violently bites the ear of an unsuspecting young man, and the audience, both times I saw the show, seemed unsure how to react.

headline: Jungle Camp in Malaysia Yields Graves and Signs of Migrant Abuse
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Smuggling']
abstract: Investigators on Tuesday revealed some of their grim discoveries at an encampment in the north, which they suspect was used by human traffickers.
lead_paragraph: BUKIT WANG BURMA, Malaysia — Among the debris of wood, bamboo and plastic tarpaulin at an abandoned camp in the dense jungle here lies a coffin-size cage made from sticks tied together with rusted barbed wire. Next to it, an enclosure that could have held scores of people also bristles with barbed wire. And over a ridge, the police have started unearthing bodies from shallow graves.

headline: Ducks’ Patrick Maroon, a Fallen Top Prospect, Climbs All the Way Back

headline: Review: ‘D Deb Debbie Deborah,’ a Dizzying Subversion of Identity
abstract: In Jerry Lieblich’s play in Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks series, questions of who’s playing whom become as giddy as a “Who’s on first?” routine.
lead_paragraph: Have they come up with a name yet for the fear of identity theft? Egokleptophobia, maybe? Whatever you want to call this topical neurosis, it throbs like an insistent bass line in “D Deb Debbie Deborah,” Jerry Lieblich’s dizzyingly clever new play about mutating selfhood.

headline: Review: Ibrahim Maalouf Salutes a Great Arabic Performer
abstract: This trumpeter’s tribute to the singer Oum Kalthoum was both a feat of cultural translation and a display of devotion.
lead_paragraph: Ibrahim Maalouf took just one unaccompanied trumpet solo in his early set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Monday night, but it was a depth charge, a flash immersion in the distinguishing features of his art. A moment earlier his band had been busy with a tumbling vamp in 7/8 meter, and he carried that pulse as he improvised, in dartlike bursts and a shadowy tone. At one point he segued into what sounded like a classical trumpet étude, exuding an impeccable control, before he moved on to a series of quavering embellishments and shivery incantations.

headline: Review: New York Youth Symphony Fearlessly Tackles Beethoven’s Ninth
abstract: The orchestra played this symphony with taut energy, clear vision and welcome heft as part of its spring concert at Carnegie Hall.

And it could stand as a description of the orchestra’s playing throughout Sunday’s program, especially in a properly exciting performance of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony.

Marchionda, coupled with a few assists from a local architectural firm, is bringing pedestrian traffic into what were once streets of desolation.

abstract: The new book from Mr. Johnson, who wrote “Pym,” is about a biracial man who finds out he has a daughter who doesn’t know she is biracial.

headline: Former Strongman, Taking Over Presidency, Raises Hope in Nigeria

Etruscan and Attic vases, a 17th-century Venetian cannon, a 12th-century mural fragment depicting Christ and three rare 17th-century books.

headline: High Desert Magic (But Don’t Call It a Music Festival)
abstract: FORM Arcosanti vets not only its lineup — bands, a folk chanteuse, pianists, filmmakers — but also its guest list.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to imagine improving on the experience of Arcosanti, the architect Paolo Soleri’s urban laboratory and Arizona desert eco-experiment. That is until the microcity — tucked away an hour north of Phoenix among Saguaro cacti and dark, spindly cypress trees — hosts FORM Arcosanti, a three-day gathering curated by the dreamy quartet Hundred Waters. With a lineup of bands like Majical Cloudz, Holly Herndon and How to Dress Well, a standout performance by the folk chanteuse Julie Byrne and a special guest performance by Skrillex, one might be tempted to call the sum of the past weekend’s events a music festival. But that would be missing the point.

headline: A Music Video That Takes Cut and Paste to a New Level
abstract: The visuals that accompany Paul de Jong’s “Hollywald” were painstakingly assembled by the musician himself.
lead_paragraph: The musician Paul de Jong could be seen as a spiritual precursor to the Tumblr generation — or, possibly, as its polar opposite. “It’s not like I’m pulling my imagery from the Internet where it’s already available,” says de Jong, referring to the massive collection of music, books and other ephemera that line the walls of his New Lebanon, N.Y. workspace and studio. “What appeals to me is that it can’t be found anywhere.” De Jong is a cellist and songwriter best known for his role as half of the experimental duo the Books, whose cut-and-paste musical collages resulted in some of the 2000s most beguiling records. Now recording solo, de Jong’s penchant for found sound and folk-pop has made its way to his new album “If” (out now via Temporary Residence) and the handmade animated video for “Hollywald,” which we’re premiering for the first time here.

headline: London’s New Trio of Exceptional Kebabs
abstract: The humble street food gets a gourmet makeover.
lead_paragraph: That bastion of late-night British cuisine, the humble kebab shop, is slowly shedding its boozy reputation thanks to a round of gourmet grill houses opening up in the capital. Foremost is Sesame, a cheerful, no-reservations Mediterranean street-food spot just opened in London’s Covent Garden. It’s the first fast-food venture from the upmarket deli group Ottolenghi — conceived by Noam Bar, the longstanding business partner, and former boyfriend, of the influential chef and food writer Yotam Ottolenghi. “It’s a happy marriage between meat, fresh salad and beautiful condiments,” explains the Haifa-raised creator of Sesame’s spiced lamb kebab, which is served in the traditional Turkish style with mint yogurt, tahini, zhough (a Yemenite chili paste) and a pared-down version of the signature Ottolenghi salad — all neatly encased in the most pillowy pitta you’re likely to encounter this side of Istanbul. “An awful lot of thought went into the spices,” Bar says. “There’s even some cinnamon in there.” Inspiration for Sesame struck the Ottolenghi co-founder as he raced around central London looking for on-the-run lunch offerings: “The possibilities are still pretty limited,” he says, adding, “I thought, ‘Enough of the sandwiches!’”

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday

lead_paragraph: 3:15 P.M. (TCM) TO SIR, WITH LOVE (1967) Sidney Poitier stars as Thackeray, an idealistic new teacher in London assigned to a school near the city’s docks, where his Cockney-accented students are ill-mannered and insolent. Christian Roberts plays Denham, the arrogant teenager who incites Thackeray’s latest classroom edict: If the students want to be treated as the adults they are about to become, they must act like adults. “A nice air of gentility suffuses this pretty color film, and Mr. Poitier gives a quaint example of being proper and turning the other cheek,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times about James Clavell’s drama. “And so ‘To Sir, With Love’ comes off as a cozy, good-humored and unbelievable little tale of a teacher getting acquainted with his pupils, implying but never stating that it is nice for the races to live congenially together.” The singer Lulu performs the title song, which became a No. 1 hit.

headline: Contain and Amplify
abstract: We need a new motto for battling extremism in the Middle East. “Fighting terrorism” hasn’t worked so well.
lead_paragraph: The Arab world is a pluralistic region that lacks pluralism — the ability to manage and embrace differences peacefully. As such, the Middle East’s pluralistic character — Sunnis, Shiites, Kurds, Christians, Druze, Alawites, Jews, Copts, Yazidis, Turkmen and an array of tribes — has long been managed by iron fists from above. But after we removed the fists in Iraq and Libya, without putting a new bottom-up order in place, and the people themselves tried to remove the fists in Syria and Yemen, without putting a new live-and-let-live order in place, a horrifying war of all against all has exploded.

headline: Horror
abstract: The season’s horror books include Clive Barker’s “The Scarlet Gospels” and Andrew Pyper’s “The Damned.”
lead_paragraph: Thank God for evil. Without it, horror fiction would be a paltry thing, a tattered coat upon a stick or, perhaps, a ragged, bloody, roughly handled zombie action figure for gullible children. That, of course, is what contemporary horror actually is, most of the time. For some writers, though, the damned soul does sometimes clap its hands and sing. Clive Barker knows the tune, and in his new novel, THE SCARLET GOSPELS (St. Martin’s, $26.99), he belts it out as rapturously as an Irish tenor crooning “Danny Boy.” Better than half the action of “The Scarlet Gospels” takes place in hell, where Barker is clearly very much at home. His descriptions of the underworld often recall the grotesque tableaus of Hieronymus Bosch, but are at other times weirdly hushed and lyrical: “The sky contained neither sun, nor stars, which was predictable enough, but what it did contain was a stone the size of a small planet. The stone reached high above the immense landscape that spread out below, and it threw off fissures like lightning bolts, through which brightness poured. The effect upon the vast panorama was uncanny.” In Barker’s work, beauty and evil are an old married couple, living together comfortably, even serenely, with no secrets left from one another.

headline: Stephen King’s ‘Finders Keepers’
abstract: Laura Lippman reviews Stephen King’s “Finders Keepers,” the second entry in a planned trilogy that began with “Mr. Mercedes.”
lead_paragraph: Literary celebrity sounds like an oxymoron, but it does happen. Selling millions of books isn’t enough; readers have to feel a profound personal connection to the writer. J. K. Rowling is definitely in the club. James Patterson, probably not. Or consider this story, one told to me 20 years ago by a member of the Rock Bottom Remainders, the writer-rock band. (Now that might be an oxymoron.) The band stopped for breakfast at a small-town truck stop before the sun was up. This was pre-smartphone, pre-social media, practically pre-Internet. Yet by the time the band members returned to their tour bus, there were several people lined up, clutching copies of “The Stand,” eager to meet the band’s undisputed rock star, ­Stephen King.

headline: How Do You Define a Gang Member?
abstract: Laws across the country are being used to target young men who fit the description for gang affiliation. But what if they aren’t what they seem?
lead_paragraph: On a rainy day last December, in a courtroom in downtown Modesto, Calif., a 24-year-old white man named Jesse Sebourn, along with five co-defendants, sat accused of second-degree murder. The victim, Erick Gomez, was only 20 when he was shot to death. He was a reputed Norteño gang member who had lived just a few minutes’ drive from the working-class Modesto neighborhood where Sebourn was raised. The police estimate that there are as many as 10,000 gang members in Stanislaus County, where Modesto is, most either Norteños and Sureños, two of California’s most notorious Latino street gangs. The feud between them often turns deadly, and according to Thomas Brennan, the district attorney, this was one such instance: Sebourn and his co-defendants were Sureño gang members hunting for rivals on Valentine’s Day in 2013, when they found Gomez, out on a walk with his girlfriend.

abstract: Having conquered New York with his restaurant Cosme, the Mexican chef is returning to his native country to extend his empire.
lead_paragraph: Having conquered New York, the Mexican chef Enrique Olvera is returning to his native country to extend his empire. Mr. Olvera, who runs the acclaimed Mexico City restaurant Pujol, opened Cosme in the Flatiron neighborhood of New York last year. It’s now one of the hottest restaurants in the city. His next project, to open on June 26, is Manta, the restaurant at the Cape, a Thompson Hotel in Los Cabos on the Baja Peninsula. Mr. Olvera, 39, is also an ambitious, food-centric traveler. During a conversation at Cosme he spoke fondly of the trip he had just taken, which included the Rhine region of Germany, Tokyo and San Sebastián in Spain. “And then back to New York,” he said. “It was two and a half weeks of a lot of eating.” Following are edited excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Matthew Aucoin, Opera’s Great 25-Year-Old Hope
abstract: The composer, conductor, poet, pianist and critic may be the most promising operatic talent in a generation. But can he handle the spotlight?
lead_paragraph: ‘We want to feel like this shape is coming out of the mist, growing legs or something,” Matthew Aucoin said to the woodwinds. They were in a rehearsal hall in Boston, workshopping “Crossing,” Aucoin’s new opera based on Walt Whitman’s Civil War diaries. To the cellos and basses, Aucoin said, “I want this to feel psychotic, like the kick drum in a techno song.” To the whole orchestra, on the subject of the work’s constant shifts in meter and cross-grained tempos — designed to counteract what he regards as the innate Italianness of opera and give “Crossing” the distinctive rhythms of American English — he said: “We want it to splinter. Ninety percent of the time I’m going to be like, ‘It’s not supposed to be together,’ and 10 percent of the time I’ll be like, ‘I messed up.’ ”

headline: Brazilian Soul Food
abstract: For feijoada, desperation begat deliciousness.
lead_paragraph: I thought I knew feijoada, that terrific black hole of meats that is the national dish of Brazil: Sausages and ribs and bellies and other cuts sweating fat into inky beans. A party in a pot. When I was a teenager, I read a recipe for it, my eyes growing wider with each meaty entry in the ingredient list, and I vowed one day to make it. Years later, in culinary school, I did, charging the sweet, musky taste of black beans with the muskier taste of muscle and bone. So I know this dish. But it turns out that it’s even more familiar to me as an American than I thought.

headline: Do I Have to Tell About a Co-Worker’s Rape?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The Ethicists consider when you should reveal someone else’s sexual assault, if at all.
lead_paragraph: My first job out of college was at a major political campaign. Late in the year, an intern told me she had been raped by one of my colleagues and that campaign higher-ups made the problem go away. I’m not sure what that means, but the police weren’t involved, nothing made the news, all the people involved kept their jobs. To my knowledge, this young woman told me and one other colleague. I kept the secret to myself for the last seven years until the other night. I let slip to a journalist friend the very basics of what happened, and now I'm being asked for contacts who can confirm that it happened. The candidate I worked for is running again. I still support the candidate, and I do not want the opponent in office. On the other hand, I am aghast that the organization would cover up such a heinous crime. I’m ashamed of myself for not saying anything at the time. Thinking about it makes me feel physically ill. Do I have any obligation to disclose information to this journalist friend? Would I be doing right for the country? For the victim? I signed a nondisclosure agreement when I went to work for the campaign — would leaking information about this to the press put me in any potential legal trouble? NAME WITHHELD

headline: 1940: Roosevelt Ends Isolationism

headline: 36 Hours in Chapel Hill-Carrboro, N.C.
abstract: These two Southern neighbors offer plenty of options for weekend travelers, from bluegrass under the oaks to a sprawling farmers’ market.

headline: Decline and Schism in Religion
abstract: Why a declining Catholic Church might be more likely to divide.
lead_paragraph: I don’t think I’ve linked to it in this space yet, but regular readers have probably already seen my long piece in the May issue of the Atlantic on Pope Francis’s biography and agenda and what his pontificate might mean for the future of Catholicism. The essay was written a little while before its actual appearance, as long-form magazine pieces tend to be, and there have been all sorts of recent developments around the church and the pontiff that deserve to be discussed afresh. I’m hoping to wade more fully into those issues next month, but first, before it slips too far into the past, I want to talk about the “s” word, schism — which features in my Atlantic essay, though perhaps not quite so prominently as the title suggests — in the context of the Pew religious data that made waves two weeks ago.

lead_paragraph: HAYDN: The Creation Arléen Auger, Philip Langridge, David Thomas, soloists; Simon Rattle, conductor; City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra and Chorus(EMI)Researching an article on Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society led me to several recordings of Haydn’s sparkling, joyous masterpiece. Period-inflected but not period-beholden, and with superb singing, it’s a reminder that although Rattle is unreliable in much of the Mozart-Beethoven-Brahms lineage, his Haydn is beyond reproach. (David Allen)

headline: A Jewelry and Home Wares Designer With a Penchant for White Porcelain
abstract: ARC Objects was born out of Daniela Jacobs’s senior thesis project at Parsons.
lead_paragraph: ARC Objects, a year-old collection of jewelry and household wares in organic silhouettes, was born out of the designer Daniela Jacobs’s senior thesis at Parsons — and many of its pieces, fashioned using small-scale production techniques, were originally intended to be one-offs for Jacobs herself. As an Integrated Design major, Jacobs’s curriculum encouraged alternative approaches to fashion rather than following normative industry practices. For one required class, students had to make an ensemble every week and come to class wearing it. Throughout the course, Jacobs became interested in “considering an outfit as an overall composition — that is, how all the elements go together — rather than clothing design specifically,” she explains. “Jewelry as an ingredient in this mix emerged as something I wanted to explore.”

headline: Review: In ‘Nice Girl,’ a Sudden Ray of Hope in a Dead-End Life
abstract: Diane Davis stars in Melissa Ross’s comedy about a 38-year-old woman burdened by duty and yearning to break out of her routine.
lead_paragraph: Sadness sits lightly on the small shoulders of Josephine, the heroine of “Nice Girl,” a tenderly drawn drama by Melissa Ross about stunted lives in a middle-class suburb of Boston. Josephine, known as Jo and portrayed with fine delicacy by Diane Davis, goes about her daily business without drawing attention to the hole in her heart. She cooks and cares for her mother, Francine, and dutifully performs her secretarial chores at an accounting firm. But in moments of repose and reflection, tears spring to her eyes, and the life she might have led seems to shimmer before her like a mirage.

headline: My Night With a Flash Flood in Houston
abstract: My husband and I went out grocery shopping. Big mistake.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — MANY people picture tumbleweeds rolling across dusty plains when they think of Texas, but Houston is actually more like Calcutta, or Panama; it is very green here, because it rains a lot. On the other hand, it usually doesn’t rain for long; violent storms come and go quickly, with some attendant street flooding because Houston is also very flat. Most of the time, however, a little water is no big deal, though its frequency helps explain why so many Houstonians drive large pickups and S.U.V.s, a fact I tend to recall only when I am stuck in rising water in my Honda Civic.

headline: Hilary Mantel on Taking Her ‘Wolf Hall’ Novels to the Stage
abstract: The author talks about bringing her novels to the stage with the help of the adapter Mike Poulton.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, I started to build a theater inside my head. I wanted to tell — or rather, to show — a story about Henry VIII, the second Tudor king. It would be about his court, his country and three of his six wives: one sad, one serpentine, one sneaky. I would create — or unleash, for they were real people — a heaving mob of courtiers, who listened at doors, who opened each other’s letters. I would turn out their pockets and count their cash. I would look into their houses and their hearts. My focus would be the king’s fixer, the ferociously ambitious Thomas Cromwell.

headline: Review: In ‘San Andreas,’ Dwayne Johnson Rushes to Rescue His Collapsing World
abstract: The big earthquake in this film has its pros and cons: On the one hand, tearing California asunder. On the other, bringing a family together.
lead_paragraph: The big earthquake in “San Andreas” — excuse me, the “seismic swarm event” — has its pros and cons. On one hand, it tears the state of California asunder. On the other, it brings a family together. As is the custom in movies of this kind, destruction is both universal and selective. Two major American cities are pretty much obliterated, catastrophes that presumably cause death on a huge scale. But the half-dozen or so people we care about struggle for survival with what the conventions of genre if not the laws of nature assure us are reasonably good odds.

headline: Science Fiction and Fantasy

lead_paragraph: Often, reading a book that calls to mind your teenage favorites is, at best, an exercise in nostalgia: a slightly uncomfortable reminder of a time when coming-of-age tales seemed to offer magnificent maps of the possible. But under those bright, forthright tales with the air of the mythic about them, you could sometimes find a messier story (courtesy of Angela Carter or Tanith Lee, say) that struck deeper, a story that knew you had already seen the outline of the dark and understood that no easy map was going to work.

headline: Travel
abstract: New books take us on a quest for Atlantis, and to Kilimanjaro, Amsterdam, Vietnam, Scandinavia and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: As you riffle through this spring’s ­rucksack of enticing new travel books, seeking somewhere to go, you might give a thought to going nowhere — that is, in the Greek sense of “nowhere,” to “utopia,” a word Thomas More coined five centuries ago, meaning “no place.” The best “nowhere” destination of all is undoubtedly Atlantis, that utopian underwater city (or subterranean city, given millenniums of earth-crust shimmies) whose rumored existence captivated Plato, around 360 B.C., and whose whereabouts continues to tantalize archaeologists, oceanographers, classicists, geographers and mythomanes. If you’ve traveled to a distant continent or four, it isn’t inconceivable that you’ve already trod upon the legendary land — without knowing it.

keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Depression (Mental)', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting']
abstract: Pregnant women often fear taking the antidepressants they rely on. But not treating their mental illness can be just as dangerous.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of spring in 2013, Mary Guest, a lively, accomplished 37-year-old woman, fell in love, became pregnant and married after a short courtship. At the time, Mary taught children with behavioral problems in Portland, Ore. Her supervisor said that he had rarely seen a teacher with Mary’s gift for intuiting students’ needs. “Mary was a powerful person,” he wrote to her mother, Kristin. “Around Mary, one felt compassion, drive, calmness and support.”

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Dohm Sound Machine
abstract: White noise to fill the dark nights of the human soul.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in 1962, a resourceful insomniac named Jim Buckwalter found himself wide awake once again. Unlike so many of us, though, Buckwalter put his sleeplessness to use, fiddling and tinkering, hoping to find a way to sleep through the night. He installed a motorized fan in a metal dog-food dish and sealed it off with a piece of wood. When he turned the fan on, the contraption produced a pleasant whir that was strangely effective at drowning out other noises. He began to sleep better with the machine on, and his rudimentary device became the prototype for the Dohm “sound conditioner” — one of today’s top-selling white-noise machines.

headline: Drizzy and the New Celebrity Worship
abstract: The fan club has migrated from bedroom walls to smartphone apps that let you text out Drake lyrics or pose with One Direction.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I messaged a friend to ask how her film project was going. She replied, “Always felt like my vision been bigger than the bigger picture.” Then, a few days later, after filling me in on her summer plans, she sent another non sequitur: “I am on a 24-hour Champagne diet!!!” Eventually, she confessed that she was using an app called Drizzy, which lets users send text messages made of snippets of the rapper Drake’s lyrics. Such a service might sound limited in its appeal, but that hasn’t stopped half a million people from downloading the app since it was released in March; right after it was released, so many people were searching and texting Drake lyrics that the server crashed. It’s just one of several dozen apps that exist only to help smartphone users relish in and broadcast their love of Drake.

A deal could be announced as soon as Thursday, one of the people said, but cautioned that talks could collapse. Avago, which specializes in chips for things like fiber-optic lines and lighting, has relatively little overlap with Broadcom’s products, which are used in iPhones and other popular devices. A merger could combine the two companies’ wares to offer comprehensive products to big communications companies, while negotiating cheaper manufacturing costs from the third-party factories where both companies’ chips are made.

headline: Tibetan Food Finds a New Home at Punda

lead_paragraph: Tenzing Tsering grew up as a Tibetan refugee in the northeast Indian state of Meghalaya, whose Sanskrit name means “abode of clouds,” perhaps because more rain falls there — more than 400 inches a year — than anywhere else on earth. His résumé could be a case study in culinary diaspora: He cooked in Moscow and Siberia, at Kathmandu’s only vegetarian hotel and at the high-end Indian restaurant Tulsi in Manhattan, and was the personal chef to the president of the Russian (and predominantly Tibetan Buddhist) republic of Kalmykia.

A holdover from the days when shows began at 8:30 p.m. and ran closer to three hours, the 11 o’clock number has typically referred, in musical comedies, to a song late in the second act that’s designed to wow the audience before the finale, or in musical dramas to a song that feels like an inevitable emotional destination — an end point, if not the show’s ending.

Somehow, it didn’t stop Gispert — whose bling-inflected exhibition “Aqua Regia,” named for the only chemical that can dissolve gold, opens on May 29 at OHWOW Gallery in Los Angeles — from completing his series and shipping it out on time.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker Stars in ‘Heisenberg,’ a Play About the Implications of a Kiss
abstract: In this production at City Center, Ms. Parker plays a woman who alters destiny when she kisses a stranger on the neck in a London train station.

New York theatergoers first fell love with her 25 (can it be?) years ago when she appeared in Craig Lucas’s “Prelude to a Kiss,” in which she set off a fairy-tale transformation by locking lips with an old man. Now she is again demonstrating the miraculous powers of osculation in “Heisenberg,” a play by Simon Stephens, opening on Wednesday. In this latest offering from Mr. Stephens, the intellectually adventurous author of “Punk Rock” and “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” Ms. Parker plays a woman who alters destiny when she kisses a stranger (Denis Arndt) on the neck in a London train station. This Manhattan Theater Club production is staged by Mark Brokaw, who memorably directed Ms. Parker in Paula Vogel’s “How I Learned to Drive.” (Wednesday through June 28, the Studio at Stage II, City Center, 131 West 55th Street; 212-582-1212, nycitycenter.org.)

lead_paragraph: “Sara was beautiful inside and out; her hair was white, and she wore only white clothes,” explains the artist Maira Kalman in the audio guide to her new exhibition, “Sara Berman’s Closet,” a painstaking recreation of her mother’s closet. “Mostly, she was adored.” Berman, who was born in Belarus in 1920, lived in Palestine and the Bronx before relocating in 1982 to Greenwich Village, where she maintained an impeccably organized closet filled with all-white clothing and accessories. The closet was both ordinary and extraordinary, and Kalman wanted to share with others its clarity of vision. “I thought it would be amazing to have people come see the closet and pay 50 cents to a dollar,” Kalman says with a laugh. “It was a crazy idea that made a lot of sense to me.”

lead_paragraph: Here’s fresh evidence that downtown, far downtown, has become a major dining draw: The chef April Bloomfield and the restaurateur Ken Friedman of the Spotted Pig are planning a high-altitude project spanning four of the top floors of 70 Pine Street, a 1931 Art Deco building that was the New York headquarters of the insurance giant AIG.

headline: Celebrating ‘The Goonies’ in Oregon
abstract: Goonies Day, scheduled for next month in Astoria, Ore., will pay tribute to the movie that has been a fan favorite for 30 years.
lead_paragraph: Goonies never say die. But they do enter their 30s.

headline: S.E.C.’s Kara Stein Takes Aim at Deutsche Bank
abstract: Wall Street banks have been able to escape any real penalty for wrongdoing, but for one S.E.C. commissioner, the line has finally been crossed.
lead_paragraph: The recent spate of settlements by big Wall Street banks has underscored their astonishing ability to persuade powerful government officials to let them escape without any real penalty for wrongdoing.

headline: Ever Elusive Sonoma Chardonnay
abstract: Individual wines can be very good, but the overall identity of the appellation is hard to pin down.
lead_paragraph: Good wine has a seemingly endless capacity to surprise. It scorns expectations, dismissing them almost at first sniff and swallow, and turning them inside out by the time the bottle is done. This is one of the most beautiful things about wine, yet one of the most difficult obstacles to overcome.

headline: Review: In ‘Inequality,’ a Respected Scholar Wades Into a Contentious Political Issue
abstract: The new book by Professor Anthony B. Atkinson fails to add much to the increasingly polarized and rhetorical discussions of income inequality.
lead_paragraph: The crisis of “income inequality” has become a cause célèbre. Until recently, the gap between the rich and poor was a topic rarely championed aggressively even by the more liberal wing of the Democratic Party out of fear of being branded a tax-and-spender or class warmonger.

headline: ‘Charlie Parker’s Yardbird’ Ties Jazz and Opera Together in Philadelphia
abstract: Lawrence Brownlee, a rising bel canto star, portrays the jazz and bebop legend in Opera Philadelphia’s world premiere.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — On a recent morning in a rehearsal room behind the Academy of Music here, the tenor Lawrence Brownlee practiced a tricky passage at the piano. The melodic profile of his vocal line zigzagged and spiked like an erratic electrocardiogram, but what gave Mr. Brownlee the most trouble was the text.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Cava
abstract: The best have a beautifully light, feathery, subtle texture that makes them perfect summer-weight sparklers.
lead_paragraph: Cava, like California chardonnay, has suffered from a bad reputation. Not without reason. Millions of bottles of cava, the Catalonian sparkling wine, are sold every year, and much of it is inexpensive and not particularly good. Yet a handful of cava producers, working conscientiously in the vineyards and diligently in the cellar, have demonstrated that it can be among the most distinctive of all sparkling wines.

headline: Google Intensifies Focus on Its Cardboard Virtual Reality Device
abstract: The search giant is introducing several initiatives to highlight its inexpensive virtual reality viewer, including a partnership with GoPro and plans to post VR videos on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has seen the future, and it is littered with cardboard boxes.

headline: A Jewelry Designer Who Sculpts First
abstract: Before launching her own collection, Charlotte Chesnais worked for Balenciaga and with Kenzo and Maiyet, among others.
lead_paragraph: The French jewelry designer Charlotte Chesnais delineates her preliminary ideas in clay, rather than in the form of flat sketches. “I like volumes,” Chesnais says. “The infinity of possibilities, the technical constraints…” One need only look at the lean sculptural wristlets and entwined rings in Chesnais’s first collection for corroboration. She’s quick to cite sculptors as a main source of inspiration — particularly Constantin Brancusi, Anthony Caro, François-Xavier and Claude Lalanne and Lygia Clark. Moreover, she never tires of her home base, Paris, as a storehouse of creativity. “My answer will seem pretty clichéd,” she says, “but a simple ride on my bike fills me with images and interesting silhouettes.”

headline: George Pataki Takes Aim at Hillary Clinton
abstract: George E. Pataki may be the most centrist candidate running for the Republican presidential nomination, but there was nothing moderate about his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton during his announcement speech Thursday.
lead_paragraph: EXETER, N.H. – George E. Pataki may be the most centrist candidate running for the Republican presidential nomination, but there was nothing moderate about his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton during his announcement speech Thursday.

lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — Central bankers and chief finance officials of the world’s wealthiest democracies received a master class in economics Thursday, as they struggled to find ways to make their torpid economies grow faster.

headline: Robert S. Wistrich, Scholar of Anti-Semitism, Dies at 70
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The professor at Hebrew University in Jerusalem was the author or editor of 29 books, including the encyclopedic “Antisemitism: The Longest Hatred.”
lead_paragraph: Robert S. Wistrich, who devoted his four-decade scholarly career to dissecting anti-Semitism, from the biblical Haman, who warned King Ahasuerus of Persia against strangers whose “laws are diverse from all people,” to modern Islamist extremists who deny Israel’s right to exist, died on May 19 in Rome. He was 70.

lead_paragraph: With the entrance of Rick Santorum on Wednesday and George Pataki on Thursday morning, the Republican field has grown to eight candidates — and that’s not including those, like Jeb Bush, who are all but sure to enter the race but just haven’t formally announced yet. As the field grows, it is perhaps easier to keep track of those who aren’t running than those who are. To that end, the following is a partial list of prominent public figures who have not yet declared their candidacy:

The decree comes as Russia faces accusations that it is sending its soldiers clandestinely to fight in Ukraine, an allegation the Kremlin denies.
