But new research by the London art market analysts ArtTactic suggests the pace of growth for high-value contemporary works is slowing.

headline: National Gallery Buys George Caleb Bingham’s ‘The Jolly Flatboatmen’
abstract: The painting has hung in the museum for decades, but was privately owned.
lead_paragraph: In its pre-Instagram, pretelevision, all-but-pre-photography day, George Caleb Bingham’s “The Jolly Flatboatmen” (1846) was a viral image, a joyous genre painting of America’s westward expansion that became wildly popular through mezzotints and lithographs. The work itself, considered one of the most important American paintings of its kind, has hung in the National Gallery of Art in Washington for so many decades — regularly since 1956 — that it long ago came to seem like a part of the museum’s fabric. But the painting was privately owned, for many years by the Pell family and then by the Detroit collector Richard Manoogian, who bought it in 1986 for $6 million, at the time the most ever paid privately or at auction for an American painting. Now, the National Gallery has brought the boatmen fully into the fold, acquiring the painting from the Richard and Jane Manoogian Foundation for an undisclosed price.

headline: Avago Deal Offers Blueprint for Chip Maker Consolidation

lead_paragraph: Avago Technologies is offering what might become a textbook merger case. In its $37 billion acquisition of rival chip maker Broadcom, Avago’s record, industry logic, cash-and-stock mix, premium of just less than 30 percent and synergies all add up. headline: Review: International Contemporary Ensemble Weaves Among Tonalities
abstract: The International Contemporary Ensemble brought “Untempered,” a program full of unusual tunings, to Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Pianists are usually the only musicians who require a helper onstage — the page turner. But during Wednesday’s concert by the International Contemporary Ensemble at the Abrons Arts Center, the guitarist Dan Lippel was aided by an assistant of a different kind: a peg turner. At certain moments during the performance of Larry Polansky’s “Preamble” for two harps and guitar, the multitasking percussionist Nathan Davis reached over to adjust the tuning of Mr. Lippel’s instrument in midplay.

headline: Review: ‘L’Épreuve Villageoise,’ a Rare Gem, at Gould Hall
abstract: This charming French comic opera from the mid-1780s by André Grétry shifts the setting to rural Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Believe it or not, we have Parisian music critics from the mid-1780s to thank for the existence of “L’Épreuve Villageoise” (“The Village Trial”), an utterly charming French comic opera by André Grétry. And a delighted audience at Gould Hall on Wednesday night had Opera Lafayette to thank for presenting a rarity in such a beguilingly simple production, directed by Nick Olcott, with a winning cast.

headline: Review: ‘Russian Modernism’ at Neue Galerie, Figurative Focus With Amorphous Results
abstract: This exhibition is an indispensable first look at Russian modernism’s figurative beginnings.
lead_paragraph: “Russian Modernism: Cross-Currents of German and Russian Art, 1907-1917” at the Neue Galerie is a lively, scattershot exhibition, with numerous paintings of great interest, others of not so much and many by Russian artists most of us have barely heard of.

headline: Review: Simon Denny Sees the Dark Side of Technology at MoMA PS1
abstract: In “The Innovator’s Dilemma,” Mr. Denny takes down irrational exuberance about technology with sardonic verve.
lead_paragraph: In a recent column for The New York Times, the economist Paul Krugman argued that the benefits of the digital technology revolution of the past four decades have been greatly overestimated. The new technologies, he suggested, might be “more fun than fundamental.” Worse, euphoric media chatter about how they’re changing the world for the better “acts as a distraction from more mundane issues,” like putting people to work in usefully productive jobs.

headline: Review: Lilja Birgisdottir, ‘If Your Colors Were Like My Dream’
abstract: In “If Your Colors Were Like My Dream,” the Icelandic artist Lilja Birgisdottir explores color in black and white through two unusual lenses — aura reading and wardrobe color analysis — at Rawson Projects.
lead_paragraph: When artists refer to color theory, they usually mention thinkers like Isaac Newton, Goethe and Josef Albers. The Icelandic artist Lilja Birgisdottir takes a different approach, employing New Age aura reading and wardrobe color analysis. The results in this small, minimal show — her first solo exhibition in New York — are poetic and provocative.

abstract: Mr. Robak focuses on the meshing of high and low; digital and labor-intensive; art and advertising.

headline: John Wesley: ‘Important Works From 1961 to 1966’
abstract: Mr. Wesley descended psychic rabbit holes and returned.
lead_paragraph: The cartoon-based paintings and sculptures that John Wesley produced at the start of his career in the 1960s were widely seen as examples of Pop Art. But the works had a poetic psychology unlike those of most other Pop stylists. An apposite piece in this wonderful show is a table from 1965 with the profiles of Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant painted on its round top and pictures of a standing, sexy woman on each side of its square base. The two parts appear unrelated, but considering that Mr. Wesley was then in the middle years of a marriage to the painter Jo Baer that he once called “a disaster,” a play between civil war and union of the sexes comes to mind.

headline: Review: Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh and Hesam Rahmanian
abstract: The three men’s work is up and down, but their affinity for found objects and images is unmistakable.
lead_paragraph: Satire, gender-bending and exuberantly mixed mediums are among the feats of this art extravaganza, an exhibition that never stops giving. It features the collective and individual efforts of two Iranian brothers — Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh — and their Iranian-American friend Hesam Rahmanian. To unite the array, the artists have painted the gallery’s floor and walls to suggest a Middle Eastern courtyard; they have also festooned white plastic lawn chairs with blue tape and collaborated on videos, assemblages, bulky but often arresting paintings and a functioning fountain that once graced the foyer of their home in Dubai. Adding to the show’s expansive embrace are impressive works from their art collection by six women: Martha Wilson, Etel Adnan, Rose Wylie, Angela Dufresne, A. K. Burns and Hannah Barrett.

headline: Colorado Killer James Holmes’s Notes: Detailed Plans vs. ‘a Whole Lot of Crazy’

Holmes laid out in scrupulous detail before carrying out a shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater. In his own handwriting, he plans a “mass murder spree” and considers theaters and times to attack for “maximum casualties.” He also plots his own psyche with pages of self-diagnosis of what he calls his “broken mind.”

headline: Review: Highway Restaurant & Bar in East Hampton
abstract: Highway Restaurant & Bar, which opened last November, is trying to stake a claim in a spot where several other establishments have failed.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to restaurants, is there such a thing as a doomed location? An address where nothing can survive, no matter the quality of the venture? If so, then 290 Montauk Highway in East Hampton might be such a spot. It’s the restaurant version of a black hole, swallowing no fewer than five establishments in a little over 10 years. Many of these lasted but a single season; others just a few months.

headline: Review: Paloma Herrera and Xiomara Reyes Give Farewell Performances of ‘Giselle’

lead_paragraph: The affection in which the ballerinas Paloma Herrera and Xiomara Reyes have been held was matched on Wednesday by the warmth with which they greeted their colleagues and audiences at their farewell performances. Ms. Herrera danced the matinee of “Giselle” at the Metropolitan Opera House, Ms. Reyes the evening.

lead_paragraph: In recent years, the former Ford showroom on the corner of Forest Street and Locust Avenue in downtown New Canaan has been a revolving door for restaurants. The latest, which opened in November 2013, is Locali Pizza Bar & Kitchen, whose name is Italian slang for “the spot,” and whose food and fair prices suggest it may have found a permanent home.

abstract: By sticking to what he knows best, Mr. Cables and his bandmates managed a kind resistance in their performance.
lead_paragraph: The patience and optimism in the pianist George Cables’s music, from his improvisation down to the spirit of his songwriting, looks like it has prevailed. At 70, he’s led a band at the Village Vanguard only once before, and only last August. This week he’s there for the second time, and played to a full and engaged room on a Wednesday night.

abstract: Plenty of history remains on view along with the contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: WHEN warm weather arrives, artists by the hundreds, including me, venture outside with paint boxes and portable easels. This passion for plein air painting is a phenomenon of recent years that has come to include competitions, workshops and shows in towns, villages and scenic spots like the Eastern Shore of Maryland, which hosts more than 200 artists each July at Plein Air Easton.

headline: A New Jersey Sausage-Eater’s Tour of Europe
abstract: Lopez Sausage Company in Newark specializes in Spanish and Portuguese varieties, Rosario’s in Montclair has Italian salamis and Union Pork Store in Union sells many German kinds.
lead_paragraph: When Herminio Lopes, the owner of Lopes Sausage Company in Newark, got a call from the White House in 1996 with a request for 100 pounds of linguiça and chorizo to be packed for President Bill Clinton, he didn’t believe it — until Secret Service agents showed up two hours later to check the shipment.

abstract: Staten Island’s Marcus Browne (14-0), who will fight Cornelius White at Barclays Center on Friday, wants to earn enough money in boxing so his mother can reopen her restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Doris Jeffrey’s one-bedroom apartment in Staten Island contains, among other things, a Bible in the kitchen and an unusually extensive collection of men’s designer sneakers, size 10, in the corner. It also contains her 24-year-old son, Marcus Browne, a professional boxer.

headline: U.S. Accuses Ex-House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Paying to Hide ‘Misconduct’
abstract: The Illinois politician is accused of lying to the F.B.I. and structuring cash withdrawals to avoid bank reporting requirements.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, has been charged with lying to the F.B.I. and making cash withdrawals from banks in a way that was designed to hide that he was paying $3.5 million to someone for his “misconduct” from years ago, a federal indictment released on Thursday said.

headline: Review: ‘From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola,’ a Bicontinental Couple
abstract: What becomes clear in this show at MoMA is that Stern and Coppola were fellow travelers and photographers, rarely collaborators.
lead_paragraph: Divided into alternating his-and-hers rooms and zigzagging across the Western Hemisphere, it’s hard to tell at first if “From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola” at the Museum of Modern Art is about an artistic couple, 20th-century migration or European modernism and its diaspora. In many ways, it’s about all of these. But despite more than 300 somber, high-contrast vintage black-and-white photographs, films and display cases of ephemera organized in neat rows, the exhibition is a bit of a hot mess.

headline: U.S. Soccer Will Support Blatter Rival in FIFA Election
abstract: Sunil Gulati said he would vote for Prince Ali bin al-Hussein to replace Sepp Blatter as FIFA president, even if it hurts U.S. Soccer’s chances to host another World Cup.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — At dawn on Wednesday, Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, woke with a start, his phone buzzing on the desk of his room at a luxury hotel here. A police raid was quietly going on in the halls around him, and some of Mr. Gulati’s closest professional colleagues — a few of them his friends — were being arrested on various charges related to corruption. The calls and texts did not stop for hours.

headline: Mmuseumm 2 to Open in TriBeCa, All 20 Square Feet of It
abstract: The second Mmuseumm in New York displays what was in the closet of Sara Berman, mother to the artist Maira Kalman and grandmother to Alex Kalman.
lead_paragraph: LOTS of New Yorkers faced with space-starved apartments and carefully assembled obsessions have joked about opening a museum of their stuff. Not many would actually go through with it. Not many are the Kalman family.

headline: Review: ‘Aloha,’ a Hangout Movie With Bradley Cooper and Emma Stone in Hawaii
abstract: Cameron Crowe’s loose and leisurely film can be enjoyed the way you enjoy a catch-up beer with an old friend you don’t have much in common with anymore.
lead_paragraph: Let me say right up front that I will always root for Cameron Crowe. That’s the kind of blunt, sincere, slightly inappropriate statement one of his characters might blurt out at an odd moment, and so much the better. He had me at the “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” script, and I’m probably not the only self-conscious, music-crazed guy of my generation who found possible alternate selves in Mr. Crowe’s alter egos: Lloyd Dobler in “Say Anything,” William Miller in “Almost Famous” and even Jerry Maguire himself.

headline: Be Here Now
abstract: Questions about tardiness and texting, rude rental behavior, unwanted advances and gift-giving.
lead_paragraph: With the rise of texting and mobile communication, I have noticed that people are generally less punctual. I often make plans with friends and receive a text five minutes before the appointed time saying: “Running late. Be there in 15.” When the offending parties finally arrive, they say, “Sorry, I’m late.” I reply, “That’s O.K.” And we move on. But it isn’t O.K. It’s annoying and disrespectful of my time. What can I say without seeming like a jerk?

headline: Breaking Silence, Richard Fuld Speaks on Love, Putin and ‘Rocky’
abstract: In his first public appearance since 2008, Mr. Fuld mused about the economy, the Middle East, love and life, but danced around the downfall of his firm, Lehman Brothers.
lead_paragraph: After nearly seven years of public silence, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, had a lot to say.

headline: Andrew Bujalski Narrates a Scene From ‘Results’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Cobie Smulders.
lead_paragraph: A comedy about personal trainers and the clients who fall for them, the latest film from the Austin independent filmmaker Andrew Bujalski has something his work has previously lacked: well-known actors. This one stars Guy Pearce, Cobie Smulders and Kevin Corrigan. In a recent interview, Mr. Bujalski, whose last film was the more experimental “Computer Chess,” talked about working with his cast and in this video, discussed this early scene, introducing the intense Kat (Ms. Smulders) as she spots one of her clients eating a cupcake and decides to chase her down.

headline: Review: ‘Results’ Tracks Exertions in Matters of the Cardio
abstract: In Andrew Bujalski’s romantic comedy, a personal trainer and her boss find their badinage interrupted by an out-of-shape heir.
lead_paragraph: “Results” is something of a paradox: a straightforward movie that reveals itself by stealth and indirection. Tracing the awkward interactions of three Austin, Tex., residents — a personal trainer, her boss and an out-of-shape client — the film seems to wander amiably, almost aimlessly through daily routines and low-key surprises. Only toward the end do you realize that the characters have been arranged into a pleasing and familiar romantic-comedy triangle and that you’ve been watching a beautifully played game of underhand slow-pitch screwball.

lead_paragraph: The pursuit began around 11:30 p.m. Wednesday, with an attempted traffic stop in the Bronx, executed by an unlikely set of enforcers: New York State Court officers, who are more practiced in shepherding defendants to their hearings than in patrolling the nighttime streets.

headline: Review: ‘Gemma Bovery,’ a Modern Sex Comedy With a Nod to Flaubert
abstract: Anne Fontaine’s film is about the midlife crisis of a man confronted with yearnings he has compartmentalized so effectively they are barely noticeable.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect “Gemma Bovery,” Anne Fontaine’s contemporary riff on Flaubert, to shed any new light on that author’s most famous character. This version of the 19th-century masterwork “Madame Bovary,” adapted from a graphic novel by Posy Simmonds, is only a platform for a frothy modern sex comedy, much of which takes place in the prurient imagination of its narrator and central character, Martin Joubert (Fabrice Luchini).

headline: Rare Early Proof of ‘The Bell Jar’ to Be Auctioned
abstract: A second-hand copy of the 1963 novel, written under the pseudonym Victoria Lucas, sat on a shelf for three decades. Now it’s expected to sell for a few thousand dollars.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 1985, a college student bought a second-hand copy of a novel by Victoria Lucas in a Winchester bookshop. It was called “The Bell Jar,” and for 30 years, it has sat on a shelf. Recently its owner, known only by her blogging name, Lucy WithaY, searched online for the name and the title. The book turned out to be a rare 1962 proof of Sylvia Plath’s famous — and only — novel, published under a pseudonym in 1963, shortly before the writer committed suicide at the age of 30.

headline: Massachusetts: Sentencing Date Is Set for Boston Bomber
abstract: The judge in the Boston Marathon bombing case set June 24 as the date he will formally sentence Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber, to death.
lead_paragraph: The judge in the Boston Marathon bombing case on Thursday set June 24 as the date he will formally sentence Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber, to death. A jury on May 15 recommended he be put to death; the official sentencing next month, by Judge George A. O’Toole Jr. of Federal District Court, will complete that phase of the process. But defense appeals are likely to extend the case for years, and there is no telling when or even whether an execution might take place. Twenty survivors and relatives of victims of the bombing are expected to speak at the sentencing hearing. Mr. Tsarnaev, 21, may also speak if he wishes; he did not testify during his trial.

headline: Kentucky: Outcome Unchanged in Governor Race
abstract: A statewide recanvass did not change the outcome of the closely fought election for the Republican nomination for governor, regulators said.
lead_paragraph: A statewide recanvass on Thursday did not change the outcome of the closely fought election for the Republican nomination for governor, regulators said. The state agriculture commissioner, James R. Comer, requested the recanvass after preliminary results from the May 19 primary election showed him trailing Matt Bevin, a businessman from Louisville, by 83 votes. But after the procedure, which differs from a recount, Secretary of State Alison Lundergan Grimes announced that the margin between the two men had not changed. Mr. Comer must decide by Friday whether to seek a recount through the courts. His campaign said he would announce on Friday afternoon “the next steps he will take in this race.”

headline: Nebraska: Challenge to Repeal of the Death Penalty
abstract: Doug Peterson, the attorney general of Nebraska, said he would challenge the constitutionality of the state’s new law replacing the death penalty with life imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: Doug Peterson, the attorney general of Nebraska, said he would challenge the constitutionality of the state’s new law repealing the death penalty. The bill, which was passed on Wednesday after lawmakers overrode a veto from Gov. Pete Ricketts, replaces the death penalty with life imprisonment in Nebraska. But Mr. Peterson, who has been a vocal opponent of the bill, said on Thursday that he believed the law was unconstitutional because it effectively changed the sentences of the 10 inmates on death row. One senator who opposed repeal of the death penalty has begun another effort to fight the new law and is trying to collect at least 115,000 signatures from registered voters, which would force a voter referendum in 2016.

headline: Anthony C. Yu, Translator of the Saga of a Chinese Pilgrimage, Dies at 76
abstract: Professor Yu’s four-volume tale of a monk and his entourage, including the Monkey King, is based on a work from 1592.
lead_paragraph: The epic saga of a heroic Chinese monk’s pilgrimage to India with a Monkey King, a pig spirit and other disciples in a search for sacred Buddhist scriptures was first published in 1592. The novelistic quest lasted 16 years.

headline: Sepp Blatter’s Embattled FIFA Presidency
abstract: As Mr. Blatter emerges from a week of scandal with a fifth term as the head of soccer’s world governing body, a look back at his troubled tenure.
lead_paragraph: As Mr. Blatter emerges from a week of scandal with a fifth term as the head of soccer’s world governing body, a look back at his troubled tenure.

abstract: The prolific author is starting his own imprint, Jimmy Patterson, to publish middle grade and young adult fiction.
lead_paragraph: The novelist James Patterson is so prolific that his annual output rivals that of many small publishing houses. Last year, with help from his stable of co-authors, he published 16 new novels, and sold around 20 million copies of his books.

headline: Greenleaf Music Label Turns 10 With a Show at SubCulture
abstract: The trumpeter Dave Douglas, chief executive of Greanleaf Music, hosted a 10th-anniversary celebration for his label featuring three strong bands.
lead_paragraph: Just after he was introduced on Wednesday night as “the C.E.O. of Greenleaf Music,” Dave Douglas hopped onstage at SubCulture in Manhattan and, with a chuckle, tried to dial back any hint of grandiosity. But Mr. Douglas — the irrepressible trumpeter-composer-bandleader, and an organizer of people and ideas — wasn’t undercutting the point of the evening, a 10th-anniversary celebration for his record label. If anything, he seemed proud, and a bit protective, of the label’s tenacious modesty of scale.

abstract: At least 20 companies have removed their ads from the show after a report that one of its stars had been investigated on suspicion of molesting underage girls.
lead_paragraph: At least 20 companies have distanced themselves from TLC’s popular reality show “19 Kids and Counting” since the cable network announced last week that it was withdrawing the program from its lineup. The network’s decision — and the subsequent move by brands to remove ads — came after a report that one of the show’s stars, Josh Duggar, had been investigated on suspicion of molesting several underage girls.

headline: World Cup Sponsors’ Situation Is Complex

lead_paragraph: World Cup sponsors demonstrated various levels of caution in their responses this week to the United States Justice Department’s indictment of nine FIFA officials on corruption charges.

headline: Review: ‘Heaven Knows What’ Dramatizes a Young Junkie’s Life
abstract: Directed by Josh and Benny Safdie, “Heaven Knows What” chronicles an addict and her pursuits on the streets of New York.
lead_paragraph: The characters of the junkie chronicle “Heaven Knows What” lead their lives in the open, which is to say on the streets of New York. Whenever a couple of them are arguing — which is frequently — you glimpse passers-by steering their way around the commotion with the practiced resolve of New Yorkers trying to mind their own business. At the very least, the directors, Josh and Benny Safdie, have created a small, beautiful classic of street theater by rendering these public disputes within a vibrant Manhattan setting through ingenious photography.

headline: Reality Checks in Debate Over Surveillance Laws
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Terrorism']
abstract: There is little evidence in the history of the expiring Patriot Act powers to bolster the arguments that either supporters or opponents are making.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate moves closer to a Sunday night showdown over whether it will let Patriot Act surveillance powers expire on Monday, supporters and critics of how the government has used those authorities have been using increasingly alarming language.

headline: Gigi Jordan Receives 18-Year Sentence for Killing Her Son
abstract: Ms. Jordan poisoned her 8-year-old son in a Manhattan hotel room and claimed that she did it to prevent the boy from being sexually tortured by his father.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy businesswoman who poisoned her son in a Manhattan hotel room was sentenced to 18 years in state prison for manslaughter on Thursday, ending a bizarre case that turned on her claim that she murdered her child to prevent him from being sexually tortured.

headline: Morris Wilkins, Who Lured Honeymooners to Poconos, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Wilkins marketed his once nondescript northeastern Pennsylvania hotel as a libidinous Land of Love.
lead_paragraph: During the post-World War II marriage boom, when gas shortages persuaded honeymooners from New York and Philadelphia to stay closer to home, hoteliers began luring newlyweds to the Poconos instead of to Niagara Falls.

headline: Michael King, Builder of a TV Empire, Dies at 67
abstract: With his brother Roger, Mr. King built King World Productions into a huge syndicator of some of television’s best known shows, including “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” “Wheel of Fortune” and “Jeopardy!”
lead_paragraph: Michael King, who with his brother transformed King World Productions, a modest company they inherited from their father, into a syndicator of television megahits like “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” “Jeopardy!” and “Wheel of Fortune,” died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: Review: In ‘I Believe in Unicorns,’ a Princess Meets Her Punk Prince Charming
abstract: The director Leah Meyerhoff brings her life story to the screen in this work filmed in her childhood home in Oakland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Like its heroine, “I Believe in Unicorns” is faltering and undeveloped, but with a wiry core that belies its apparent uncertainty. Stretched to 80 minutes, the story (by the director Leah Meyerhoff) almost breaks; that it holds together without compromising its simplicity or emotional authenticity only proves that, contrary to the  maxim, you don’t need a gun if you’ve got the right girl.

headline: Obama, in Miami, Comments on Extreme Weather, Terrorism, Cuban-Americans and Basketball
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Cuban-Americans', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s overnight visit included a Twitter chat and visits to a Cuban-American church and with the family of Stephen Sotloff, a journalist killed by ISIS.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The visit lasted less than 24 hours, but President Obama managed to use a stop in South Florida to maximum advantage as he touched on some of the highest priorities of an administration heading into its final stages.

headline: Review: In ‘Tu Dors Nicole,’ the Daughter Loafs While the Parents Are Away
abstract: This third feature from Stéphane Lafleur follows a woman who takes what she wants on the job at a secondhand store and generally lives an impulsive life.
lead_paragraph: “Tu Dors Nicole,” the third feature by the Québécois director Stéphane Lafleur, is a movie about wasting time. Is there really such a thing? Or is all of life what might be called “a learning experience” with interludes in which nothing seems to be happening, while a storm brews.

headline: Chimpanzees in Liberia, Used in New York Blood Center Research, Face Uncertain Future
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Research', 'Blood']
abstract: After years of using a colony of chimpanzees in Liberia for biomedical research, the New York Blood Center has withdrawn funding for them, prompting outrage from animal welfare groups.
lead_paragraph: After about 30 years of using a colony of chimpanzees in Liberia for biomedical research, which ended 10 years ago, the New York Blood Center has now withdrawn all funding for them, prompting animal welfare groups to urge the center to reconsider its decision.

headline: ISIS Alternates Stick and Carrot to Control Palmyra
abstract: The militants have alternated between terrorizing residents and courting them in their takeover of the ancient Syrian city.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hours after they swept into the Syrian city of Palmyra last week, Islamic State militants carried out scores of summary executions, leaving the bodies of victims — including dozens of government soldiers — in the streets.

headline: U.N. Resolves to Combat Plundering of Antiquities by ISIS
abstract: A resolution adopted unanimously by the General Assembly amounted to the broadest international condemnation so far to the cultural destruction wrought by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly frustrated by the Islamic State’s brazen pillaging and trafficking of artifacts in the Middle East, all members of the United Nations agreed on Thursday to take new steps intended to thwart and prosecute antiquities smugglers, ensure the return of plundered ancient treasures and counter what diplomats described as “cultural cleansing,” a new tactic of war to spread hatred and erase the heritage of civilizations.

headline: Review: ‘The True Cost’ Investigates High Price of Fashion Bargains
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: This documentary by Andrew Morgan details the exploitation of workers in garment factories and cotton fields around the world.
lead_paragraph: A distressing overview of the consequences of our addiction to fast fashion, “The True Cost” might suggest another exposé of corporate greed versus environmental well-being. That is certainly in evidence, but under the gentle, humane investigations of its director, Andrew Morgan, what emerges most strongly is a portrait of exploitation that ought to make us more nauseated than elated over those $20 jeans.

headline: Yemen: Amnesty Says Antiaircraft Fire by Houthis Has Killed Many Civilians
abstract: Antiaircraft munitions fired by Yemen’s Houthi rebels have killed or maimed scores of civilians in Sana.
lead_paragraph: Antiaircraft munitions fired by Yemen’s Houthi rebels have killed or maimed scores of civilians in Sana, the capital, Amnesty International said in a report issued on Thursday. Doctors and residents told the group that the munitions were the leading cause of casualties in the city, adding to the many dangers that have confronted civilians during the conflict between the Houthis and their allies and a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia. Airstrikes by the Saudi coalition that struck weapons depots in residential areas in the capital have also killed and wounded residents, the group found. In two recent airstrikes, residents told Amnesty that the coalition had provided no warning beforehand.

headline: Syria: Insurgent Coalition Pushes Assad’s Forces From a Stronghold
abstract: Insurgents seized one of the last Syrian government positions in the northern province of Idlib on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Insurgents seized one of the last Syrian government positions in the northern province of Idlib on Thursday night, in the latest in a series of recent gains by a newly effective opposition coalition that includes the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda as well as other Islamist factions and a few nationalist groups backed by the United States. The government forces’ quick retreat from the small city of Ariha left insurgents celebrating in the streets and made it appear increasingly unlikely that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad would retake the provincial capital, also called Idlib, as officials vowed to do when it fell to insurgents two months ago. The government is also facing advances by the Islamic State, which seized the central desert city of Palmyra last week. Taking Ariha puts the insurgents a step closer to the government’s coastal strongholds and the plains around the city of Hama.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA: ANDRIS NELSONS’ INAUGURAL CONCERT Mr. Nelsons (above), the Latvian conductor, makes his debut as the ensemble’s music director in this program of Wagnerian and Italian verismo repertory, featuring his wife, the soprano Kristine Opolais, and the German tenor Jonas Kaufmann. Among the works in this “Great Performances” presentation, taped in September, are Wagner’s “Tannhäuser” overture, which Mr. Nelsons has credited with inspiring him at the age of 5 to pursue a life in music. “As he walked to the podium on Saturday he was greeted with a long, rousing ovation; many people were on their feet,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times in his review of that concert. “But the best indication that Mr. Nelsons was a strong choice for the job was the superb playing of the musicians of this great orchestra, especially in, of all things, Respighi’s familiar 1924 symphonic poem, ‘Pines of Rome.’ If you are going to conclude an important inaugural concert with a shameless showpiece, well, picking this skillfully written, dazzlingly orchestrated and colorful score was the way to go. Mr. Nelsons drew a glittering, textured and cinematic account of that 20-minute work from his players.”

abstract: Pursuing an artistic career, and feeling the effects of geopolitics, in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: When I was young, my mother and father would say, “He will become a doctor, he’ll be something.” But my passion was art. In school, in my village near the Afghan border, I studied through matric, finishing 10th grade, and I made quite a name for myself in class with my drawing skills. But I would often skip school, and when I left school for good, this passion for painting grew. I worked as an apprentice to a painter in Quetta for almost three years. I used to do just calligraphy, but then I developed an interest in painting trucks.

headline: How to Ride a Bull
abstract: Develop your core. Hit the ground running.
lead_paragraph: “Superstition is not going to help you,” Adriano Moraes says. When he started riding bulls professionally in the United States in 1993, he found American cowboys to be oddly obsessed with bad luck — they didn’t put their hats on beds, accept $50 bills or eat chicken before getting on a bull. Instead, Moraes says, develop your core strength. He did 2,000 crunches a day during the 15 years he competed with the Professional Bull Riders, the international organization known as the P.B.R., eventually becoming its first three-time world champion. Bulls can weigh up to 2,200 pounds and are bred for their explosive leaps and midair spins. “Dance with the bull,” advises Moraes, 45, who retired in 2008 and now scouts talent (bovine and human) and runs events for the P.B.R. in his native Brazil. “Never try to fight; if you fight, you always lose.” Stay up near the animal’s shoulders, away from its high-kicking hindquarters.

headline: In Varazdin, a Thriving Arts Scene Emerges

Situated on the top floor of a two-story 18th-century building that’s surrounded by cobblestone streets, the flat overlooks a small garden where more than 50 open umbrellas in bright shades rest on thin metal crisscrossing wires, forming a canopy, and the mishmash of seating includes a white bathtub that the owner, Martin Kaminic, cut in half and fashioned into a bench.

abstract: Fuld Breaks His Silence | Battle Behind the Scenes at S.E.C. | Broadcom Purchase Underscores Avago’s Ambitions | S. Parker Gilbert, Morgan Stanley Leader, Dies at 81
lead_paragraph: FULD BREAKS HIS SILENCE | In his first public appearance since the financial crisis, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, used his speech at the Marcum MicroCap Conference in New York to touch on a wide range of topics like the Islamic State and the American economy, quoted from the movie “Rocky” and ruminated on the meaning of life. “But while Mr. Fuld, known as ‘the Gorilla’ of Wall Street for his brusque style, was eager to share his views about the world, he assiduously avoided talking about his role in the largest bankruptcy in United States history,”  David Gelles writes in DealBook. Instead, Mr. Fuld offered his views on personal topics and made frequent references to his resilience. One example: “What did Rocky say? ‘It’s not how hard you hit but whether you get up after you’ve been knocked down.’ I love Rocky.”

lead_paragraph: Though he’s best known for playing guitar and percussion with the minimalist rock trio the xx, Jamie xx — born Jamie Smith in London — grew up steeped in dance music and was a D.J. in bars and clubs at the same time the band was taking off. Now, with “In Colour,” his first solo album, Mr. Smith, 26, is tapping a broader tonal range than the xx’s severe palette allows. “On my own, I become very self-indulgent and go off on tangents,” he said.

headline: ‘My Paris Dream,’ by Kate Betts
abstract: A fashion editor recalls her time as a young journalist in Paris in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: We’ll always have Paris. And as long as there are Americans who long to reinvent themselves, we’ll always have books about Paris — books that still mention Hemingway and ­pigeon-gray rooftops, lovers in cafes and swirling Gauloise smoke. If there’s anything new to be said about the city, or a surprising new way in which to describe it, it’s as rare as a helpful French bureaucrat — at least in the latest batch of books in which Paris is a main character. Kate Betts, at least, got what she went there for. And now, almost 30 years later, she shares her coming-of-age in a self-assured book that should be given to every college senior with a Doisneau poster (or Chanel ad) on her wall.

headline: Buzzing in Midtown
abstract: At BookExpo America, the annual trade convention, publishing-industry insiders make the case for forthcoming books.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, publishing-industry insiders and readers of all stripes will be in New York for BookExpo America, the annual trade convention. Jonathan Franzen was scheduled to kick off this year’s event, discussing his forthcoming novel, “Purity,” with the literary critic Laura Miller. Franzen represents an old-fashioned bookish draw, but much of the conference could be mistaken for a TV upfront, with new books peddled by big names like Mindy Kaling, B. J. Novak, Aziz Ansari, Nick Offerman and David Duchovny.

headline: Letters: ‘One Nation Under God’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Kevin M. Kruse’s “One Nation Under God,” David McCullough’s “The Wright Brothers” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘One Nation Under God’

headline: Gardening
abstract: “Highgrove: An English Country Garden,” “A Buzz in the Meadow” and more.
lead_paragraph: Gardeners have active fantasy lives to keep us going despite constant setbacks. Fifty shades of green don’t begin to capture what’s looping through our brains. Lucky is the gardener who can bring those fantasies to life — to the delight or comfort of family and strangers alike. In Charleston, S.C., David Rawle has created a beautifully tranquil public garden dedicated to the memory of his mother, Theodora, an avid gardener. Theodora Park features palmetto trees and camellias; a ceramic artist has created colorful tiles for a fountain. On the other coast, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, is sinking five billion shades of green into an Eden for his company’s new California campus. Perhaps no one will ever be tempted to leave.

headline: U.S. Removes Cuba From State-Sponsored Terrorism List
abstract: The decision to remove Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism is a crucial step in normalizing ties between Washington and Havana.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday removed Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism, a crucial step in President Obama’s push to normalize ties between Washington and Havana.

headline: ‘Emma: A Modern Retelling,’ by Alexander McCall Smith
abstract: In Alexander McCall Smith’s updating of Jane Austen’s “Emma,” the heroine is a budding interior decorator.
lead_paragraph: As bicentenaries come and go, so do adaptations of Jane Austen. “Pride and Prejudice” (1813) begat “Pride and Prejudice and Kitties” (2013), not to be confused with “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” (2009). In 2011, two centuries after Austen broke into print, the Austen Project commissioned modern retellings of her six novels.

headline: ‘Re Jane,’ by Patricia Park
abstract: Patricia Park retells “Jane Eyre” from the perspective of a contemporary half-Korean young woman in New York City.
lead_paragraph: “You act like an orphan!” The ­Korean-American writer Patricia Park was always struck by the strange rebuke her mother hurled at her in limited English whenever she was bad. In an interview with her publisher, Park said that when she read Charlotte Brontë’s classic 19th-century orphan tale, “Jane Eyre,” it came together: Whether 170 years ago in England or 60 years ago during the Korean War when her mother was growing up, parentless children who hadn’t gotten “a good family education,” as her own family put it, were scorned, the lowest kind of misfit.

headline: ‘American Epics: Thomas Hart Benton and Hollywood’
abstract: Thomas Hart Benton was part of the first generation of American artists to let the influence of movies run through their work.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Hart Benton was already 14 in 1903, when “The Great Train Robbery” flickered onto screens, but he was still impressionable enough to become part of the first generation of American artists to let the influence of movies run through their work. In Benton’s case, “run” is almost literal; everything in the fluid, vivid murals that made him famous seems to be pulsing or coursing. His pictures were, in a sense, motion pictures, which may be why, in 1937, Life magazine commissioned him to go to Hollywood to create a “movie mural” that would bring its readers closer to the heart of the still-newish mystery of how films were created.

headline: ‘Burning Down George Orwell’s House,’ by Andrew Ervin
abstract: In this debut novel, a burnt-out advertising worker in Chicago moves to an isle in Scotland to refresh his soul.
lead_paragraph: In this debut novel, Andrew Ervin works familiar ground: the burnt-out protagonist who gives up a comfortable but spiritually toxic life in order to refresh his soul and seek redemption in a far-off — or, in current parlance, “off the grid” — place, which according to the formula will inevitably be populated by locals for whom the appropriate collective noun is “menagerie.” One approaches the scenario braced for cliché. But Ervin pulls it off, and then some. “Burning Down George Orwell’s House” is a sweet book full of delights. Since many of its best passages are rhapsodies on single malt whiskies, one is tempted to call it a wee bonny dram of a tale.

headline: California’s ‘Hellhole’ for Traffic Violators
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown has proposed an amnesty program for drivers caught in a spiraling accumulation of court costs.
lead_paragraph: The harsh lessons of the confrontation between the citizens and police of Ferguson, Missouri, last year are registering nationwide — notably in California where Gov. Jerry Brown is proposing amnesty for poor people buried under the escalating costs of unpaid traffic fines. “It’s a hellhole of desperation,” Mr. Brown said, underlining charges that the state has been exploiting low-income and minority residents caught in a spiraling accumulation of court costs that they can’t pay.

headline: ‘The Brethren,’ by Robert Merle
abstract: “The Brethren," published in France in 1977, is the first of 13 volumes detailing more than a century of French history and known as “Fortunes of France.”
lead_paragraph: Historical fiction plays a delicate trick, honoring the factual record even as it embroiders it. Where to adjust the register without straying beyond the fixed range? One of the many delights vouchsafed by Robert ­Merle’s “The Brethren” is the sense that the author is astonished that what he’s writing about actually happened — that 450 years ago France consisted of a batch of tenuously ­allied provinces, with Catholics and Protestants locked in holy and civil war; that 14-year-old ­nobles were joined in ­marriage; that kings died in jousting ­matches; that Gypsies haunted untamed forests; that castles were ­defended with blunderbusses and cutlasses. Where Merle teases this history is through his invented Huguenot family, headed by two Jeans, the exemplary Baron Jean de Siorac and his austere best friend, Jean de Sauveterre — the “brethren” of the novel’s title, united by war and joint masters of Mespech, a castle in ­southern Périgord.

headline: Mutual Fund Giants Vote to Keep the Insiders In
abstract: Fidelity and Vanguard, the fund behemoths, could swing a good number of shareholder votes to expand shareholder rights. So, why don’t they?
lead_paragraph: Are Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, two of the nation’s largest mutual fund companies, the skunks at the proxy access party?

headline: Y.A. Crossover
abstract: New books by Margo Rabb, David Almond, Justine Larbalestier and Nova Ren Suma.
lead_paragraph: KISSING IN AMERICA

headline: ‘Daughters of the Samurai,’ by Janice P. Nimura
abstract: The daughters of samurai families were “volunteered” for a decade of study abroad.
lead_paragraph: For college students today, junior year is considered the optimal occasion for study abroad, a time when they have “transitioned” from the comforts of home, declared a major and acquired a smattering of a foreign language. For three Japanese girls in 1871 — Sutematsu Yamakawa, age 11; Shige Nagai, 10; and Ume Tsuda, 6 — study abroad began much earlier and lasted for 10 long years. They were transformed in the process, as was the country they left behind. “Though they were, each of them, purebred daughters of the samurai,” Janice P. Nimura remarks in this beautifully written book, “they became hybrid by nurture,” at home neither in their adopted country nor in their homeland.

headline: ‘Oh! You Pretty Things,’ by Shanna Mahin
abstract: The heroine of this first novel set in Los Angeles is preoccupied with fame and its discontents.
lead_paragraph: Recent transplants to Los Angeles are often mocked for their jejune view of the city. “Why, nobody walks here . . . or eats bread . . . and yikes, Harry, there’s another set of breast implants!”

headline: ‘Beale Street Dynasty’ and ‘Dreams to Remember’
abstract: “Beale Street Dynasty” adds a fascinating chapter to civil rights history, and “Dreams to Remember” evokes the fire of Otis Redding and his Memphis label, Stax Records.
lead_paragraph: In 1917, the composer W. C. Handy titillated the nation with “Beale Street Blues,” his song about a true-life Sodom and Gomorrah in downtown Memphis. “If Beale Street could talk, if Beale Street could talk,” he wrote, “married men would have to take their beds and walk.” Fats Waller, Lena Horne and the former Beale resident Alberta Hunter all went on to sing it, but probably few people today know about that post-Civil War nirvana for liberated slaves. On Beale Street, freedom ran raucously, dangerously amok. Races cohabited and brothels thrived; heated games of dice-rolling often ended with the flash of switchblades. Cocaine was sold over the counter. The anarchy was set to a soundtrack of early jazz, much of it provided by Handy, the bandleader and composer of “St. Louis Blues.”

headline: ‘Gironimo!’ and ‘Lanterne Rouge’
abstract: One writer retraces the 1914 route of the Tour of Italy, and another researches the men who have finished last in the Tour de France.
lead_paragraph: There are many sensible reasons the British travel writer and humorist Tim Moore cycled the 1914 route of the Giro d’Italia (the Tour of Italy) wearing antique woolen biking shorts held up by a safety pin, on a bike with wine corks for brakes, wooden rims, no gears and 100-year-old parts.

headline: ‘The Sculptor,’ by Scott McCloud
abstract: In Scott McCloud’s first graphic novel since 1998, a sculptor trades his life for his art.
lead_paragraph: If you want to read ambitious comics and graphic novels, you have many choices, but if you want to learn how to read them, you probably have to start with Scott McCloud. The writer and artist first got noticed for a teenage superhero series, “Zot!” (1984-91), then broke through with “Understanding Comics” (1993), an exegesis, in comics form, of comics form. McCloud drew himself as a friendly, bespectacled guide, demonstrating why “cartoony,” stylized faces (as in “Peanuts”) help us identify with characters; and how comics can tell many sorts of stories, whether or not there are superpowers or family traumas involved. “Reinventing Comics” (2000) predicted broad uses for digital platforms; “Making Comics” (2006) showed potential creators how to use the pen-and-ink and electronic tools we have.

headline: Physical Evidence Scant, Focus Is on Statements in Kayak Case
abstract: Legal experts say the incriminating statements from Angelika Graswald, who is accused of killing her fiancé, are both the case’s greatest strength and its weakness.
lead_paragraph: Until last weekend, the biggest challenge facing prosecutors in the murder case involving two kayakers was the missing body. That was resolved Saturday, however, when the police found the body of Vincent Viafore, 46, in the middle of the Hudson River, just north of the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
abstract: This week, Judy Blume talks about her new novel; Liesl Schillinger rounds up new travel books; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vanessa Grigoriadis discusses Wednesday Martin’s memoir, “Primates of Park Avenue”; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Judy Blume talks about her new novel; Liesl Schillinger rounds up new travel books; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vanessa Grigoriadis discusses Wednesday Martin’s memoir, “Primates of Park Avenue”; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
abstract: This week, Judy Blume, Liesl Schillinger and Vanessa Grigoriadis.
lead_paragraph: This week, Judy Blume, Liesl Schillinger and Vanessa Grigoriadis.

headline: ‘Church of Marvels,’ by Leslie Parry
abstract: This debut novel tells closely linked stories set in New York City in the 1890s.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Parry’s debut novel opens with a strange discovery: Sylvan, an isolated young man living on the Lower East Side of 1890s Manhattan, finds an infant abandoned in a privy. Sylvan is a night-soiler — if you’re unfamiliar with the profession, imagine the worst possible sanitation job that a person could hold before the age of indoor plumbing — and until he finds the baby, he’s had very little in the way of direction or hope. The family who raised him have all died of TB.

headline: ‘Bitter Bronx’ and ‘Just Kids From the Bronx’
abstract: An interlocking collection of short fiction and a sprawling series of reminiscences, both set in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn, Brooklyn, Brooklyn. It’s all anyone talks about. From a punch line to a symbol of cool urban affluence with a literary bent, it’s had a niche in the national psyche for decades. The other boroughs look on, some more annoyed than others.

headline: ‘The Last Bookaneer,’ by Matthew Pearl
abstract: Matthew Pearl’s fifth novel conceives of 19th-century literary pirates who published manuscripts and books without their authors’ permission as swashbuckling criminals.
lead_paragraph: You will not find ‘bookaneer’ in any dictionary,” says the narrator of Matthew Pearl’s fifth novel, “The Last Bookaneer,” and he’s right. In his afterword, Pearl does claim to have encountered this unfortunate pun in an 1837 text by the poet Thomas Hood, but if so it never managed to appear in the Oxford English Dictionary. Either the editors of the O.E.D. are slipping or Matthew Pearl is having us on.

headline: Gary Clement’s ‘Swimming, Swimming,’ and More
abstract: A place for playing with friends, freeing the imagination and, of course, swimming: Three picture books celebrate the pool.
lead_paragraph: Swimming pools loom giant in the imaginations of children. They’re symbols of summer, and of vacations. The big ones can be vast and terrifying. The kiddie ones can be conquered. If we learn to swim, most of us in America first learn how in pools.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Dan Santat was stunned when his picture book “The Adventures of Beekle” won the Caldecott Medal in February: “I crumpled to the floor and started crying.”
lead_paragraph: Feeling Lucky: To anybody who’s known a toddler, it might seem counterintuitive that the children’s picture book list at the moment is so stable and calm — seven of this week’s 10 entries have been on the list for six months or longer. (In some cases much longer: Hervé Tullet’s “Press Here” is coming up on four years.) That means that Dan Santat’s sweet story “The Adventures of Beekle,” about an imaginary friend in search of his human, is a relative newcomer: It’s No. 7 after 13 weeks. Santat’s book got a bump when it won the Caldecott Medal in February, setting it apart as last year’s “most distinguished American picture book.” The award caught Santat off guard, he told Publishers Weekly at the time. “I never really thought that I had a chance,” he said. “When I got the call, I hate to admit it, but I started crying. I crumpled to the floor and started crying.” Santat has illustrated other people’s books for a long time (he previously hit the list as the illustrator for Ahmet Zappa’s “Because I’m Your Dad,” in 2013), but “The Adventures of Beekle” is just the second story he’s written on his own. He almost chose not to, he told Publishers Weekly: Five years ago he had a chance to join Google, drawing doodles for the home page. “Should I take this job and make money to support my family,” he asked himself, “or should I chase my dream?” Turning Google down, he continued, “motivated me to use the other side of my creative brain, to write more.” It paid off. Among the highlights of Santat’s February, according to his Tumblr account, was outselling “50 Shades of Grey” (“for a brief moment”) and receiving the following Valentine’s “newsletter” from his 9-year-old son, Alek: “Dan Santat has just won his amazing Caldecott award. Many people think that Dan is known around the world.”

headline: For Cruise Visitors, an On-Shore Taste of Alaska’s Bounty
abstract: Until recently, Juneau didn’t have much to offer the discerning diner. But that has changed with fresh enthusiasm for locally sourced fare.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one million cruise passengers annually visit Juneau, Alaska’s rugged state capital, from May through September, often swarming the town of nearly 33,000 residents on day trips and shore excursions. Its main attractions include the nearby Mendenhall Glacier, where the visitors’ center offers boardwalk trails that overlook bear-viewing areas, and small boat trips to watch orca and humpback whales.

headline: Blatter Speaks Before FIFA Election
abstract: Sepp Blatter addressed the FIFA congress in Zurich on Friday, speaking through a translator before the presidential election. Mr. Blatter is running for a fifth term as president of FIFA.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter addressed the FIFA congress in Zurich on Friday, speaking through a translator before the presidential election. Mr. Blatter is running for a fifth term as president of FIFA.

headline: Drink and Draw
abstract: An all-female art show in East Williamsburg, cleverly named “Girls of Summer.”
lead_paragraph: An all-female art show in East Williamsburg, cleverly named “Girls of Summer.”

headline: Meet ‘Harry,’ a Detective Wrestling With Grief and Drug Trafficking
abstract: This six-part crime drama set in New Zealand stars a Samoan-born actor who also wrote the darkly realistic script.
lead_paragraph: “Someone once said the darkness that surrounds us cannot hurt us,” Harry Anglesea, a police detective in New Zealand, says a month after the unexpected death of his wife. “It is the darkness in our hearts that we should fear.” Unable to cope with his searing grief in solitude, he returns early from bereavement leave to solve a vicious murder involving a young Samoan high on the drug P. But when the trail leads to a major meth shipment headed to Auckland from offshore, the world of the psychologically scarred Harry, which includes a daughter, starts to disintegrate.

headline: Classical Music Ensembles Offer Free Concerts
abstract: Abrons Arts Center and the Miller Theater present new-music groups with no admission fee.
lead_paragraph: The barriers to entry are nil in three free concerts by leading new-music groups. On Sunday, in honor of Henry Street Settlement’s 100th anniversary, the International Contemporary Ensemble and the guest conductor Steven Schick perform George Lewis’s raucous, sly “The Will to Adorn,” Varèse’s “Intègrales” and the original 1944 ballet-score version of Copland’s “Appalachian Spring.” (7 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, iceorg.org.) In the first of two back-to-back Pop-Up Concerts at the Miller Theater, the American Contemporary Music Ensemble plays works on Tuesday by the composer and pianist Timo Andres, including his 2012 Piano Quintet and the New York premiere of “Clear and Cold” for solo piano. The event on Wednesday features an enviable ensemble — the pianist Vicky Chow, the violinist Jennifer Choi and the cellist Michael Nicolas — in three trios by John Zorn. (6 p.m., Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, 212-854-7799, millertheatre.com.)

headline: Maria Schneider, With New Album, to Perform at Birdland
abstract: It has been eight years since Ms. Schneider released an album with the Maria Schneider Orchestra, her flagship band.
lead_paragraph: The composer-arranger Maria Schneider has been the farthest thing from idle in recent seasons: Last year, her music turned up on a film-noirish new song by David Bowie, months after her ambitious album “Winter Morning Walks” won three Grammys in the classical field. But it has been eight years since Ms. Schneider released an album with the Maria Schneider Orchestra, her flagship band.

headline: David Gulpilil Stars in ‘Charlie’s Country’
abstract: David Gulpilil draws on his own struggles for his role in this drama about Aboriginal and white identity.
lead_paragraph: When moviegoers first met David Gulpilil in the 1971 film “Walkabout,” he was an unknown teenager. Now he’s one of Australia’s best-known Aboriginal actors. And he’s still playing characters who are exploring the intersection of traditional and modern cultures in that country — most recently in “Charlie’s Country,” a film by Rolf de Heer that opens on Friday at Lincoln Plaza Cinema.

headline: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet Will Take Final Bow at BAM
abstract: The dance company, founded by a Walmart heiress, abruptly announced its closure in March after 12 highly visible years.
lead_paragraph: Richard Branson has his Virgin Galactic, Elon Musk has his SpaceX, and Nancy Laurie, a Walmart heiress, had her Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet: all visionary pet projects shooting for the stars. For 12 highly visible years, Cedar Lake traced a burning arc through the dance world and, like a meteor, is about to expire. The company abruptly announced its closure in March to the surprise of many and takes a final bow this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Robert Irwin Instillation of Color and Light Returns
abstract: “Excursus: Homage to the Square³ (1998-99),” which was shown in Chelsea 17 years ago, is going on view in Beacon, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Robert Irwin — an artist whose work migrated from galleries “out into the world,” as he put it, in the form of architectural interventions, gardens and barely there tweaks to the perception of the everyday — has had a rich history with the Dia Art Foundation. He collaborated with the foundation on the master plan for its sprawling outpost in Beacon, N.Y., shaping even the parking lot. Now Mr. Irwin, 86, is returning to Beacon with an installation that brings him back into the galleries as a sculptor of space and light. “Excursus: Homage to the Square³ (1998-99),” which goes on view Monday and remains through May 2017, is a maze of translucent chambers, formed with scrim and fluorescent lights, that Mr. Irwin describes as being mostly about color, “with very little matter involved,” and a nod to the color theories of the painter Josef Albers. The installation represents the return of “Excursus” to public view almost 17 years after its premiere at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, where it became a kind of touchstone of Mr. Irwin’s working methods. (3 Beekman Street, Beacon, N.Y.; 845-440-0100, diaart.org.)

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: IN THE KINGDOM OF ICE: The Grand and Terrible Polar Voyage of the USS Jeannette, by Hampton Sides. (Anchor, $16.95.) In June 1881, two years into its Arctic expedition, the U.S.S. Jeannette’s hull was crushed by ice, forcing the commander, George Washington De Long (1844-81), and his 32-man crew to abandon ship 1,000 miles north of Siberia. Sides’s first-rate narrative recounts the horrors (crude amputations, madness, starvation) in the crew’s desperate struggle to survive.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in the West Village, on the Upper West Side and in Manhattan Beach.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in the West Village, on the Upper West Side and in Manhattan Beach.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE DAEMON KNOWS: Literary Greatness and the American Sublime, by Harold Bloom. (Spiegel & Grau, $35.) Inspiration’s origin, sought through close readings of daemon-possessed writers interrogated in pairs (e.g., Twain with Frost).

headline: Cooking
abstract: New cookbooks include “Food52 Genius Recipes,” “Milk Bar Life” and “A Bird in the Hand.”
lead_paragraph: Ask anyone what makes a cookbook a success and you’re bound to get a range of answers. Some of us require the full escapist experience we’d expect of a novel, a ­cover-to-cover immersion in another food lover’s world. Some call it a win if the book offers a single recipe to add to the Forever Repertoire. Others ask: Will it offer techniques and inspiration to apply elsewhere? Will it romanticize the food we grew up with? Or have us sprinting to the nearest farmers’ market to exorcise the food demons of our past? By any of these measures, this spring’s new cookbooks deliver.

headline: ‘Primates of Park Avenue: A Memoir,’ by Wednesday Martin
abstract: Wednesday Martin’s memoir is a takedown of upper-class culture by an outsider with a front-row seat.
lead_paragraph: A few pages into “Primates of Park Avenue,” I raised an eyebrow as high as a McDonald’s arch. Was Wednesday Martin, a ­Midwestern-born Ph.D., trying to explain the rites of the Upper East Side to me, an autochthonous Manhattanite schooled at one of the neighborhood’s top “learning huts”? She was a late transfer to the New York troop — a particularly vicious troop, at that — and it’s a weak position to be in throughout the primate kingdom, whether human or monkey.

headline: Debate Over the Rabbi and the Sauna
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Rabbis', 'Saunas and Sweat Lodges', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: An email thread has again raised questions about the behavior of Jonathan Rosenblatt, the prominent leader of a Bronx congregation, who invited boys to shvitz naked with him.
lead_paragraph: For years, Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt, the leader of an affluent Modern Orthodox synagogue in the Bronx, did something unusual with the boys in his congregation.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a farmhouse in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Glen Cove, Long Island.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a farmhouse in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Glen Cove, Long Island.

headline: 1915: Mental Strain on German Sailors
keywords: ['GERMANY', 'NEW YORK CITY', 'Ships and Shipping', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Sailors on German liners in New York go mad, 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twelve sailors employed aboard interned German liners in New York have lately gone mad. Three became so violent, says the ‘‘Daily Telegraph’s’’ correspondent, that they have been placed in a padded room in the county jail. Dr. King, the official medical officer, describes their malady as ‘‘acute melancholia,’’ produced largely by homesickness and absence from their native land in a time of stress.

headline: A Hobby Anthropologist Dissects the Tribes of the Upper East Side
abstract: For those without crocodile bags, Wednesday Martin offers a look inside an elite coterie with her book, “Primates of Park Avenue.”
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, a woman named Wednesday Martin, a hobby anthropologist whose graduate degree is in comparative literature, published an op-ed article in The New York Times outlining some of the observations she makes in her forthcoming book, “Primates of Park Avenue.” News of the book, a memoir that presents itself as a pop ethnography of Upper East Side motherhood, immediately prompted intense reaction in part because of some of the claims made in it — that wealthy nonworking mothers receive a “wife bonus” for outstanding domestic performance, to cite an example — and in part because Ms. Martin, observed last week table-hopping at Michael’s in jeans and heels, had seemed to so thoroughly embrace the manners of the women she had written about with such an imperious strain of sympathy.

headline: At the Races With a Top Horse Trainer and an Owner
abstract: When Sheila Rosenblum, a New York socialite, met Linda Rice, a trainer and owner, three years ago, Ms. Rosenblum owned a small number of horses that had never won a race. The pair joined with another woman, Iris Smith, to create Triumphant Trio, a rare all-female partnership, which has been attracting attention.
lead_paragraph: When Sheila Rosenblum, a New York socialite, met Linda Rice, a trainer and owner, three years ago, Ms. Rosenblum owned a small number of horses that had never won a race. The pair joined with another woman, Iris Smith, to create Triumphant Trio, a rare all-female partnership, which has been attracting attention.

abstract: Plus, the return of granny panties, ballet in Balmain and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Women Who Bought American Pharoah’s Half Brother
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Women and Girls', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: A syndicate that Linda Rice, a top horse trainer, and Sheila Rosenblum, an owner and New York socialite, started in February with another woman garnered attention when it spent $840,000 on the half brother of the Triple Crown hopeful American Pharoah.
lead_paragraph: For an industry in which the ultimate compliment is being “a real horseman,” Linda Rice is an anomaly. Barely topping 5 feet, Ms. Rice has shoulder-length blond hair and sharp features that could make her a Ralph Lauren model. The first female horse trainer to top the standings at a major racetrack, she’s tough and she speaks at a no-nonsense clip.

headline: One-Tap Giving? Extra Steps Mire Mobile Donations
abstract: Mobile apps can be used to summon a car or order food with a simple tap, but making a charitable donation is not as easy.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, perhaps it was a Memorial Day parade that moved you. The sight of veterans marching might have touched off a desire to make a donation right then and there to the American Legion.

headline: Soft-Shell Crab Arrives With the Heat
abstract: Sauté a bunch in a spicy curry butter, which complements the richness of the crabs.
lead_paragraph: An Alaskan King crab is enormous, with incredibly long legs. By comparison, the hefty, meaty West Coast Dungeness crab seems small.

headline: Australian Start-Ups Lure Silicon Valley Money
abstract: American firms are scouring opportunities in Australia and New Zealand, attracted by a familiar legal and regulatory environment and few competitors.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In November 2013, John Locke and Nate Niparko, two members of the investment team at the American venture capital firm Accel Partners, got off a plane here and jumped in a taxi.

headline: Candida Höfer’s Wide Open Spaces
abstract: Photographing absence in the world’s great theaters and opera houses.
lead_paragraph: The German photographer Candida Höfer is often described as a photographer of empty space. Since 1980, she has focused her lens almost exclusively on the uninhabited interiors of public buildings around Europe and the United States: libraries, universities, museums, palaces, theaters, opera houses.

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
abstract: “Charlie Palmer’s American Fare,” “Healthy Happy Vegan Kitchen” and more.
lead_paragraph: BENU. By Corey Lee. (Phaidon, $59.95.) A lavishly illustrated celebration of the three-Michelin-starred San Francisco restaurant and its Korean-American chef.

headline: Green Garlic Toast
abstract: Melissa Clark makes compound butter with green garlic to spread on toast, among things.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes compound butter with green garlic to spread on toast, among things.

headline: Green Garlic Toast Offers a Hint of Springtime
abstract: The stalks have the spirit of regular garlic, but at a gentle whisper rather than an aggressive roar. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Green garlic season is fleeting.

headline: A Guiding Hand for Those in the Backstretch
abstract: The Rev. Humberto Chavez, who serves the Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga tracks, is a chaplain for the largely unseen workers who keep the horses running.
lead_paragraph: ELMONT, N.Y. — In his years as a chaplain to grooms and hot walkers and exercise riders and the rest of the workers at three racetracks in New York State, the Rev. Humberto Chavez had made countless hospital visits and seen more than enough fractured skulls and shattered legs. Nothing, however, prepared him for the sight of a jockey named Andrew Lakeman in a Long Island medical center one night in May 2007.

lead_paragraph: The mayor was trying not to crack up.

lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss ASAP Rocky’s new album.

headline: New York Nail Salons Now Required to Post Workers’ Bill of Rights
abstract: The placards are the latest effort by city and state leaders to curb the widespread exploitation of workers in the sprawling nail salon industry.
lead_paragraph: Effective immediately, every nail salon in New York will be required to post a manicurists’ bill of rights in clear sight of customers and employees, the latest effort by city and state leaders to curb the widespread exploitation of workers in the sprawling nail salon industry.

headline: Northern Discomfort
abstract: Gloomy Finns, depressed Dutch.
lead_paragraph: The FT has an interesting although garbled story about Finland’s economic woes. Ignore the numbers, which as best I can tell are all wrong (is this becoming an FT trademark?); more crucially, someone seems confused about the difference between wages and unit labor costs. If you go to the Conference Board numbers, you find that Finland has indeed seen a rapid rise in ULC, but not because of a wage explosion; it’s all about collapsing manufacturing productivity.

headline: After Divorce, Losing Veterans’ Support Along With a Spouse
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Marriages', 'Veterans']
abstract: Once you are divorced from a veteran, resources such as counseling go away, and many women who were dependent on their spouses’ incomes find themselves financially in shambles.
lead_paragraph: My wedding day was the first best day of my life. I could not have ordered a more perfect day if I had had a menu of choices in front of me. The marriage to my best friend was what I was really looking forward to. I wanted to settle down and start a family and that’s what we did. Our ideal world was lost on Sept. 6th, 2003. My husband, a member of the National Guard, was activated two days before our second son was born. Two weeks later he went to Iraq on what ended up being almost a year-and-a-half journey where he fought for his country and I fought to maintain our home.

headline: Popcast: ASAP Rocky Returns to a Haze
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss ASAP Rocky’s new album.
lead_paragraph: ASAP Rocky’s music has been blurry before, but on his new album, “At.Long.Last.ASAP,” it’s blurry in a new way. On his first mixtape, in 2011, he was adapting Houston slowness as one of many ways to expand the possibilities of New York hip-hop. Now he’s gone farther and made something closer to an hour-plus of psychedelia, a major hip-hop record with many different producers and guest rappers from many different precincts — Kanye West, Lil Wayne, Future, M.I.A., Rod Stewart — that doesn’t act on the listener the way such records normally do. It remains coherent and unified no matter how much it drifts and disorients. Jon Caramanica, whowrote about the album this week, explains how the album represents the aesthetics of Rocky and his associate ASAP Yams, who died in January.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Most Ugly Child
abstract: Americana from deepest England.
lead_paragraph: I had a really good time over the weekend at How The Light Gets In; to be honest, more the music than the deep thought, but maybe that’s me. Here’s one example, your basic terrific country/Americana band from Nottingham (hey, they have sheriffs too, right)?

headline: Study Using Gay Canvassers Erred in Methods, Not Results, Author Says
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Research', 'Academic and Scientific Journals']
abstract: Michael J. LaCour apologized for misrepresenting some aspects of the study about the effect gay canvassers can have in changing people’s minds about same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: The graduate student at the center of a scandal over a newly retracted study that has shaken trust in the conduct of social science apologized for lying about aspects of the study, including who paid for it and its methodology, but he said Friday in his first interview since the scandal broke that he stands by its finding that gay canvassers can influence voters’ attitudes on same-sex marriage.

headline: ‘Devious Defecator’ Case Tests Genetics Law
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Feces', 'Discrimination', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A company’s use of DNA tests to investigate employee wrongdoing ran afoul of a federal antidiscrimination law.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, Congress prohibited employers and insurers from discriminating against people with genes that increase their risks for costly diseases, but the case that experts believe is the first to go to trial under the law involves something completely different: an effort by an employer to detect employee wrongdoing with genetic sleuthing.

headline: The Unreleased Nikes President Obama Got First
abstract: The company’s new MTM pack is a two-pair combo created in celebration of the 30th anniversary of Air Jordan.
lead_paragraph: What do you give to the man who has everything — no, really, everything, including a bowling alley in his house? Nike has an answer that’s hard to top: When President Obama visited the company’s world headquarters in Beaverton, Ore., earlier this month, he was the first person on Earth to receive the soon-to-be-released MTM, a new two-pair pack Nike is releasing in June in celebration of 30 years of Air Jordan. MTM is named for the three men who designed the two pairs in collaboration: Nike C.E.O. Mark Parker and designer Tinker Hatfield and, of course, Michael Jordan himself. “The MTM is a great way to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Air Jordan franchise,” Jordan says of the collaboration. “It was a lot of fun to work with Tinker Hatfield and Mark Parker on reimagining two of the best shoes we have ever created.”

headline: Why Homeowner Insurance Deductibles Vary by State
abstract: An analysis done for the online site insuranceQuotes.com found that the numerous variations on deductibles can be traced in part to the differences in state laws.
lead_paragraph: AS with most types of insurance, you can lower the monthly premium on your homeowner’s policy by raising your deductible. But whether it makes sense to do so can vary by state, a new report finds.

headline: The “Girls of Summer,” Anatomically Speaking
abstract: A “Drink and Draw” event (where the combination of booze and a nude model give way to liberated, personal sketches) inspired an all-female show last night in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, bare breasts abounded in Vandervoort Studio in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Not in the flesh. But rather, on paper (and on a few pots) along the studio’s white walls and on a table beneath the windows. The art showcased the “Girls of Summer” — a clever anatomic euphemism that lent the pop-up show its name. “I originally wanted to call it ‘free the nipple,'” says Nikki Cohen, the curator of the one-night-only exhibition and founder of the conceptual art project This Place. The concept originated at a “Drink and Draw” — a gathering that This Place regularly hosts around New York City, at which guests sip boozy drinks and sketch a nude female model.

lead_paragraph: Forget that Betty Buckley’s brilliant new show at Joe’s Pub, “Dark Blue-Eyed Blues,” has only a distant resemblance to a blues concert. Yes, Thursday’s opening night included the Harold Arlen-Johnny Mercer standard “Blues in the Night,” but that’s just one of many elements.

That battle is becoming a bit harder as condominium prices start hitting highs comparable to those in pricier Lower Manhattan neighborhoods like SoHo, NoLIta and NoHo.
