headline: Ring 5A for the Secret Skateshop of Washington Heights
abstract: Eugene Kang’s shop grew from a sometime venture in the corner of his living room into a store with skateboards, T-shirts shoes, five-panel hats and patterned socks for those in the know.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Eugene Kang sat in the middle of Terminal Skateshop, telling a story about a problem customer, a neighborhood barber who came in looking to buy a board. Mr. Kang helped him pick one out, along with trucks, wheels, bearings — the works — and, making small talk, asked him where he normally skates. The barber explained that he didn’t; he just wanted to hang the board up at work, for show.

headline: Review: ‘Treetop Cat Rescue’ on Animal Planet
abstract: “Treetop Cat Rescue,” on Animal Planet, follows two specialists going out on limbs to retrieve felines that got stuck.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’ll enjoy Animal Planet’s latest show comes down to how much you trust cats. If you think they’re merely adorable, innocent balls of fur, sure, help yourself to a mindless half-hour. If, on the other hand, you view them as manipulative little buggers intent on world domination, then prepare to be alarmed.

headline: Ross Ulbricht, Creator of Silk Road Website, Is Sentenced to Life in Prison

lead_paragraph: Ross W. Ulbricht, the founder of Silk Road, a notorious online marketplace for the sale of heroin, cocaine, LSD and other illegal drugs, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Despite threats to the Great Barrier Reef from climate change and human activity, United Nations conservation experts stopped short of recommending on Friday that the reef, a World Heritage site, be classified as “in danger.”

headline: Warriors’ Klay Thompson Has a Concussion and Is Indefinitely Sidelined
abstract: Thompson, a guard, was injured in Wednesday but was cleared to return to the game by team doctors. He will not be able to play again until he is symptom free, the team said.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Klay Thompson of the Golden State Warriors sustained a concussion, the team said Friday, casting doubt on his availability for the start of the N.B.A. finals next Thursday.

headline: No, You Can’t Blame Your Belly on Traffic
abstract: A recent study found an association between traffic noise exposure and an increase in abdominal body fat. But it was only an association.
lead_paragraph: Honking horns and screaming sirens could give a city dweller a migraine. But can an urban area’s unruly rhythm also give a person love handles? That’s the claim that some recent headlines made based on a study that looked at traffic noise and obesity.

headline: How Tanya Menendez and Matthew Burnett, Founders of Maker’s Row, Spend Their Sundays
abstract: Ms. Menendez and Mr. Burnett, founders of a start-up for entrepreneurs, start their day in Brooklyn with work, a walk and some basketball.
lead_paragraph: Tanya Menendez and Matthew Burnett are the founders of Maker’s Row, a Brooklyn start-up that connects entrepreneurs with American manufacturers. Forbes magazine recently included Ms. Menendez, 27, in its 30 under 30 issue. Mr. Burnett, 30, is a former watch designer who worked for Marc Jacobs and DKNY. Maker’s Row is their second company: In 2011, Ms. Menendez left a job at Goldman Sachs to join Mr. Burnett at a leather goods line he had started called the Brooklyn Bakery. A year before that, she joined him romantically. The two met through friends at a Roots concert in Prospect Park. They live in a one-bedroom apartment near Borough Hall in Downtown Brooklyn with their dog, Mr. Pickles.

lead_paragraph: It takes more than just good dancers or a committed artistic director, or even a stellar board of directors, to preserve a choreographer’s legacy. Good teachers are also essential, to train all those future heirs.

headline: Review: Manfred Honeck Coaxes a Burnished Sound From the New York Philharmonic
abstract: The Pittsburgh conductor, who some regard as a potential candidate to lead the ensemble, led the orchestra through an unorthodox performance of classics.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic played Mozart, Brahms and Johann Strauss on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. A program so crustily traditional almost feels like news, given the orchestra’s innovative track of the last few months, with intriguingly balanced programs and new(ish) works by Thomas Adès and John Adams, Thierry Escaich and Peter Eotvos. Under Alan Gilbert, evenings of Old World heft are no longer the norm.

headline: Why the S.E.C. Could Use Commissioners With Wall Street Experience
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Two vacancies give the regulator a chance to add market expertise. Critics may gripe about the revolving door, but it pays to know how the financial world works.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission will soon have two top vacancies, and a Wall Street pedigree would be a plus for new watchdogs. Nominees with financial industry ties might prompt gripes about the revolving door, but it pays to know how the market works.

headline: Have We Learned Anything From the Columbia Rape Case?
abstract: The messy conclusion of the dispute between Emma Sulkowicz and Paul Nungesser shows how much universities still have to sort out in dealing with sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Last week, one of the messiest campus sexual-assault cases in recent memory came to an equally messy conclusion when Emma Sulkowicz, aided by four friends, carried a 50-pound mattress onto the stage at a Columbia University graduation ceremony. In a much-publicized art-performance-slash-protest, Sulkowicz had carried the mattress everywhere she went on campus since the beginning of her senior year last fall, vowing to continue to do so until she graduated — or until Columbia expelled a classmate she accused of rape in April 2013. More than seven months earlier, she says, Paul Nungesser, a friend at the time, raped her during what had until that point been a consensual encounter at the start of their sophomore year.

headline: Finding a Toad With a New York Accent
abstract: Once plentiful throughout the five boroughs, it has become difficult to spot a Fowler’s toad in the area.
lead_paragraph: Walking along a little-used trail in Bergen Beach three or four years ago, I came across a pudgy toad scampering across the sandy path. Unlike frogs, which leap gracefully, toads scramble through the underbrush on shorter legs. This one, traveling at top toad speed, may have been motivated by a garter snake following closely, probably with dinner in mind. I sensed a photo opportunity, but the snake preferred to dine alone, and veered off quickly. Undeterred, I photographed the toad and filed the photos. This was fortunate — though I have heard the bleats of a few Fowler’s toads since, this was the last one I have seen in the five boroughs.

headline: Death on the Steppes: Mystery Disease Kills Saigas
abstract: In the past two weeks, more than a third of all saigas have been killed, conservationists have found. The cause of the outbreak is unknown.
lead_paragraph: Before the end of the last Ice Age, saigas roamed by the millions in a range stretching from England to Siberia, even into Alaska. Eventually they moved to the steppes of Central Asia, where they continued to thrive — until the 20th century, when these strange-looking antelopes began flirting with extinction.

headline: Brooklyn Hamlet of Free African-Americans Was Ahead of Its Time
abstract: After New York abolished slavery in 1827, a “black separatist community” was created in what was later called Weeksville.
lead_paragraph: The houses on Hunterfly Road, an abandoned Colonial trail, are the last vestiges of a lost settlement in Brooklyn. Clustered behind a dense meadow rippling with bluestem grass and dandelions, the three wooden houses were once part of Weeksville, a hamlet where more than 500 free African-Americans lived the white-picket-fence dream years before President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation in 1863.

headline: Washington Bans Political Ads From Public Transit
abstract: The ban, which remains in effect through the end of the year and follows a similar move in New York, came after ads critical of Islam were submitted.

headline: Iraq: 14 Are Killed in Hotel Bombings
abstract: The Islamic State took responsibility on Friday for car bombings that struck two luxury hotels in Baghdad, which a security official said had killed 14 people.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State took responsibility on Friday for car bombings that struck two luxury hotels in Baghdad, which a security official said had killed 14 people and wounded 25. The bombings took place in the parking lots of the hotels around midnight Thursday, highlighting the ability of militants to maneuver around strict security measures. Foreigners frequently stay at the hotels. In one attack, a bomb in a parked car hit the Cristal, which used to be called the Sheraton, in the city center, starting a fire in the middle of one of the city’s busiest areas. The hotel is a frequent spot for weddings and is next to an upscale private club. The other attack, a suicide car bombing, hit the Babylon, a recently renovated hotel that sits on the banks of the Tigris opposite the American Embassy.

headline: Iran: Prisoners’ Relatives to Testify
abstract: Relatives of three Americans imprisoned in Iran and of a fourth who has been missing there for eight years will be the featured witnesses on Tuesday at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of three Americans imprisoned in Iran and of a fourth who has been missing there for eight years will be the featured witnesses on Tuesday at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, its chairman, Representative Ed Royce, Republican of California, announced Friday. Mr. Royce said in a statement that their testimony would provide an opportunity “to hear from the families of these four Americans and explore ways to secure their release.” The four are Nagameh Abedini, wife of Saeed Abedini, an Idaho pastor sentenced to eight years; Sarah Hekmati, a sister of Amir Hekmati, a Marine veteran from Michigan sentenced to 10 years; Ali Rezaian, brother of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been held since July and could face up to 20 years on charges including espionage; and Daniel Levinson, son of Robert A. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in 2007. The hearing is taking place a week after the start of Mr. Rezaian’s trial in Tehran, which has been described as a sham by the United States government, outside rights groups and his family.

And despite the relentless pace of development and industrialization worldwide, 80 percent of it remains wild and intact.

headline: The Real America

Of course, if you’ve ever sought advice about how to break in a new glove, you already know that.

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: My Father’s Kidnapping
abstract: My 83-year-old dad was held for ransom. He’ll never forget it.
lead_paragraph: MY father was kidnapped in Nigeria on a Saturday morning in early May. My brother called to tell me, and suddenly there was not enough breathable air in the world. My father is 83 years old. A small, calm, contented man, with a quietly mischievous humor and a luminous faith in God, his beautiful dark skin unlined, his hair in sparse silvery tufts, his life shaped by that stoic, dignified responsibility of being an Igbo first son.

headline: Directing the Final Scene
abstract: My brother and I had different ideas about how to mark our father’s passing.
lead_paragraph: When they pulled out the pump that was keeping my father’s heart going, his hands shot up in the air, and he shouted “Wonderful!” My brother, Jeff, and I knew why. He had been waiting to die for a year, having tried to take his life with far too few pills to do the job. It left him, at 81, doomed to a life sentence with a failing heart that wouldn’t let him be the fun-loving, bridge-playing, romantic crooner we had known. He was happy to be leaving us and we, in turn, were happy to see him go. We’d been mourning him for a year as he faltered and despaired.

headline: Treating H.I.V. Patients Before They Get Sick
abstract: Putting people on antiretroviral drugs as soon as H.I.V. is detected can prolong lives. Do the will and resources exist to do so globally?
lead_paragraph: A major international clinical trial has provided the strongest evidence yet that people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, should get treated as soon as possible, even if they are feeling well, to ward off serious illness and fatal complications in future years. The finding raises the powerful moral question of whether global and national organizations can find the will — and the resources — to protect millions of people from deaths and diseases that could be prevented.

The crisis left many middle-class minority communities strewn with abandoned houses, further widening the already huge wealth gap between African-Americans and whites.

lead_paragraph: Under FIFA’s system, the smallest country has the same voting power as the biggest, and payments from FIFA for projects help to ensure allegiance to Sepp Blatter.

headline: Yorkville, Where Hastert Taught, Is Shaken by Charges for ‘Denny’
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: J. Dennis Hastert worked for 16 years as a teacher and coach in the Illinois city, which has long taken pride in its ties to the former speaker of the House.
lead_paragraph: YORKVILLE, Ill. — For years, J. Dennis Hastert has been the pride of this small city. There may not be a bronze statue in his honor, but that would be counter to what people here have most admired about Mr. Hastert: that someone who once wielded so much power could also be so ordinary, so much like them, so Yorkville.

headline: After Speakership, Hastert Amassed His Millions Lobbying Former Colleagues
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation']
abstract: J. Dennis Hastert’s years as a lobbyist explain how he was able, according to federal officials, to promise $3.5 million to a former student who claims Mr. Hastert molested him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — J. Dennis Hastert, the longest-serving Republican House speaker in history, was swept from leadership in 2006 on a wave of Republican revulsion over what critics saw as a legislative favor factory he presided over in Congress. That wave deposited him on K Street, a prime address for the capital’s lobbyists, where his influence and good name kept the favors flowing — including into his bank accounts.

headline: Martin O’Malley’s Star-Spangled, Snafu-Speckled Debut
abstract: The former governor and mayor had a gorgeous backdrop but a few snags at his presidential campaign announcement on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Martin O’Malley couldn’t have asked for a more picturesque backdrop for his presidential campaign announcement on Saturday: A blue sky met the clear water of Baltimore’s Inner Harbor off Federal Hill Park.

headline: Rangers Left to Digest Another Empty Result
abstract: The team had few answers for its lack of offense and its underwhelming performance at home in Game 7 after losing the Eastern Conference finals to the Tampa Bay Lightning.
lead_paragraph: For these Rangers, simply skating in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals — scoreless with the Tampa Bay Lightning heading into third period — was something of a postseason miracle.

headline: With Veteran Help, Lightning Gain Finals
abstract: A collection of veterans, including Anton Stralman nor Brian Boyle, provided leadership during the Lightning’s run to the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: Last season, the Tampa Bay Lightning watched the Rangers win the Prince of Wales Trophy as the Eastern Conference champions, after being swept out of the playoffs by the Montreal Canadiens in the first round.

headline: Gregorius Inherited Jeter’s Position, but So Far, Not His Defensive Instincts
abstract: Didi Gregorius has shown a lack of awareness and confidence at shortstop this season, two traits that defined his predecessor, Derek Jeter.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The signature play in Derek Jeter’s long Yankees career occurred here. During the 2001 playoffs, the Yankees, clinging to their postseason life against the A’s, were rescued when Jeter raced across the diamond to cut off a throw home and flipped it backhanded to catcher Jorge Posada, who tagged out Jeremy Giambi just before he touched home plate for what would have been a crucial run.

headline: Leadership on View in ‘Art Walk’ Near West Point
abstract: Steps from the United States Military Academy, an exhibition of large-scale sculptures on Main Street, Highland Falls, offers a destination for a warm-weather outing.
lead_paragraph: Under a tree in Ladycliff Park in Highland Falls, three life-size concrete women sit together, their knees jutting up toward their chests. Featureless, armless, their rough-hewed bodies face one another as if engrossed in conversation.

headline: Yogi Berra’s Values Shape Museum’s Mission
abstract: Mr. Berra’s institution in Little Falls on the Montclair State University campus is also a learning center that places increasing emphasis on teaching life lessons to children.
lead_paragraph: May 12 marked Yogi Berra Day in New York and New Jersey, and except for the Drums of Thunder, a drum corps of fourth and fifth graders from Hillside Elementary School in Montclair, it was a quiet, tender affair — part photo opportunity, part nostalgia.

headline: Nashville Debates How to Prevent Another Devastating Flood
abstract: After a May 2010 disaster, the mayor wants to pass a $100 million plan to protect the downtown area, but critics say more could be done to save lives.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — As Texas reels from catastrophic flooding, this booming city on the Cumberland River is contemplating what to do to protect itself in the wake of its own disaster from five years ago, the May 2010 flood that killed 10 people and damaged or destroyed 11,000 properties.

headline: Review of ‘Rock of Ages’ at Gateway Playhouse in Bellport
abstract: The high-octane ‘Rock of Ages’ exploits 1980s excesses with big hair and bigger ballads.
lead_paragraph: “Rock of Ages,” now at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport, is an entertaining, high-energy party. It is also exceedingly silly, but that’s a good thing. If this musical, featuring broad humor and 1980s pop songs, many of them from hair-metal bands like Poison and Twisted Sister, took itself seriously, it could easily become insufferable.

headline: Camping in Church? Make Way for Champers
abstract: Travelers can now spend a night surrounded by history in three of England’s treasured country churches as part of the “champing” program.
lead_paragraph: Glampers, make way for “champers.” Travelers can now spend a night surrounded by history in three of England’s treasured country churches as part of the “champing” program — camping in churches — run by the Churches Conservation Trust. The trust, which cares for more than 340 churches no longer used for regular worship, is offering overnight stays as a way to help preserve the buildings, raise money and promote “slow tourism.”

headline: Japanese Towns Thank Their Moneyed Donors
abstract: The patrons who help finance Japan’s poorer areas not only get tax benefits, they also receive fresh local foods from the towns they support.
lead_paragraph: The patrons who help finance Japan’s poorer areas not only get tax benefits, they also receive fresh local foods from the towns they support.

headline: In Japan, You Get a Tax Break and a Side of Lobster and Beef

lead_paragraph: HIRADO, Japan — Tax breaks come in many forms. Charitable gifts. Health care expenses. Mortgage interest payments.

headline: Review: A Rambunctious Production of ‘Kiss Me Kate’ in Hartford
abstract: “Kiss Me Kate,” at Hartford Stage, remains a merry mix of fisticuffs and sex about the subtle emotions that define love that though exhausted, is not yet extinguished.
lead_paragraph: The most notorious spanking in theater history is being delivered with good-humored gusto at Hartford Stage, where the musical “Kiss Me, Kate” is happily conflating Shakespeare and Cole Porter in a rambunctious production masterminded by the director Darko Tresnjak and the choreographer Peggy Hickey.

headline: E.P.A. Proposal Will Put Bigger Trucks on a Fuel Diet
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to propose rules requiring heavy trucks to increase their fuel economy by up to 40 percent by 2027.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Inside the National Vehicle and Fuel Emissions Laboratory here, a mammoth contraption, with steel rollers, advanced electronics and exhaust tubes, is nearing completion.

headline: Making Projections
abstract: Tom McCoy’s puzzle brings me back to my early years as a mother.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE  — When The Girl was of pre-school age, she liked to dress herself and, as the mature, authority figure in her life, I (metaphorically, Officer) threw her under the bus to her teacher. Those of you who are parents or guardians of small children can probably already see where this is going, but I feel like I need to get this off my chest.

headline: A Florida Police Killing Like Many, Disputed and Little Noticed
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In wrongful death cases in South Florida, lawyers discovered files missing, videos erased and police accounts that sometimes did not match the evidence.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND PARK, Fla. — The witnesses who saw a Broward County deputy sheriff kill a man who had strolled through his apartment complex with an unloaded air rifle propped on his shoulders agreed: Just before he was gunned down, Jermaine McBean had ignored the officers who stood behind him shouting for him to drop his weapon.

headline: Iowa Republicans Move to Draw Candidates to Straw Poll
abstract: With multiple presidential hopefuls indicating that they will not spend money on the gathering this summer, a group of Republican activists in Iowa has become concerned about the importance of the tradition seeming to diminish.
lead_paragraph: With multiple presidential hopefuls indicating that they will not spend money on the Iowa Republican straw poll this summer, the importance of a decadeslong tradition increasingly seems diminished. Concerned about this prospect, a group of Republican activists in Iowa is moving to press candidates into actively participating in the Aug. 8 gathering.

headline: Democrats Seek a Richer Roster to Match G.O.P.
abstract: While Republican presidential candidates can count on a stable of billionaires, none of the top Democratic donors have committed to supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton on a similar scale.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the last few months, Harold M. Ickes, a longtime ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton, has helped organize private meetings around the country with union leaders, Clinton backers and Democratic strategists. The pressing topic: Who will step up to be the Democrats’ megadonors in the 2016 presidential race?

headline: Ukrainian Migrants Fleeing Conflict Get a Cool Reception in Europe
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Favored destinations in the European Union for Ukrainian asylum-seekers have overwhelmingly rejected their applications, saying that unlike other restive nations, areas of Ukraine remain secure.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Volodymyr Zelenyuk knew it was time to bolt when the pro-Russian separatists came to the carwash he owned in the eastern Ukrainian coal town of Antratsyt and demanded his help making and repairing weapons.

headline: Jon Niese’s Troubles Continue as Marlins Thrash Mets
abstract: Niese lasted four innings, his shortest start of the season, while giving up five runs on the way to a 9-5 loss to Miami.
lead_paragraph: Through Jon Niese’s first six starts of the season for the Mets, his successes were largely overshadowed.

headline: Building of Islands Is Debated, but China and U.S. Skirt Conflict at Talks
abstract: After a week of public rancor over China’s rush to build artificial islands on reefs, rocks and atolls in the disputed waters of the South China Sea, an annual security meeting in Singapore presented a chance to lower the temperature.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — It was an unexpectedly direct exchange: With nearly every significant Asian defense official gathered in a single room, a senior Chinese military officer on Saturday defended his country’s island-building spree in the South China Sea and rebuked Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter for saying it threatened the region’s stability.

headline: Rare Stumble for U.S. Women Against South Korea
abstract: The United States will enter the Women’s World Cup on a nine-match unbeaten streak, but a tie with South Korea raised questions about their ability to win a world title.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — The United States will enter the Women’s World Cup on a nine-match unbeaten streak, but a scoreless tie with South Korea on Saturday raised more questions than it answered about the team’s ability to win its first world title since 1999.

headline: Malaysians Seek Escape in Pulp Fiction as Government’s Grip Tightens
abstract: A new-style pulp fiction in Malaysia has tapped into a desire for escapism among younger Malaysians as their country has become more socially conservative.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — When Anis Suhaila wants a cheap thrill, she turns to Instagram and Twitter to learn about the latest Malaysian paperback releases. But she does not buy them in ordinary bookstores here, some of which do not carry the titles she is most interested in.

headline: Lionel Messi Powers Barcelona to Victory in Copa del Rey
abstract: Messi scored two goals as Barcelona completed the second leg of a possible treble with a 3-1 victory over Athletic Bilbao.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Barcelona completed the second leg of a possible treble by winning the Copa del Rey on Saturday, led by an unstoppable Lionel Messi, who opened and closed Barcelona’s scoring in a 3-1 win over Athletic Bilbao.

Putin of Russia for help governing an area coveted by pro-Russian separatists.

headline: Russia’s Barring of Officials Seen as Reprisal
abstract: The European Union confirmed the existence of a list of officials that Russia has barred, a move thought to be retaliation for the group’s barring of Russians said to have backed the annexation of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Russia has barred dozens of European officials from entering its territory in what appears to be retaliation for the European Union’s barring of Russian politicians, officials and businessmen who Europe says have supported the annexation of Crimea or the pro-Russian forces fighting in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Beau Biden, Vice President Joe Biden’s Son, Dies at 46

headline: U.S. Paid Residents Linked to Nazi Crimes $20 Million in Benefits, Report Says
abstract: A report by the Social Security Administration’s inspector general concludes that virtually all of the payments were proper under policies in place at the time.

abstract: Did Batman or Hurricane Sandy bring this couple together?
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Rose Lewis and Timothy Allan Hade were married Saturday at Twin Willows, an estate owned by a family friend in Lyme, N.H. The bride’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: In Sickness and in Laughs
abstract: The bride is to begin work as an operations project manager at a medical center; the groom works for an auto dealership.
lead_paragraph: Elyse Christine Jasmund, the daughter of Elizabeth Donlin Jasmund and David J. Jasmund of Winter Park, Fla., was married Saturday to Andrew Mifflin Starling, a son of Susanne Hollyday Starling and Alan C. Starling of Orlando, Fla. The Very Rev. Richard M. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Knowles Memorial Chapel on the campus of Rollins College in Winter Park.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, May 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Our side isn’t used to being asked for that kind of money. If you asked them to put up $100 million for a hospital wing, they’d be the first in line.”

abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION After 24 years as this show’s host and 46 with CBS, Bob Schieffer, above, signs off by interviewing Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate and former Florida governor.

headline: Outfielder Makes His Debut With the Yankees in a Win Over the Athletics
abstract: Ramon Flores is the fifth player this season to make his major league debut with the Yankees, who remain in first in the American League East with a win in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Here was outfielder Ramon Flores on Saturday afternoon, sitting in a major league clubhouse, wearing a major league uniform. He was at the airport in Philadelphia at 5 a.m., connected in Minneapolis and arrived in the Bay Area in time for lunch. He had seen his name in the starting lineup posted on the wall, had just been congratulated by several teammates and was talking to about a dozen reporters.

headline: The World’s Coming Broadband Divide
abstract: Ultrafast Internet access is spreading unevenly throughout the world. And not getting that kind of broadband access could mean some communities miss out on significant economic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Several events last week pointed out how much business success, economic development and even international competition is starting to depend on once unimaginably fast Internet speeds.

headline: For Some in Chicago, Spike Lee’s ‘Chiraq’ Has a Title That Rankles
abstract: City officials and some residents object to the film’s name, a reference to Chicago’s gun violence, but others say a movie title is not the problem.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In his 1914 poem, an admiring Carl Sandburg called Chicago the “City of the Big Shoulders,” a proud label for the working people who called it home. During the winter of the polar vortex 100 years later, as temperatures dipped below zero and bitter winds whipped off Lake Michigan, miserable Chicagoans quipped that they were living in Chiberia.

headline: John Kerry Cuts Europe Trip Short After Breaking Leg in Bicycle Accident
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Accidents and Safety', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The secretary of state struck a curb while he was cycling near Scionzier, France, and was returning to Boston for treatment.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Secretary of State John Kerry plans to cut short his trip to Europe after breaking a leg while bicycling on Sunday and will return to Boston for medical treatment.

headline: Doctors Seek Test for Deploying New Life-Extending Cancer Drugs
abstract: Identifying which patients are likely to benefit from expensive treatments such as Opdivo, Yervoy and Keytruda could save money and prevent side effects.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — New drugs that boost the immune system’s ability to fight tumors may be one of the greatest medical advances in years, cancer doctors say, pulling some patients from death’s door and keeping them in remission for years.

headline: China Says It Could Set Up Air Defense Zone in South China Sea
abstract: A Chinese admiral told a security forum in Singapore that Beijing could create a zone above disputed areas if it felt it was facing a large enough threat.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese admiral said Sunday that Beijing could set up an air defense zone above disputed areas of the South China Sea if it thought it was facing a large enough threat, according to Chinese news media.

headline: A Special-Needs Parent Against My Will, Learning My Own Adaptive Lesson
abstract: People warned me that I would cry at my daughter’s first adaptive ballet recital, but they didn’t say why.
lead_paragraph: I recently attended my 3-year-old daughter’s first ballet recital. It was one of the hardest things I’ve ever done.

headline: Western Officials Alarmed as ISIS Expands Territory in Libya
abstract: The group’s expansion in Libya gives it an alternative base of operations as it appears to be gaining ground in Palmyra in Syria and in Ramadi in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The branch of the Islamic State that controls Surt has expanded its territory and pushed back the militia from the neighboring city of Misurata, militia leaders acknowledged Sunday.

headline: Grim History Surfaces With Wreckage of Slave Vessel
abstract: The Portuguese slave ship São José Paquete Africa left Mozambique in 1794 bound for Brazil, but never made it past the Cape of Good Hope.
lead_paragraph: The Portuguese slave ship São José Paquete Africa left Mozambique in 1794 bound for Brazil, but never made it past the Cape of Good Hope.

headline: Grim History Traced in Sunken Slave Ship Found Off South Africa
abstract: The Smithsonian will announce Tuesday that the wreckage of a vessel that sank in 1794 has been found, the first time a slaving ship that went down with slaves aboard has been recovered.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Dec. 3, 1794, a Portuguese slave ship left Mozambique, on the east coast of Africa, for what was to be a 7,000-mile voyage to Maranhão, Brazil, and the sugar plantations that awaited its cargo of black men and women.

headline: 1890: A Railway Horror
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A train accident on a drawbridge claimed the lives of women and children in California.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Later telegrams from San Francisco give the following additional details of the accident to the Oakland train, an account of which was cabled yesterday [May 30].

headline: ‘Skylight’ Revival on Broadway Makes Back Investment
abstract: In addition to being nominated for seven Tony Awards, “Skylight,” starring Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy, is also paying off for investors.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway revival of “Skylight,” starring Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy, has recouped its capitalization despite a relatively limited run, the producers said Sunday.

headline: Grim History Surfaces With Wreckage of Slave Vessel
abstract: The Portuguese slave ship São José Paquete Africa left Mozambique in 1794 bound for Brazil, but never made it past the Cape of Good Hope.
lead_paragraph: The Portuguese slave ship São José Paquete Africa left Mozambique in 1794 bound for Brazil, but never made it past the Cape of Good Hope.

headline: This Age of Derp, Kansas Edition
abstract: An experiment that failed, but will be ignored.
lead_paragraph: Menzie Chinn notes the continuing failure of the Kansas experiment with supply-side tax cuts. And yes, it is an experiment — Gov. Brownback said it was, and by cutting taxes radically on the basis of ideology rather than any compelling event, Kansas in effect provided us with a natural experiment on exactly what such cuts accomplish. Menzie uses business indicators; I just look at employment growth since Brownback took office, compared with the nation as a whole (red line). No hint whatsoever of a supply-side boost, and of course a terrible fiscal crisis.

headline: Crane Accident in Midtown Manhattan Injures 7 and Damages Buildings
abstract: The crane was lifting a heating and air-conditioning unit to the top of 261 Madison Avenue when it came untethered, sending the unit falling 30 stories to the ground, the Fire Department said.
lead_paragraph: A heating and air-conditioning unit weighing several tons came untethered from a crane and fell 30 stories to the ground in Midtown Manhattan on Sunday, leaving seven people scraped, bruised and shaken up, officials said.

headline: Beau Biden Introduces His Father in 2012
abstract: Joseph R. Biden III, who was known as Beau, introduced his father, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., during the 2012 Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden III, who was known as Beau, introduced his father, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., during the 2012 Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: A Peep Inside the Former Home of Walter Winchell, America’s Top Transom Peeper
abstract: Eric and Lori Friedman have lived in a house in Edgemont, N.Y., once owned by Mr. Winchell, since 2001. Now, as Mr. Winchell would say, they are ready to scram.
lead_paragraph: The temptation is to begin with a Winchellism like this: “Good evening, Mr. and Mrs. America from border to border and coast to coast and all the ships at sea. Let’s go to press.” So much time has passed since that was a national catchphrase that an explanation would be necessary — an explanation of what Winchellisms were and who coined them.

headline: Seismic Swarms of ‘San Andreas’ Top Box Office
abstract: “Pitch Perfect 2” (Universal) was second, taking in about $14.8 million, for a three-week total of $147.5 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box office data. “Tomorrowland” (Disney) was third. The weekend’s only other new wide-release film, Cameron Crowe’s “Aloha” (Sony) was not able to crack the top five, taking in a sad $10 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Dwayne Johnson became a bona fide movie star over the weekend, powering his “San Andreas” disaster thriller to a better-than-expected $53.2 million in North American ticket sales.

headline: An Artist With Too Many Ideas to Consider Retiring
abstract: Audrey Flack, 84, a contemporary of notables like Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning, is creating new works and shaping a memoir, resisting the urge to retreat full time to her banjo.
lead_paragraph: The thought sometimes flashes through her mind in the sleepless hours after midnight, when she is energized and annoyed by the deluge of ideas flooding her brain.

headline: Netanyahu Lashes Out at Criticism of Israel
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Sunday that his country faces “an international campaign to blacken its name” that was “connected to our very existence.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Sunday that his country faced “an international campaign to blacken its name” based not on his policies toward the Palestinians but “connected to our very existence,” likening the mounting boycott movement to anti-Semitic “libels” of previous eras.

headline: Lennie Merullo, the Last Cub to Play in a World Series, Dies at 98
abstract: Merullo enjoyed a distinction that would elude hundreds of other Cubs: he was the last surviving ballplayer to have worn a Cubs uniform in a World Series.
lead_paragraph: Lennie Merullo was honored by the Chicago Cubs at a June 2014 game, throwing out the ceremonial first pitch and leading the crowd in “Take Me Out to the Ballgame” during the seventh-inning stretch, part of the many events marking Wrigley Field’s 100th anniversary.

headline: 1940: Flanders Evacuation Continues Orderly as Bad Weather Hampers Nazi Bombers
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Residents in English port towns recall the arrival of allied soldiers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A series of dramatic eyewitness descriptions of Allied soldiers arriving in English ports after being evacuated from Flanders was given today [May 31] by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: Beau Biden’s Death Triggers an Outpouring of Grief
abstract: Politicians from both parties, celebrities and others shared their genuine sorrow in statements and on Twitter after Mr. Biden’s death on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a town where few events ever truly break through the thick layer of partisanship, the death of Joseph R. Biden III on Saturday night unleashed an outpouring of sorrow.

headline: ‘Big Bang Theory’ Creates Science Scholarship
abstract: Chuck Lorre and actors on “The Big Bang Theory” have set up a fund for a science scholarship at U.C.L.A.
lead_paragraph: The stars of the “The Big Bang Theory” will be putting their very big paychecks to good use. Actors on the sitcom, as well as members of the crew and the CBS show’s co-creator Chuck Lorre, have created a scholarship at the Univerity of California, Los Angeles, for science students seeking financial aid.

headline: Review: Matthew Aucoin’s ‘Crossing’ Is a Taut, Inspired Opera
abstract: The opera, which had its premiere in Boston on Friday, is based on the diaries of Walt Whitman from his experience tending to wounded Civil War soldiers.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — At 25, the American composer, conductor, pianist, poet and sometime critic Matthew Aucoin has already been an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, made his conducting debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and written pieces for Yo-Yo Ma, among other renowned artists, not to mention lecturing on music and poetry at the Shakespeare Society in New York.

headline: Doris Hart, a Tennis Star Who Deftly Overcame Leg Ailments, Dies at 89
abstract: Although leg and knee conditions left her bowlegged and relatively slow — a leg infection when she was a child led a specialist to recommend amputation — Hart became one of the world’s best players.
lead_paragraph: Doris Hart, who overcame a life-threatening leg infection as a child and became one of the world’s best tennis players in the decade after World War II, died on Friday at her home in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 89.

headline: As Rafael Nadal Awaits, Jack Sock Hopes to Win a Battle of Forehands
abstract: After cruising through three rounds of the French Open, the young American has to face a potent force in Nadal, who is 69-1 at the French Open.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jack Sock has already experienced a Jack Sock Day, which took place last September in Lincoln, Neb. He has also been honored at a University of Nebraska football game and is still hoping to take batting practice with the Kansas City Royals in his other touchstone city.

headline: Jeb Bush Says He Is Still Just Considering a Presidential Run
abstract: Watchdog groups have complained that Mr. Bush has evaded campaign finance limits and disclosure requirements by not declaring himself a candidate, even though he has repeatedly visited early-voting states and hired a staff of political operatives.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush continued to maintain he was merely thinking about a presidential bid when asked on Sunday if he was delaying an announcement to continue courting wealthy donors.

headline: Review: ‘A Human Being Died That Night,’ a Look at an Apartheid Assassin, at BAM
abstract: Nicholas Wright’s play, based on the book by Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, reveals the atrocities committed by the South African police forces during apartheid.
lead_paragraph: The words are sober, almost clinical: “A Human Being Died That Night.” The play that bears this title, on the other hand, reveals in searing, sometimes heart-rending detail the atrocities committed by the South African police forces during the terrible years of apartheid.

headline: Obama’s Trade Deal Faces Bipartisan Peril in the House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: After clearing the Senate last month, the bill to give the president fast-track authority for the Trans-Pacific Partnership will meet skepticism from both sides of the aisle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bruising battle over President Obama’s push for the power to negotiate two potentially far-reaching trade pacts will shift this week to the House, where the White House faces entrenched opposition from Democrats and the stirring of rebellion from the Republicans’ right flank.

headline: Ex-FIFA Official Cites Satirical Article From The Onion in His Self-Defense
abstract: Jack Warner, arrested last week in connection with a criminal investigation, held up the faux news report as evidence, he said, of an American conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: Jack Warner, a former vice president of world soccer’s governing body, FIFA, defended himself against corruption charges on Sunday by citing an article from The Onion, apparently unaware that it was satire.

headline: Review: Donald Berman Balances Fire and Rhapsody at Bargemusic
abstract: The pianist brought quality and thoughtfulness to a program of Berio, Fauré, Scott Wheeler and Ives at this concert hall moored under the Brooklyn Bridge, with a view of Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of an aphoristic gallery of portrait pieces by Scott Wheeler on Friday night, the pianist Donald Berman paused, seemingly to look out the window.

headline: Review: Jane Comfort Signals a Departure With a Moody New Work
abstract: “Altiplano” had its premiere at the La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Jane Comfort is a choreographer with a penchant for fusing text and movement — until now. “Altiplano,” which received its premiere on Thursday as part of the La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, signals a departure for this longtime modern choreographer, who in past dance-theater works has explored the myth of Persephone and notions of beauty with Barbie.

headline: Review: ‘To Life!,’ a Show of Songs Cut From ‘Fiddler on the Roof’
abstract: “To Life!: Celebrating 50 Years of ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ With Sheldon Harnick” presents songs cut from the original “Fiddler on the Roof.”
lead_paragraph: Unless you’re a finicky musical-theater historian or a fanatical devotee of the show being examined, a program of songs discarded from “Fiddler on the Roof” should be a tough sell.

headline: Review: School of American Ballet Workshop Includes ‘Harlequinade’
abstract: Students, often mentored by City Ballet alums, danced a program on Saturday at Peter Jay Sharp Theater that included pas de deux.
lead_paragraph: At the annual workshop performances of the School of American Ballet you can see the past becoming the future: the stars of tomorrow, often coached by the stars of yesterday, frequently in ballets and roles that the teachers danced back when they were promising students. The historical continuity is strong, as is the connection to New York City Ballet. That’s where the teachers had their dancing careers and where many of the best pupils end up. Many of the students have already performed with City Ballet, as children in “The Nutcracker” or “Harlequinade.”

headline: Bartolo Colon Adds a Double to His Legend in a Win Over the Marlins
abstract: Colon scorched a run-scoring double and limited the Marlins to three runs in his seven innings on the mound, earning his major-league high eighth win.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ pitching staff already has a Thor in Noah Syndergaard and a Dark Knight in Matt Harvey. But Bartolo Colon may be the true superhero.

headline: Review: Stephen King Leaps Through Time in ‘Finders Keepers’
abstract: This middle volume of a trilogy that began with “Mr. Mercedes” lacks the high drama of the opening installment, but it has greater depth and time for reflection.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King has won many specialized awards — the Black Quill, the Balrog, the Bram Stoker, just to name a few of the B’s — during his long, incredibly prolific career. But until April he had never won an Edgar for best novel. This is the greatest genre-specific accolade available for crime books and thrillers, and Mr. King finally won it for “Mr. Mercedes,” an atypical King novel published last June. It features a vicious, teasing killer determined to inflict mass violence on crowds of Americans. And it describes him in what is, for Mr. King, a pretty no-frills fashion.

headline: Key Parts of Patriot Act Expire Temporarily as Senate Moves Toward Limits on Spying
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The government’s authority to sweep up bulk phone data in the hunt for terrorists expired temporarily at 12:01 a.m. Monday, but the Senate indicated that legislation to curtail the program is likely to pass this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government’s authority to sweep up vast quantities of phone records in the hunt for terrorists expired at 12:01 a.m. Monday after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, blocked an extension of the program during an extraordinary and at times caustic Sunday session of the Senate.

headline: Review: ‘Red Hot + Arthur Russell’ Pays Funky, Introspective Tribute to a Composer and Musician
abstract: A concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music celebrated the music of Mr. Russell, whose songs have been prized by indie-rock musicians and dance-pop groups.
lead_paragraph: Red Hot + Arthur Russell, which started its two nights at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday, was a tribute to the kind of genre-busting artist who defined downtown New York City in the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: Lifetime’s ‘UnREAL’ Traces the Cracks in Reality TV’s Fourth Wall
abstract: A fictitious show about making a reality show, “UnREAL” unrelentingly asks questions about a format that blurs the line between fiction and reality.
lead_paragraph: Imagine everything on “The Bachelorette” is nonfiction. The kisses and the heavy petting. The warp-speed growth of love-like feeling. The letdowns and the meltdowns. The belief in a happy ending. The current season of the show — the 11th, or 30th if you include its partner show, “The Bachelor” — is only two weeks in, and already, all of those things have erupted.

headline: Review: ‘The Whispers,’ on ABC, an Imaginary Friend With Dangerous Intentions
abstract: This summer series based on the Ray Bradbury short story “Zero Hour” features invaders capable of manipulating electricity and snatching a fighter jet out of the sky.
lead_paragraph: The brightly creepy opening scene of “The Whispers” gives you what you want in the television equivalent of a beach read. While children cavort on an idyllic suburban lawn, one little girl stands off to the side talking to her imaginary friend. Having received her instructions, she goes in the house and gathers the tools — a hammer, a saw — that she’ll need to build a booby trap designed to kill her mother.

headline: Review: ‘American Genius’ Focuses on Rivalries on the Road to Innovations
abstract: This eight-part series on the National Geographic Channel begins on Monday with episodes about Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, and the Wright brothers and Glenn Curtiss.
lead_paragraph: Serious historians would surely find an abundance of oversimplification in “American Genius,” an eight-part series that begins with two episodes Monday night on the National Geographic Channel. But the treatments still have a lot to recommend them, whether it’s raising the profile of some less-heralded historical figures or simply reminding us of the speed of change.

headline: Review: ‘The Sleeping Beauty,’ Reawakened by American Ballet Theater
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s production is the climactic event of American Ballet Theater’s 75th-anniversary season.
lead_paragraph: The ballet of “The Sleeping Beauty” — new in St. Petersburg in 1890 — addresses tradition, renewal and diverse aspects of dance theater. To Serge Diaghilev, the idea of staging it in the West first arose from Tchaikovsky’s music, which, in 1920, he and Stravinsky (Russians unable to return to Russia) found themselves continually playing. But when Diaghilev’s production was realized, in London in 1921 with designs by Léon Bakst, Stravinsky found that its greatest revelation was not Tchaikovsky’s score — for many of us the best and most abundant of all his compositions — but Marius Petipa’s choreography. Its classicism showed, as Stravinsky wrote in his “An Autobiography,” “the triumph of rule over the arbitrary” and “the perfect expression of the Apollonian principle.”

headline: Review: American Symphony Orchestra’s George Perle Centennial Tribute
abstract: The orchestra’s nod to Perle, who died in 2009, included “Transcendental Modulations” in a concert at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: It is a rare encounter with the great musical revivalists Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra that does not involve a lot of scholarly baggage or special pleading for a forgotten composer. But “American Variations: Perle at 100,” an attractive program well played at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, pretty much spoke for itself.

headline: Challenging Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders Gains Momentum in Iowa
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The first evidence that Mrs. Clinton could face a credible challenge in the Iowa presidential caucuses appeared late last week in the form of overflow crowds at Mr. Sanders’s first swing through that state.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — A mere 240 people live in the rural northeast Iowa town of Kensett, so when more than 300 crowded into the community center on Saturday night to hear Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, many driving 50 miles, the cellphones of Democratic leaders statewide began to buzz.

headline: Cogito Ergo Sum
abstract: David Woolf offers a nice, smooth Monday puzzle to ease us into a new solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Confession: One of my favorite cuisines is Korean — I was introduced to it a while back when I was studying a Korean martial art — and I briefly entertained the idea of starting a blog about Korean cooking that I was going to call “SEOUL Food.”

headline: The Population Bomb?
abstract: In the 1960s, fears of overpopulation sparked campaigns for population control. But whatever became of the population bomb?
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, fears of overpopulation sparked campaigns for population control. But whatever became of the population bomb?

headline: The Unrealized Horrors of Population Explosion
abstract: In 1968, a book by a Stanford biologist predicted doom for the planet in coming decades. Whatever became of the population bomb?
lead_paragraph: The second half of the 1960s was a boom time for nightmarish visions of what lay ahead for humankind. In 1966, for example, a writer named Harry Harrison came out with a science fiction novel titled “Make Room! Make Room!” Sketching a dystopian world in which too many people scrambled for too few resources, the book became the basis for a 1973 film about a hellish future, “Soylent Green.” In 1969, the pop duo Zager and Evans reached the top of the charts with a number called “In the Year 2525,” which postulated that humans were on a clear path to doom.

headline: A House Is a Spinning Dome
abstract: It takes only a motor the size of a lawn mower with the strength of a blow dryer to rotate a 2,500-square-foot house in New Paltz, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: It takes only a motor the size of a lawn mower with the strength of a blow dryer to rotate a 2,500-square-foot house in New Paltz, N.Y.

headline: Federal Investigators Fault Medicare’s Reliance on Doctors for Pay Standards
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Medicine and Health', 'Medicaid']
abstract: An overreliance on the American Medical Association may result in inaccuracies in the distribution of more than $70 billion a year to doctors treating Medicare patients, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government relies too heavily on advice from the American Medical Association in deciding how much to pay doctors under Medicare, and the decisions may be biased because the doctors have potential conflicts of interest, federal investigators say in a new report.

headline: Saudis Turn Birthplace of Wahhabism Ideology Into Tourist Spot
abstract: Saudi officials hope a massive project to rebuild Diriyah, featuring parks, restaurants, and museums about traditional Saudi life, will link citizens to their past.
lead_paragraph: DIRIYAH, Saudi Arabia — More than 250 years ago, in this sunbaked oasis of mud-brick houses and ramparts, the ancestors of the Saudi royal family and an outcast fundamentalist preacher formed an alliance that has shaped this land ever since.

headline: Families of 1972 Munich Victims Find New Hope for Remembrance
abstract: A memorial for the 1972 attack will be built in Munich this year, and Olympic officials have shown support for recognition at the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: For 43 years, the families of the victims of the terrorist attack at the 1972 Munich Olympics have pushed and lobbied the German government and the International Olympic Committee for some kind of official acknowledgment to publicly honor those killed in the massacre.
